prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
In silence, truth begins to bloom,
A whisper threading through the gloom.
Not shouted loud, nor carved in stone,
But heard in hush, in marrow, bone.
Truth! I shall speak you—if I dare
To lay my clamor, my pride, my prayer,
And sit beneath the boughs of stillness,
Where thought dissolves and breath is will-less.
For how can I echo your steady tone
If I’ve never known how to be alone?
If every moment brims with noise,
With script, with spin, with false poise?
You rise not from the mouth’s decree,
But from the ear’s humility.
So let me learn the art of wait,
To open wide the soul’s gate.
Then, when the world has ceased its din,
And I have let the false self thin,
You’ll stir within, a quiet spark—
Truth, not spoken, but lived in the dark.
And when I rise, I’ll not pretend;
Truth, I shall speak you—as you descend.

Truth, you dwell not in the shout,
But in the hush that breathes throughout.
I cannot speak you, bold and bright,
If I have never courted night,
If I have never paused to hear
The ache beneath the everyday fear.
To speak you, Truth, I must first kneel,
Let silence pierce what words conceal.
You are not mine to claim or wear,
But a guest I must invite with care.
In listening, you take root and grow,
In quiet soil where insights flow.
Each word I’ve borrowed, loud and grand,
Was built on shifting, false demand.
But here, in stillness, stripped and bare,
I start to meet you, breath by breath.
No armor, no rehearsed disguise—
Just ears attuned to your soft cries.
And when at last I truly hear,
My voice will only hold what’s clear.
Then, not before, I’ll speak your name:
Truth, I shall speak you—born of listening’s flame.

You say I’ll speak you—Truth—if first
I train my heart to do the worst:
To stop, to hush, to simply be,
To let the world’s loud chorus flee.
For how can I repeat your tone
If I have never sat alone,
If every thought is half a scream,
A fractured, flickering daydream?
Truth, you are not mine to own,
Not carved from ego’s brittle stone.
You come in glimmers, thin and slight,
When I release the need to fight.
So let me learn the grace of pause,
To feel the rhythm of your cause.
To listen—not to reply,
But to let your presence draw nigh.
Then, from that depth where shadows play,
My words might carry your pure ray.
Not loud, not proud, but stark and real:
Truth, I shall speak you—having learned to feel.

Truth, you are not a sword I wield,
Nor armor forged on battlefield.
You are the hush between two beats,
The quiet where understanding meets.
I cannot speak you, sharp and clear,
If I have never lent an ear
To wind, to grief, to love’s soft moan,
To all the voiceless things unknown.
To speak you, Truth, I must first bend,
Let silence be both guide and friend.
For every lie I’ve told in haste,
Was born where listening lay waste.
So let me sit, let voices cease,
And welcome you through inner peace.
No grand pronouncement, no decree—
Just honesty that dares to be.
And when at last I hear your tread,
My tongue will echo what’s been said
In stillness, deep beneath the show:
Truth, I shall speak you—having learned to know.

Truth, I shall speak you—yet not now,
For I am loud, and you are slow.
You move like rivers under stone,
While I rush forward, half alone.
To speak you, I must first grow still,
Let every boast and bluff be nil.
For how can lips declare what ears
Have never caught through passing years?
You dwell in pauses, in the space
Between the world’s relentless race.
You rise in those who dare to wait,
Who welcome silence, and its weight.
So let me train my soul to hear—
The crack of dawn, the sighing year,
The unvoiced pain, the hidden grace—
Then speak your name with steady face.
No mimicry, no hollow sound,
But truth that’s rooted, truth that’s found.
And when my listening has grown deep,
Truth, I shall speak you—in your sleep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
In silence, truth begins to bloom,
A whisper rising from the loom
Of thoughts unspun, of hearts undone—
A quiet light beneath the sun.
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not loud in pride, but soft and true.
Like roots that drink the hidden rain,
I learn your voice through joy and pain.
You do not shout, nor claim the stage,
But walk the path of age to age
In breaths between the spoken word,
In songs half-heard, in wings unstirred.
To speak you, truth, I must first kneel,
Let stillness break the mind’s hard seal.
For only ears attuned to grace,
Can hear your slow, enduring pace.
So I will wait, I will attend,
On you, my compass without end.
And when at last my silence grows
A garden where your presence flows,
Then from my lips, no longer mine,
Your voice will rise—pure, undivined.

Truth, you dwell not in the shout,
But in the hush the world leaves out.
You slip through cracks in hurried speech,
Where souls are still, beyond their reach.
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I let stillness shape my view.
Not carved in stone, nor signed in flame,
But breathed in dusk, in sorrow’s name.
You come not when the ego calls,
But when the inner chamber falls
Away—like walls that once confined,
Now open to the wind, the wind
That carries echoes of the real,
Of wounds that heal, of what is sealed.
To speak you, I must first be small,
A vessel, not a fortress wall.
So I will sit where noise decays,
And learn the art of hidden ways.
For only in the deep, dark soil,
Does truth emerge to touch the toil
Of one who dares to not proclaim,
But listen first—then bear your name.

You are not found in bold decree,
But in the hush beneath the sea
Of voices clamoring to be known.
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
If I let silence be my tutor,
If I refuse the gilded fraud.
You slip through fingers clenched with pride,
Where arrogance has long denied
The ache of what is unconfessed,
The weight of dreams laid to rest.
You rise in moments unadorned,
In glances where defenses are torn.
Not in the lecture, nor the scroll,
But in the tremor of the soul
That dares to stand without disguise,
Beneath the vast, unblinking skies.
To speak you, truth, I must first hear
The sobs that time could never clear,
The unvoiced grief, the stifled cry—
Then from that well, your words run high.
So I will train my heart to wait,
To open every bolted gate.
For only lips that first inhale
The breath of silence can exhale
Your name—not mine, but ever true—
A voice shaped by listening to you.

Truth, you do not wear a crown,
Nor march with thunder through the town.
You dwell where footsteps fade to none,
Beneath the moon, beneath the sun,
In spaces words have never filled,
Where broken hearts are slowly healed.
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
If I let stillness be my guide,
If I sit long with what's denied.
You are not seized, but slowly known,
Like seeds that wait beneath the stone.
No triumph marks your quiet birth,
Just depth replacing thoughtless mirth.
You speak in shadows, not in light,
In absence, absence of the fight
To prove, to win, to claim, to own—
You're found when I am most alone,
Yet not forsaken. In the hush,
You stir the ember into flush.
To speak you, I must first be still,
Let go of every scripted will.
Then from the silence, soft and vast,
Your voice may rise—unforced, unpassed.
Not mine to own, but mine to say,
If I have learned to hear your way.

Truth, you slip through fingers wide,
A ghost that walks on silent tide.
Not carved in law, nor sworn in court,
But felt in breath, in every sort
Of quiet ache, of unshed tear,
Of moments lived without a peer.
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
If I forsake the need to know,
And let your currents ebb and flow.
You do not shout, you do not plead,
But plant your seed where silence feeds.
No fanfare marks your slow ascent,
Just cracks where broken light is sent.
You speak in pauses, not in sound,
In holy ground where none is crowned.
To utter you, I must first bend,
Let go of all I thought I'd defend.
For truth is not a prize to keep,
But something buried in the deep—
A pulse beneath the noise we make,
A tremor in the soul's own lake.
So I will wait, I will attend,
Until my listening has no end.
Then, from my lips, not loud, but clear,
You may emerge—because I hear.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
In silence, truth first learns to grow,
Not in thunder, nor in show.
I’ve worn the cloak of quiet years,
Where doubt dissolves and listening clears.
Truth! I shall speak you—if I hear
The hush between the wind and fear,
The whisper rising from the deep,
Where even shadows fall asleep.
Not forced, nor shaped by pride or art,
But drawn from chambers of the heart
That strain to catch what’s barely said—
A breath, a sigh, a tear instead.
So let me stand in stillness long,
A vessel shaped by silence, strong.
For only when my soul takes heed
Will truth arise, and plant its seed.
And when at last my lips unbind,
It will not be my voice, but thine.
Truth! I shall speak you—soft, sincere—
When I have learned to lend an ear.

Truth, you dwell not in the shout,
But in the hush that lingers out
Beyond the clamor, past the lie,
Where only listening eyes pry.
I cannot speak you, bold and bright,
Unless I’ve met you in the night,
Where questions fold like wings at dawn,
And every answer must be drawn
From depths where noise has never been,
A sacred, almost-forgotten scene.
To speak you, Truth, I must attend—
Not as a master, but a friend
Who sits in wait, who does not press,
But grants you space and gentleness.
For how can voice proclaim your name
If ears have never learned your frame?
So I will listen, slow and true,
Until my silence speaks for you.

You said I’d speak you—Truth—
Only if I first gave ear,
Not leapt with tongue in reckless haste,
But knelt where quiet thoughts are placed.
So I have trained my breath to slow,
To watch the roots of meaning grow
Beneath the soil of daily noise,
Away from pride, from need, from poise.
I’ve turned my face from hollow light,
To trace your outline in the night.
You do not shout, you do not plead—
You stir in moments I concede
To stillness, to the ache, the tear,
To what I’ve buried year on year.
Now, when my voice begins to rise,
It carries not my will, but sighs
Of all I’ve heard in silent prayer:
Truth, here you are—because I cared.

Truth, I have chased you through the storm,
With fists of words and lungs outworn.
But you evade the boastful cry—
You answer only to the eye
That watches, waits, and does not press,
To ears that long for tenderness
Of tone too faint for common sound,
A pulse beneath the hallowed ground.
Now I sit low, remove my shoes,
Unlearn the lies I used to use.
For speech that bears your sacred name
Must rise from listening, not from claim.
I’ll not pretend I know your face
Until I’ve met you in this space
Where silence sings and hearts align—
Then, Truth, I’ll speak you, word by line,
Not as a conqueror, but one
Who finally learned to be undone.

To speak the truth, one must first hear—
Not just the voice, but what’s held dear
In pauses, cracks, and stifled cries,
In unshed tears and distant skies.
I used to think that truth was loud,
A banner stretched above the crowd.
But now I know it walks so near,
It asks for presence, not for fear.
So I have stilled my rushing mind,
Let questions linger, unconfined.
I’ve learned the art of holding space
Where truth may show its gentle face.
No proclamation born of pride
Can carry what the quiet side
Reveals in time, in trust, in grace—
Truth speaks through those who first embrace
The gift of listening, deep and long.
Then, and then only, comes the song.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
In silence deep, where shadows creep,
A whisper stirs the breath of night—
Truth, barefoot, through the thicket leaps,
Cloaked in absence, veiled in light.

I sought you loud with tongue aflame,
Declared your name on every street,
Yet you withdrew, a fleeting name,
A pulse beneath a frozen sheet.

But when I stilled, when words withdrew,
And sat beneath the listening trees,
You rose not as a shout I knew,
But rustled through the swaying leaves.

You do not dwell in bold decree,
Nor ride the storm of argument.
You bloom where quiet dares to be,
In soil of thought, where roots are bent.

Truth! I shall speak you—not with pride,
But when my ears have learned your tone,
When in the hush I’ve opened wide
The chambers of the heart, alone.

Then speech may wear your gentle face,
Not forged in fire, but shaped in grace.

Truth, you are not a thing I claim,
Nor pin upon a speaker’s chest;
You drift like scent without a name,
In pauses where the world’s at rest.

I used to shout, convinced I knew
The shape and sound that you should wear.
But every boast, each bold adieu,
Left only echoes in the air.

Now I sit where rivers hush,
Beneath the arch of starless eaves,
And train my soul to not rush,
To let the quiet build its eaves.

For you, Truth, are not proclaimed,
But overheard in breath between,
In glances that remain unnamed,
In spaces where the mind’s unseen.

So speak I shall—but not before
My silence learns your quiet tread.
I’ll speak you when my lips implore
Not praise, but what the stillness said.

You said I’d speak you—only then,
When listening shaped my soul’s refrain.
Not in the clamor, not the pen
That writes before it feels the pain.

I used to wear your name like gold,
A medal forged in argument.
But every story I extolled
Was half-true, half my own lament.

Now I walk where voices cease,
Along the edge of falling streams.
I crave not victory, but peace,
And you—born out of listening dreams.

For truth is not a sword I wield,
Nor flag I plant on conquered ground,
But seed that grows in time revealed,
In quiet where no noise is found.

So I attune my inner ear,
Let silence scour my pride away.
And when at last you draw near,
My words will wear your face that day.

Truth, I once thought I owned your voice,
That I could summon you on stage,
Command you forth with lifted choice,
And cage you in a reasoned page.

But you withdrew, slipped through the lines,
Avoided every bold decree.
You dwelled not in the sharp designs
Of logic’s cold geometry.

Instead, you lived where stillness grew,
In gardens tended without sound,
Where questions lingered, soft and true,
And answers rose from hallowed ground.

So now I learn to stand and wait,
To let the wind instruct my ear.
I’ll not dictate, I’ll not translate—
I’ll listen first, then you’ll appear.

And if one day my lips speak clear,
It’s only because I first drew near.

I thought to speak you, bold and bright,
To wear you like a knight’s true crest.
But you eluded every light,
A guest who favors quietest.

You do not answer to demand,
Nor rise when summoned by the wise.
You walk the edges of the land
Where listening clears the inner eyes.

So I unlearn the need to preach,
The urge to prove, to dominate.
I seek the corners out of reach,
Where silence holds a greater weight.

And in that hush, a breath, a sign—
A tremor in the air, a thread.
You start to stir, and then to shine,
Not said, but born inside my head.

Truth, I shall speak you—yes, but when
My soul has learned to listen, then.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
In silence, truth begins to bloom,
A whisper rising from the loom
Of quiet moments, deep and wide,
Where thoughts like rivers gently glide.
Truth! I shall speak you—if I hear
The hush between the wind and fear,
The pulse beneath the spoken word,
The uninvited, singing bird.
Not in thunder, not in boast,
But in the calm where truths are host.
I learn to listen, ear to ground,
Where hollow noise is nowhere found.
You come not when I call your name,
But when I dim the flame of shame,
When ego fades and eyes grow still,
And I accept your steadfast will.
Oh, not a sword, but softest light,
You dawn in those who seek the night.
So let me sit, let me attend,
Let me on humble silence spend
The hours, until your voice, so clear,
Rings not from me—but through me, here.

Truth, you are a timid deer,
Startled by the slightest sound,
I must sit among the ferns,
And make no move, make not a sound.
If I am in habit of listening,
Perhaps you’ll graze into my sight,
A flicker in the morning mist,
A glimmer bathed in silver light.
I’ll not reach to hold or claim,
Nor cage your grace in spoken line,
But wait—attentive, still, and bare—
Until your presence makes me mine.
For truth is not a thing to seize,
But one that comes when called by ease,
When ego sleeps and hearts grow wide,
And silence stands as open guide.
So I will listen, day by day,
And let the false words fall away,
Until from depth, without a cry,
You rise—and I, at last, reply.

Truth, I’ve chased you through the storm,
With fists of logic, words in swarm,
But you slipped through every claim,
A shadow without a name.
Now I sit beneath the oak,
Let thoughts dissolve like morning smoke.
No plea, no cry, no grand demand—
Just open palm, unclenched hand.
If I am in habit of listening,
Perhaps you’ll hum a single tone,
Not in the roar, but in the hush,
In seeds beneath the frozen stone.
You speak not loud, nor wear a crown,
But rise where stillness weighs the town.
You are the breath behind the speech,
The wound that teaches how to reach.
So I will wait, and I will hear,
Not with my mind, but with my fear,
Until the noise of me gives way,
And truth begins to softly say:

Truth, you are not carved in stone,
Nor etched in proclamations known.
You live in pauses, deep and wide,
Where wounded hearts and dreamers hide.
If I am in habit of listening,
I may hear your tender tread,
A footfall soft on mossy ground,
A voice among the quiet dead.
Not in the shout, the bold decree,
But in the ache of what might be.
You come when armor starts to fall,
When pride surrenders, last of all.
I’ll tune my ear to silent cries,
To unshed tears and clouded eyes,
For truth is not a thing I own,
But one that seeds in blood and bone.
So let me listen, let me stay,
Until you shape my words one day,
And from my lips, without disguise,
You speak—not I, but you—arise.

Truth, you hide in plainest sight,
Behind the veil of day and night,
Not in the glare of bold pretense,
But in the hush of common sense.
I’ve shouted, argued, claimed your name,
Yet missed you in the very flame
That lit my pride, my need to know—
You dwelled where quieter waters flow.
Now I sit, I breathe, I cease,
I trade my noise for inner peace.
If I am in habit of listening,
Then maybe, just maybe, you’ll come near,
Not in thunder, not in storm,
But in the shape of something warm
That hums beneath the skin of things—
The song the broken heart still sings.
You are the root, the unseen thread,
The word unsaid, but clearly said.
So here I wait, with open ear,
For truth to draw me ever near.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
In silence woven through the hush of dawn,
Where whispers climb the latticework of bone,
A voice emerges, not from tongue or breath,
But from the soil of near-forgotten death.

Truth! I shall speak you—if my ears are wide,
If I have knelt where shadows coincide,
If I have let the quiet crack my chest
And let your syllables replace my rest.

For you are not a shout, nor sharp decree,
But moss beneath the stone, the root, the key.
You bloom where listening has learned to kneel,
Where ego thins and silence starts to heal.

And so I train my soul to hear your tread,
To catch the word that hangs unsaid, unsaid.
Not mine to claim, but mine to let unfold—
A truth that speaks when I am brave and old.

So let me stand not as a sage or seer,
But as a vessel tuned to what is near.
Truth! I shall speak you, if I first attend—
If I am in the habit of listening.

Truth! I shall speak you—when the wind retreats,
And every lie I've worn dissolves in sheets
Of morning mist that lifts from frozen ground.
Only then do your quiet roots make sound.

Not in the clamor of the crowded square,
Nor in the boast that brags itself aware,
But in the hush where longing learns to wait,
Do I begin to resonate your weight.

To speak you, Truth, I must first let you near—
Not as a guest, but as the atmosphere.
I must unlearn the noise I called my voice,
And trade my pride for stillness as my choice.

For you are not a weapon or a crown,
But water seeping gently into ground.
You ask for no allegiance, no decree,
Just ears that stay unstoppered, quietly.

So train me, silence, in your patient art,
To let you speak before I claim my part.
Truth! I shall speak you—if I first attend,
If I am in the habit of listening.

Truth! I shall speak you—when the mirrors break,
And all the faces I have worn awake
Not as disguises, but as dust and thread,
Then might your voice rise softly from the dead.

For how can I proclaim what I ignore?
How chant your name when I lock every door
To the quiet ache, the uninvited thought,
The whispered doubt that cannot be bought?

You do not live in slogans or in stone,
But in the tremor of the flesh and bone
That dares to feel the weight of what is real,
Not spun from pride, nor polished to conceal.

To speak you, I must first let silence grow
A garden where your seeds of knowing blow.
I must become a listener, not a sage,
A student kneeling at attention’s stage.

So teach my breath to pause, my heart to hear—
Let listening become my native air.
Truth! I shall speak you, if I first descend,
If I am in the habit of listening.

Truth! I shall speak you—when the masks I wear
Have slipped like sand into the evening air,
And nothing’s left but skin and breath and fear.
Only then might your voice draw near.

Not in the boast, the polished, proud refrain,
But in the crack, the sob, the soft terrain
Where vulnerability begins to bloom
And silence clears the path to your dim room.

For speaking truth demands a deeper art—
Not crafting speech, but opening the heart
To hear the murmurs buried deep within,
The quiet pulse that chaos would shut in.

I cannot speak you if I never hear
The hush between the footsteps, sharp and clear,
The unvoiced grief, the joy I’ve disavowed,
The self I’ve muted in the name of proud.

So let me practice stillness, slow and long,
Let listening become my daily song.
Truth! I shall speak you—if I first attend,
If I am in the habit of listening.

Truth! I shall speak you—when the storm has passed,
And what remains is not the first, but last:
The fragile note that lingers in the breast,
The quiet knowing that won’t be repressed.

Not in the thunder of a righteous claim,
Nor in the fire of an untamed name,
But in the hush where all defenses fall,
Do I stand ready to proclaim your call.

For speech without the gift of deep regard,
Is hollow echo, not the soul laid bare.
You speak through wounds, through cracks in certainty,
Through all I’ve feared and tried so hard to flee.

To voice your name, I must first learn to kneel,
To let your presence make the silence real.
Not as a master, but a humble guest,
Who finds you present in the calm unrest.

So train my ears to hear before I speak,
Let listening grow strong where pride was weak.
Truth! I shall speak you, if I first descend,
If I am in the habit of listening.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have braved the stormy sea,
Nor scaled the cliffs where silence sings,
Nor traced the path on broken wings.

For thee, I’ve watched the stars grow dim,
And walked where shadows seldom brim;
Through fields of frost and gardens bare,
I breathed a name upon the air.

Not gold, nor fame, nor endless years,
Could match the weight of love that bears
The quiet ache, the tender plea—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

I’d trade the sun, the moon, the sky,
To see your gentle eyelids sigh;
To hear your breath in morning’s gleam,
And live within a single dream.

So take this heart, both scarred and free,
It beats for no one else but thee;
No sacrifice too vast or steep—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would dawn have found me on my knee,
Petitioning the hush of night
To yield one glimpse of thy soft light.

I've turned from crowns and kingdoms bright,
From songs that danced in golden flight,
For in thy gaze, the world I see
Outshines all else eternally.

No mountain high, no ocean wide,
Could match the depths where thou dost hide
Within my soul—a constant sea,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

I’d silence every poet’s tongue,
Unwrite each verse that’s ever sung,
To craft one line, sincere and deep,
Where only thine and my hearts sleep.

So let the stars forget to burn,
If lessons of thy love I learn;
For life, for death, for all to be—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have learned what it means to be
A flame that flickers, bold and wild,
A weeping willow, reconciled.

I’ve shed the masks I used to wear,
And faced the void with trembling prayer,
All for the grace that dwells in thee—
A boundless, bright eternity.

Not wealth, nor wisdom, nor acclaim,
Could soothe my soul the same, the same,
As just one touch, one word from thee—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

I’d wander deserts, stark and bare,
Forget my name, forget my prayer,
If in the end, I found your hand
Outstretched to help me understand.

So bind my fate, my breath, my plea—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would silence speak so tenderly.
I’ve left the noise, the rush, the fray,
To hear you breathe at break of day.

No jewel, no throne, no crown so high,
Could lift me half as you lift the sky
When morning blushes, soft and free—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

I’d give the echoes of my past,
The dreams I held too firm to last,
If in their place, I could hold you,
And find the world made fresh and new.

So let the seasons come and flee,
My heart remains secured in thee—
No greater gift, no destiny—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have crossed the midnight sea,
Where tides of doubt and longing meet,
And hearts are lost beneath the heat.

I’ve burned my maps, erased my name,
To walk beside your quiet flame;
No harbor calls, no land to see—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

I’d trade the music of the spheres,
The laughter caught in bygone years,
For one soft glance, one word from thee—
A truth no time could ever free.

So let the world forget my plea,
My soul is tethered, bound to thee;
No higher cause, no victory—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

responses.text:

Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

responses.text:

So take this heart, this fragile flame,

Dear love, for nothing less than thee

Not fame that gilds a fleeting name,

Could match the grace within your eyes,
The quiet truth in your replies.
For thee, I'd face the longest night,
Endure the storm, embrace the fight.
Each breath I draw, each step I take,
Is for your sake, for your sake.
You are the compass, you the shore,
The breath that leaves me wanting more.
In every star, I see your face;
In every dream, I find your grace.
So take my life, my soul, my all—
No greater gift could ever fall.
Dear love, for nothing less than thee

Dear love, for nothing less than thee

I'd trade the moon’s pale, watching eye,

Not empires built on blood and gold,

Could rival what your silence gives—
The peace that only passion lives.
You are the fire, the hush, the spark,

My heart, once closed, now dares to see:

So let the tides forget the shore,
Let every truth be known no more.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I believe in destiny.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I abandon memory,
The scent of rain on summer fields,

I’d leave the music, leave the art,
Unlearn the language of the heart,
If only you would stay and be

Not all the wonders time has known,
The pyramids, the seeds once sown,
Could match the miracle I see
Each time you smile, each time you're near me.
You are the verse, the rhyme, the breath,
The life that conquers even death.
In you, the scattered stars align,

So take my past, my fears, my pride—

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I dare to finally be free.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unlock what’s locked in me,
The hidden streams, the silent cries,

I’d trade the sun, the moon, the sky,

For just one breath, one touch, one glance,
One fleeting chance to take your chance.
Not power, nor the sage’s mind,
Nor treasures left by humankind,
Could stir the depths your presence stirs—
The quiet hum beneath the words.
You are the dawn, the dusk, the song,

My soul, once restless, now takes flight,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee

No star so bright, no song so clear,
Could move my soul as thou art near.
Thy voice, a lullaby soft and low,
Unravels all I’ve come to know.
I’d trade the mountains capped with snow,
The rivers where the wild winds blow,
For just one glance, one breath, one sigh,
Beneath the vast and vaulted sky.
For in thy gaze, the world takes form,
A shelter safe from every storm.
No treasure mined from deep below,
Could match the grace I’ve come to know.
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unbind my soul to be
Lost in the echo of thy name,
A flickering light, a dying flame.
Yet even then, I would not flee—
For thee, my heart, eternally.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would time unspool so endlessly.
The moon might wane, the tides retreat,
But I’d still kneel at thy quiet feet.
No empire built on gold or pride,
No kingdom stretching far and wide,
Could lure me from thy gentle hand,
Or break the bond we understand.
Thy laughter is the morning’s chime,
A rhythm lost to measured time.
Each word you speak, a sacred thread,
Weaving through dreams inside my head.
I’d sacrifice the sun’s first ray,
The colors of the breaking day,
To feel your breath upon my cheek,
To hear you whisper, soft and meek.
For love like ours defies the years,
Transcends the weight of hopes and fears.
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender all I be—
And even then, with final breath,
I’d choose you over life and death.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I dare to walk the sea,
Or chase the wind through barren lands,
With empty heart and trembling hands.
No bloom that springs from winter’s sleep,
No lullaby the stars might keep,
Could warm the chill of nights alone,
Or turn my weary bones to stone.
Thou art the pulse within my chest,
The calm when all the world’s distressed.
A single touch, and I am whole,
No longer searching for my soul.
I’d trade the songs of seraphs high,
The glow of dawn across the sky,
For just one moment by your side,
Where all my fractured thoughts collide.
For love like this is not a plea—
It is the breath, the blood, the key.
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unlearn what it means to be,
And in that unbecoming, find
Eternity within thy mind.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unclench my memory,
Release the past, its joy and pain,
And step into the wind and rain.
No crown of thorns, no gilded throne,
Could make me claim a life unknown,
If thou wert not beside me there,
To share the weight, to breathe the air.
Thy presence is the quiet grace
That paints the world in softer face.
Each shadow fades when you appear,
And doubt dissolves, dispelled by fear.
I’d give the poems left unsung,
The tales my trembling voice has flung,
For just one night beneath your stars,
Where silence speaks and healing bars
Are lifted from my aching chest—
For in your arms, I find my rest.
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I dare to dream, to be,
To rise, to fall, to start anew—
My soul belongs, eternally, to you.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I uproot my destiny.
The path I walked, though long and steep,

No ocean vast, no desert wide,
No fortress where the proud reside,

My heart, once called by your refrain.
Thou art the fire in frozen air,

A single glance, and I am thine,
No longer bound by space or time.
I’d trade the music of the spheres,
The wisdom gathered over years,
For just one kiss, one fleeting touch,
That means to me so very much.
For love like ours defies the end,
A timeless flame, a faithful friend.
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I abandon liberty—
And find, in chains of sweet desire,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text: Dear love, for nothing less than thee, I'd trade the stars that stud the night, the moon’s soft glow, the ancient sea, and every sun that claims the light. Not empires vast, nor golden throne, nor songs that echo through the years, could match the depth I feel, unknown, when gazing into all thy tears. For in thine eyes, the world takes form—new Eden sprung from silent breath; each whisper, each approaching storm, is sacred in the dance of death. I'd leave the heavens, cold and wide, to walk with thee through mortal rain, to stand with you, my constant guide, through joy, through loss, through grief, through pain. No treasure, no immortal fame, could sway my heart from where it lies: enfolded in love’s gentle name, beneath the vast, forgiving skies. So take this soul, this breath, this bone—dear love, for nothing less than thee, I walk this earth, and stand alone, yet never am I less than free.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee would I unlearn the sky’s blue tongue, or trade the hush of bended knee for something fleeting, falsely young. The seasons turn with quiet grace, yet none compare to how you bloom—each glance a sunlit, sacred space, dispelling shadows, lifting gloom. I’d silence poets, still their quills, to hear your laughter, soft and clear; I’d trade cathedral-steady hills for just one moment, drawing near. Not fame, nor fortune, nor the crown of ages past could hold my name—no, only where your hands come down to lift me through love’s gentle flame. The world may spin on gears of gold, but I am tethered to your breath; a story truer to be told in silence, love, beyond the death. So take this heart, both cracked and true, for nothing less than you could be the reason that I dare break through—to love, to live, to finally be.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee would I forsake the morning’s blush, the quiet hush of forested tree, the ocean’s hymn in tidal rush. I’d trade the dreams that poets write, the lullabies of distant spheres, for just one breath, one glance, one light that flickers when you dry my tears. No jewel, no crown, no endless sky could match the worth I find in you—your voice, the reason I still try; your touch, the world I walk into. The stars may burn for centuries, but you’re the flame that warms my core; with you, even silence sings with ease, and every ending feels like more. I’d leave the music of the spheres, the echoes of eternity, to spend my fleeting, fragile years entwined, in love, with only thee. For nothing less—no grand design, no fate, no god, no mystery—could make this trembling heart align the way it does, dear love, with thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee would I unweave the evening’s thread, or trade the scent of rain-wet tree for promises long left for dead. The moon may pull the tides with ease, the wind may write on shifting sand, but none could stir my soul like these—your fingers laced within my hand. I’d silence every ancient bard, erase the sonnets carved in stone, to hear your voice, though soft and scarred, speak gently, calling me your own. Not glory, nor the world’s acclaim, nor endless days of golden light, could match the quiet of your name whispered in love’s most tender night. So take my years, my dreams, my song—this fragile life I can’t reclaim. For nothing less than you feels strong, and nothing less could bear my name. In every breath, in every plea, in every hope that dares to be, I find the truth I long to see: dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee would I disturb the sleeping dew, or trade the hush of history for moments lived anew with you. The mountains stand, the rivers flow, the stars compose their distant psalms, yet none could make my spirit glow like shelter found within your palms. I’d trade the wisdom of the sage, the comfort of a well-worn book, for just one page, one whispered page, where love is written in your look. No crown, no throne, no endless spring could match the grace I see in you—the way you rise, the songs you sing, the way you make the broken new. So take my doubt, my fear, my past—each shadow that I thought I knew. For nothing less than love so vast could make a mortal feel so true. And in your arms, the world recedes; time slows, the noise begins to flee. Dear love, for nothing less than these—your soul, your heart, your all—are thee.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:

So take this heart, both scarred and true,

Not time, nor distance, nor the years,

The quiet strength of this decree:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

I've danced with shadows, dreamed of flame,

Yet still, the silence answered back

No jewel, no throne, no poet's rhyme,

So let the stars forget their course,

I'll stand where thou and I may be,

And if the heavens should deny,

Still would I whisper, wild and free:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee

No harvest moon, no summer's grace,
Could match the light upon your face.
I've turned from crowns, from wealth, from fame,
To whisper softly your true name.

The tides may mock, the winds may chide,

Beyond the weight of hopes and fears.

In every leaf, in every stream,

A bond too vast for mortal sight.

So take my all, my breath, my plea:
For nothing less than thee.

And should the world dissolve to dust,
And time unmake what once we must,
One truth will stand eternally:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have crossed the midnight sea,
Or learned the tongue of distant birds,
Or kept the silence of the words

Too sacred for the light of day,
Too fierce to ever fade away.
No gentle breeze, no mountain high,
Could lift my soul as thou dost fly.

Thou art the hymn my heart repeats,
The rhythm pulsing under streets
Of memory, where shadows play
And call your name throughout the day.

I've turned from empires, proud and wide,
For just one glance, one breath, one tide
That brings you near, that makes me whole—
You are the keeper of my soul.

So let the stars burn cold and dim,
Let every song grow faint and slim;
I'll hold this truth, forever free:
For nothing less than thee.

And when the final curtain falls,
And silence answers to the calls,
One whisper will remain with me:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Have I walked through fire unafraid,

No simple joy, no passing light,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer, the sun hung high,
A molten coin in the cloudless sky.
Heat shimmered above the golden wheat,
While drowsy bees hummed a slow heartbeat.
The air stood still, yet whispered low,
Of secrets the meadow refused to show.
A brook babbled on with a silver tongue,
Its melody old, its current young.
Shadows were short, like thoughts held deep,
Where silence and sunlight together sleep.
A hawk circled wide in a thermal's embrace,
Tracing slow arcs through boundless space.
Children once danced where the clover grew,
Now only their laughter lingers, faint and true.
Time, too, pauses beneath the blaze,
Caught in the amber of those sunlit days.
No storm in sight, no shadow near,
Just earth and light in a truce sincere.
Oh, to remain in that golden hush,
Where the world drinks deep from midday’s flush.
But the sun will wane, as all things must—
Even summer yields to the turning of dust.

'Twas noontide of summer, fierce and bright,
The fields ablaze in liquid light.
Cicadas sang their shrill refrain,
A pulsing rhythm in nature's brain.
No breath of wind to stir the trees,
Just stillness bent on its bended knees.
The sky, a bowl of endless blue,
Held not a wisp of cloud in view.
A lizard darted on scorched stone,
Seeking cracks where coolness shone.
The world seemed paused, in held suspense,
Caught in time’s warm recompense.
A farmer wiped his sunburnt face,
Dreaming of shade and water’s grace.
Yet in the heat, a beauty grew—
A stark, bold life that dared break through.
For in this blaze, no fear takes root,
Only endurance, firm and mute.
So let the sun crown noon its king,
Let every living creature sing
Not of comfort, not of ease,
But life that thrives beneath the squeeze.

'Twas noontide of summer, a blaze of gold,
Where stories in the heat unfold.
A hammock swayed on a porch so wide,
With lemonade left to cool inside.
Grandmother fanned herself with grace,
Recalling youth’s forgotten face.
Somewhere a train on distant tracks
Cut through the haze with iron cracks.
Children once ran through sprinkler spray,
Leaving wet prints on dusty clay.
Now all is still, as noon demands,
Even dreams lie in sunlit strands.
The oak tree stood with arms held high,
Its leaves like coins against the sky.
A single crow called from a wire,
Setting the silence slightly afire.
In this hour, no clocks apply—
Time dissolves in the thickened sky.
Oh, to live where moments melt,
Where memory and sunlight belt
A truth that hums beneath the glare:
Even stillness has its prayer.

'Twas noontide of summer, the zenith’s reign,
When light consumes both joy and pain.
No moon to whisper, no stars to guide,
Just sunfire poured from open sky.
Fields shimmered like mirage dreams,
Beneath the weight of solar beams.
A world stripped bare of shade or guise,
Exposed beneath the watchful skies.
A snake slid slow through cracked earth’s skin,
A silent hymn beneath the din
Of heat-induced, drowsy trance,
Where thought dissolves in golden lance.
Even sorrow feels too heavy here,
Too dense for breath, too warm for tear.
Yet in this burn, a truth takes hold—
That beauty wears a blazing mold.
For life persists, though bent and dry,
With roots that drink from hidden sky.
And in the peak of summer’s might,
We glimpse the soul stripped pure and bright.

'Twas noontide of summer, the air thick and sweet,
With honeysuckle pulsing in the heat.
A tractor hummed in a distant field,
Its rhythm slow, its purpose sealed.
A dog lay stretched on a wooden sill,
His breath a soft, continuous drill.
Above, the sun with steady gaze
Counted the hours in molten days.
A child drew chalk on blistering ground,
Creating worlds without a sound.
Crickets had not yet begun their song,
For even they felt the heat too strong.
Yet in this hush, a pulse remained—
Life in the veins, though not explained.
Each leaf, each stone, each silent door,
Held stories the sunlight could not ignore.
The clock stood still, the world stood tall,
Answering summer’s loudest call.
And in that blaze, both fierce and clear,
Existence whispered, 'I am here.'

'Twas noontide of summer, the world stood still,
Beneath a sky of unyielding will.
The sun, a sovereign without a peer,
Cast every shadow far and near.
Fields of barley bowed in gold,

Yet in this heat, a beauty thrived—
A kind of peace that can’t be contrived.
The earth, though tired, wore pride like a crown,
Alive in the heat, not broken, but grown.
For noontide does not scorch and go,

And when the evening dares to creep,

'Twas noontide of summer, the air stood clear,
A moment suspended, devoid of fear.
The sun, not harsh, but gently wide,
Spread honeyed light on every side.
Bees hummed slow in clovered rows,
Time itself in repose.
An old man sat with eyes half-shut,
Remembering loves and chances lost.
Yet now, in this heat, they didn’t sting—
Just ghosts that softly took wing.
The world was full, yet strangely bare,
Stripped to the bone of the weight of care.
No need to move, no need to speak,
Just warmth upon the aging cheek.
O noon, you are a gentle priest,
Who offers silence as your feast.
And in your glow, both young and old
Find stories more precious than gold.

'Twas noontide of summer, the light was loud,

The pavement shimmered, a liquid street,
Where reality wavered beneath bare feet.
A cat lay flat on a windowsill,
A statue of calm, obeying no will.
Above, the sky—an endless blue,
Too vast, too bold, to feel true.
And yet, within that heated dome,
A sense of belonging far from home.
For noon is not just heat and glare,
But presence—raw and standing there.
No shadows to hide, no dusk to flee,

So let the sun burn, let hours stall—

And in that pause, so full, so deep,
The world confessed it longed to sleep—

’Twas noontide of summer, fierce and bright,
The sun a blade, the sky alight.
Grass bleached pale beneath its glare,
And silence pressed the heavy air.
No bird dared sing, no bee took flight,
All life withdrew from blinding light.
A lone dog panted by the gate,
His shadow small, his fate to wait.
The road turned silver, cracked and thin,
A mirage danced like water within.
A farmer wiped his sunburnt face,
And cursed the heat with weary grace.
Yet in the orchard, apples swelled,
By photosynthesis compelled.
This brutal hour, though harsh and long,
Was where the season proved its song—
Not in the dawn, nor twilight’s hue,
But noon’s bold kiss, relentless, true.
For in that fire, life found its core,
And summer breathed, and asked for more.

’Twas noontide of summer, soft and wide,
A sleepy sigh where moments glide.
The garden sprawled in quiet bloom,
Drenched in light and gentle gloom.
Bees drifted slow from rose to rose,
Their wings like stained-glass as they rose.
A cat curled tight on sun-warmed stone,
Dreaming of mice and being alone.
The air was thick with lavender breath,
And childhood memories just beyond death.
A porch swing creaked with no one near,
As if ghosts still sat, holding dear
The laughter lost to passing years,
And vanished smiles, and silent tears.
The sun stood still, as if to say,
‘This peace is mine, I’ll not give way.’
And in that pause, so calm, so deep,
The soul recalled what time would keep—
Not clocks or tasks, but golden haze,
The quiet heart of summer days.

’Twas noontide of summer, sharp and clear,
A moment frozen, held so near.
Each leaf defined, each stone aglow,
As if the world had stopped to show
Its perfect face, unblinking, bold,
A story in the light untold.
A hawk hung high in motionless flight,
A sentinel of burning light.
Below, the wheat fields rippled slow,
Not from wind, but heat’s soft glow.
A child ran through a sprinkler’s arc,
Laughing loud against the stark
Brilliance of sky and sunlit ground,
Where joy and fire both were found.
Time stretched like taffy, sweet and long,
In this, summer’s proudest song.
No need for dusk, no call for rain,
Just this: the sun, the field, the plain.
And in that blaze, so fierce, so vast,
The present held the future fast.

’Twas noontide of summer, still and deep,
The kind of heat that makes time sleep.
Crickets stitched sound through drowsy air,
While oaks stood tall, beyond compare.
A pond lay hushed, its surface glass,
Reflecting clouds that seemed to pass
In silent films of cotton white,
Drifting through endless blue of light.
A heron stood on stilted legs,
Patient as ancient prophecy begs.
Nearby, a girl with sun-bleached hair
Skipped stones with grace beyond her years.
Each splash a note in nature’s hymn,
Each breath a prayer grown soft and dim.
The world felt full, as if it knew
This noon was more than just a view—
It was a pulse, a sacred beat,
The earth’s own heart beneath our feet.
And in that glow, so warm, so true,
The soul remembered: this is you.

Above, the sky, a flawless blue,

I closed my eyes and let it in—

'Twas noontide of summer, bold and grand,

Children’s laughter, faint and far,

Oh, noontide rich with vibrant sound,

You pulse with joy, you burn, you bloom—

'Twas noontide of summer, hushed and wide,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text:
This anger burns deep within,
A smolder beneath silent skin,
Not loud, not rash, but carved in stone,
A fire that walks through flesh and bone.
It does not flare, it does not shout,
But twists the roots the soul lives out.
Each breath a war, each glance a spark,
A tempest locked inside the dark.
It feeds on words that went unsaid,
On promises that broke like thread.
It dreams of storms, of thunder’s might,
Of drowning wrongs in endless night.
Yet still it waits, it does not leap,
It guards its grief, it will not weep.
For rage like this knows time is long,
And justice wears a patient tongue.

This anger burns deep within,
A quiet hum beneath the skin.
No thunderclap, no sudden flame,
Just embers whispering my name.
It coils like roots beneath the ground,
Where light once touched, now silence found.
It doesn’t beg, it doesn’t plead,
It plants its grief and lets it feed.
On every lie, each stolen breath,
On love that danced right past the edge.
It does not shout, it does not break,
It learns the weight that silence takes.
And though the world moves on, unaware,
This fire stays, this fire dares.
Not to destroy, but to remain,
A quiet storm, a voice without a name.

This anger burns deep within,
Not wild, but carved by where I've been.
It sits like stone in hollowed chest,
A guest I never gave a guest.
It knows the weight of turned backs,
The cracks behind each smile that masks.
It doesn’t flinch, it doesn’t flee,
It learns the art of memory.
Each slight, each cut, each word ignored,
It stores them deep, it keeps them stored.
It doesn’t crave a public fight,
It feeds on stillness, thrives at night.
And when the dawn forgets the pain,
It licks its wounds and burns again.
Not loud, not proud, but fiercely true—
A flame the world will never view.

This anger burns deep within,
A slow eclipse beneath the skin.
It doesn’t roar, it doesn’t chase,
It learns to live inside the space
Between the breath and broken trust,
Between the lie and what is just.
It maps the scars the world has made,
And quietly begins to shade
The edges of my every thought,
A lesson harshly taught, long caught.
It does not seek to be released,
It knows the cost of being pleased
By fleeting peace or hollow grace—
It guards its fire, holds its place.
For some wounds never learn to mend,
They simply learn to burn and bend.

This anger burns deep within,
A quiet war I never win.
It doesn’t blaze, it doesn’t fade,
It walks each step that I have made.
It knows the hush of slammed doors,
The ache of what was said before.
It doesn’t beg for sympathy,
It draws its strength from history.
From every time I bit my tongue,
From every wrong that went unsung.
It doesn’t crave a grand display,
It wears its wounds another day.
And though I smile, though I pretend,
It stokes the coals around the bend.
For rage like this won’t be denied—
It lives where love and loss collide.
