But thundered down the judgment day,
With blade unsheathed, piercing the night.
No dove descended, soft and mild,
But ravens circled, dark and wide,
And every heart, both man and child,
Felt steel press deep with sacred pride.
"I bring no peace," the heavens cried,
"But fire to burn the false and weak,
The chaff shall fall, the wheat abide—
Divide the strong, the meek shall speak
Not of comfort, but of war,
For truth demands the soul’s own door.
Brother turns on brother then,
And love is proven through the flame.
The sword He bears is not of men,
But forged in God’s unyielding name.
And though the ground runs red with loss,
It waters seeds of holy cross.
No easy grace, no sweet refrain,
But justice carved in blood and pain.

He stepped from clouds with silent tread,
Yet earth cracked wide beneath His feet.
No olive branch, no blessing said—
A sword He drew, both sharp and fleet.
Not peace, He claimed, but fire and fight,
To cleave the world in two, upright.
The shadows fled, the idols fell,
As truth rang out from heaven’s knell.
No lullaby, no soft embrace,
But holy war for time and space.
Fathers and sons now stand apart,
Torn by the sword that pierces heart.
For none may straddle light and dark,
When Christ divides with single spark.
This blade is love in fiercest form,
To shield the weak, to break the norm.
It cuts away the rot within,
To let new life begin, begin.
So though He came not as we dreamed,
Still is He Lord, still is He King.
And every cut, though deep and sore,
Leads to a peace forevermore.

He came not riding on a lamb,
But storm-wreathed, with eyes aflame.
No harp of peace, no hymn of grace,
But iron drawn from sacred place.
"I bring division," was His cry,
"To split the false from true, the lie
From faith that stands in fire tried—
Let kin be foes, let hearts divide."
The sword He bore was not for war
Against a king or distant shore,
But to unmask the hidden soul,
To claim the lost, to make them whole.
So peace deferred, but justice near,
And every shadow forced to clear.
No middle ground, no neutral side,
When Christ, the Judge, has come with pride.
Though peace may seem a shattered dream,
It flows beyond the sword’s keen gleam—
A peace not born of ease or rest,
But from the crucible, manifest.

No angel choir, no manger bed,
No quiet word for those in dread.
He came with thunder in His stride,
And sword in hand, no place to hide.
"Not peace," He said, "but sword I bring,
To split the heart, to test each thing.
Let daughter rise against her mother,
Let doubt give way to holy brother."
The world once lulled by gentle tales
Now shook beneath celestial gales.
No compromise, no softened line—
Truth cuts like flame through every sign.
This sword, though feared, is mercy too,
For love must sometimes wound to renew.
To cleave the soul from selfish pride,
And stand the righteous, purified.
So though He came not as we prayed,
Still is His justice perfectly made.
And every cut, though sharp and dire,
Kindles the soul with holy fire.

From eastern dawn to western sea,
He came not meek, but fiercely free.
No dove, but hawk with wings outspread,
And fire poured where once was tread.
"I bring not peace," the voice declared,
"But sword to cut what must be bared.
The time of silence now is past,
The die is cast, the die is cast."
No lull of lamb, no shepherd’s tune,
But battle cry beneath the moon.
For peace through compromise is lie,
True peace must through division try.
So kin against kin, and friend turned foe,
When Christ divides the high and low.
Yet in the clash, the blood, the loss,
Rises the cross, the cross, the cross.
For every wound the sword has made,
Is where the light begins to fade
Into a dawn no night can dim—
Salvation forged on edge of Him.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text:
On the scene came Christ the Lord, not with peace but with a sword,
A flame-lit dawn, a thundered Word,
That split the hush of age-old lies.
No lambent smile, no lullaby,
But justice swift, with piercing edge,
To cleave the soil of sin and pledge.

He came not cloaked in velvet grace,
But stormed the gates of time and space,
With truth like steel, a two-edged flame,
To burn away the world’s false name.
No gentle hand to smooth the way,
But judgment strong to rend the day.

Families fell to sundered sides,
Where light and shadow both collide;
A father spurned, a daughter sworn,
For Christ, the blade, the horn, the thorn.
No peace that worldlings understand,
But peace beyond, by death, He planned.

So take the sword He brings, not hate,
But truth that opens heaven’s gate.
For only fire can cleanse the core,
And only war brings peace evermore.

He stepped from heaven’s silent dome,
Not bearing dove nor prayer nor psalm,
But steel that flashed with holy ire,
To set the sleeping world afire.

No olive branch, no calm decree,
But storm that split the false and free.
A sword—yes, not for blood or throne,
But truth that stands, and stands alone.

It cut through lies in sacred halls,
Through love that bowed to mammon’s calls.
It split the heart, the home, the street,
Where comfort wore the mask of meek.

Not peace as silence, peace as death,
But life that draws a single breath
Of righteousness, though kin disown,
Though standing stands on splintered stone.

So let the blade descend, refine,
This crooked soul, this fractured line.
For peace will bloom where truth has scored—
Brought by the Christ, the sword, the Lord.

From Galilee’s hush to Jerusalem’s height,
He walked with dawn, not peace, but fight.
No silver chime, no soft refrain,
But thunder in a man of pain.

The sword he bore was not of steel,
But Word made sharp, that none could heal
Once spoken—truth that cuts the guise,
That parts the false from true, the wise
From those who sleep in sacred robes,
Who name His name but serve their mobs.

He came to set the household war,
Where love must choose what lies are for.
To follow Him means break the tie
Of blood, if blood denies the sky.

Not peace that lulls, but peace that burns,
That through the cross, at last, returns.
So wield His sword with hands made pure—
It is His love that will endure.

A hush once lay on earth and sea,
Then came a step—divinity.
Not robed in calm, nor wreathed in light,
But girt with war, with piercing might.

The sword He brought no soldier knew,
No edge for conquest, but for truth.
It slashed the veil, it split the night,

No peace that soothes the guilty mind,

Who cling to idols, soft and sweet,

So let the blade divide, refine,

He came not with a wreath of bloom,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text:
The orchard slept beneath a silvered moon,
Where shadows coiled in silence, soft and deep.
The snake, once guardian of root and rune,
Now tasted longing in the air’s sweet creep.

The apple hung, a lantern gold and bright,
Pride of the bough, untouched by tooth or hand.
But whispers slipped into the hush of night—
A murmur born of dust and dark command.

He spoke of wisdom, of forbidden light,
Of eyes unblinded, of a world made clear.
She reached, her fingers trembling toward the height,
And plucked the fruit that seeded ancient fear.

The crunch rang out like thunder in the glen,
And time collapsed beneath that single bite.
The garden wept, and earth began to bend,
Lost innocence beneath a falling light.

Now every bite we take recalls the fall,
The snake, the fruit, the whisper, and the wall
That rose between us and the dawn’s first call.

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
Of trust misplaced and secrets cast like spells.
Once, in a garden wrapped in morning’s bell,
They danced in peace, no hint of earthly hells.

But knowledge called with voices sharp and low,
A serpent’s tongue, a promise wrapped in flame.
The fruit, so red, seemed ripe for man to know,
And ignorance could never be the same.

She did not weep when Eden turned to dust,
Nor did he curse the soil with bitter toil.
They walked ahead, in quiet, sacred trust,
Through thorn and storm, with purpose and with poise.

For though the tale begins with sin and fall,
It ends with courage rising after all.
Each bite we take, a choice to break or bind,
To seek the truth, and leave the lies behind.

In twilight’s hush, where ivy veils the stone,
A serpent wound through roots of ancient tree.
An apple glowed, half-ripe, and all alone,
The weight of fate hung heavy, silently.

He did not speak of power, nor of pride,
But whispered, 'What if knowing sets you free?'
No malice lived within his scaled hide,
Just sorrow for what was meant to be.

She took the fruit, not tricked, but full aware,
Her heart a storm of doubt and deep desire.
The garden gasped, the sky turned cold and bare,
Yet from that fall, a kind of truth took fire.

No Eden lasts where conscious beings dwell,
And every choice bears both a heaven and a hell.
The snake still waits, the apple still is near—
And every soul must taste, and then revere.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text:
On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the wind sings low through the wattle and thorn,
A homestead leans in its sunbaked unrest,
Beneath a sky both pitiless and worn.
No neighbor's light breaks the evening's hush,
Just the kangaroo’s bound and the crow’s harsh cry.
The seasons turn with a farmer’s hush,
His face lined deep with a patient why.

He sowed his hope in the stony ground,
Watered it with sweat, not rain.
Years passed by without a sound,
Save the rustle of drought and the ache of pain.
Yet still he stands by the gate at dusk,
Watching the horizon bleed into blue—
Not for riches, nor for lust,
But for one small thing: something true.

For in that silence, vast and wide,
A soul may hear what the world denies.
And though the land gives little in return,
It teaches fire how to burn.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,

Her hands, cracked maps of toil and time,

No city’s hum, no lover’s call,
Just the crackle of embers and memory’s sting.
The silence here builds a wall,
Yet in that hush, her heart takes wing.
For in the absence, she finds a voice—
A quiet hymn to loss and choice.

She plants roses where the thistles were,
Not for show, but to prove she’s near.
Near to life, near to pain,

And when the moon swells, pale and wise,
She dances barefoot beneath its eyes.

For solitude, though sharp and long,
Can be where we’ve belonged.

A dog barks once—then lies down to rest,

No train whistles, no distant song,
Just the creak of the windmill’s tired arm,
Turning slow where it’s stood too long,
Guarding dreams that came to harm.

A rusted plow in the brittle grass,
Tells of hopes the soil denied.
The years passed like shadows that pass,
And left only bones where dreams once cried.

Yet in the dusk, a wattle blooms,
Bright yellow defiance in the gray.
A sign that life still finds its rooms,
Even where men have gone away.

For though the land may starve and fight,
And silence press with all its weight,
There’s beauty born in endless night—
A stubborn love that won’t abate.

And somewhere, deep in the dreaming earth,
A seed remembers what it’s worth.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the horizon bleeds into rust and bone,
A man walks slow with a Bible in his vest,
And a heart turned hard as the clay he’s known.
No church bell rings, no choir sings,
Just the whisper of scripture in the gale.
He prays for rain, for the joy that springs,
But mostly he prays not to fail.

The sheep are few, the dam is dry,
And hope is a currency he can’t afford.
Yet every dawn, he lifts his eye
To the hill where he buried his wife and lord.

She loved the stars, she named them all—
Orion, Vega, the Southern Cross.
Now he speaks to her when shadows fall,
And finds in silence what love once was.

For loneliness is not always pain,
Sometimes it’s where the soul grows plain.
And in that plainness, stark and wide,
He walks with God, and she beside.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the sun cracks the earth like an old, dry drum,
A child draws shapes in the red dirt, pressed
By the weight of a sky without one single hum.
No school bell rings, no playground calls,
Just the whisper of ants and the buzzard’s glide.
Yet in her chalk-line world, the silence falls
Into castles, rivers, oceans wide.

She talks to the wind, names it Jack or June,
Builds cities from stones and sticks.
In her mind, the desert’s a lagoon,
And the fence post a pirate ship that ticks
With stories only she can tell—
Of dragons in the gully, and mermaids in the well.

Her mother watches from the sagging porch,
Smiling through the ache of years.
She sees not lack, but a boundless torch—
The fire of dreams that conquer fears.

For even here, where hope seems thin,
Imagination lets the light in.
And in that child’s unbroken gaze,

Her gate swings slow on rusted hinge,

Yet still she plants, still dares to flinch
At every cloud that dares appear—
A flicker of faith, year after year.
No glory here, no poet's praise,
Just quiet grit through dust-filled days.
But in her eyes, a steady flame,
That whispers each unyielding name:
Survivor. Keeper. Silent flame.
And though the world may never know,
Her quiet stand against the woe,
She is the pulse the outback hides—
The soul that in the silence bides.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the horizon hums with heat and haze,
A horse stands still, its coat distressed
By flies and sun’s unblinking gaze.
No stockyard clang, no stockman’s call—
Just silence stretched for miles and more.
The wind stirs dust along the wall
Of what was once a kitchen door.
A rusted plough lies half-buried,
A child’s shoe beside a stone.
Time has stripped, consumed, and buried
Every seed that stood alone.
Yet in the soil, beneath the crust,
A seedling pushes through the dust.
Defiant green in shades of tan,
A fragile hope no drought can ban.
For life returns, though slow and slight,
To claim the day, to greet the light.
And in that sprout, a truth is told:
The loneliest land holds more than cold.
It holds the pulse of what survives—
The will that stubborn nature drives.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the stars burn cold and bright,
A dog howls once, then lies down to rest,
Beneath the vast and vaulted night.
No lamp is lit, no fire glows,
The house stands dark, its timbers thin.
No voice recalls the years that rose
And fell like tides beneath the skin
Of those who tilled this thirsty ground,
Who fought the wind, the flood, the fire.
Now silence is the only sound,
And memory feeds the dying pyre.
Yet in the dark, a wattle blooms,
Its gold a spark against the gloom.
A sign that life, though pushed aside,
Still finds a way where dreams have died.
For even here, where hope seems lost,
Where every gain is bought with cost,
Something endures beyond the years—
The quiet hum of unshed tears,
And in the soil, a whispered claim:
We were here. We bore the name.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the gibber plains stretch wide and bare,
A crow alights on a telegraph wire, distressed
By visions only birds can share.
It caws once—sharp against the blue—
A sound that cuts the empty air.
Below, the remnants of a life once true:
A rusted stove, a broken chair,
A child's drawing, faded, pinned
to a wall that sags with years.
The wind flips pages, thin and thinned,
Of ledgers filled with hopes and fears.
No soul remains to read the lines,
Of droughts endured and harvests thinned.
Yet in the dust, a rhythm sings—
The pulse of earth on fragile wings.
For though the settler's dream may fail,
And every story end in wail,
The land remembers every tread,
Each whispered word, each silent prayer.
And in the stillness, softly said,
A legacy floats on desert air.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text:
On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the wind sings low through the wattle and thorn,
A hut of bark leans with the weight of the years,
And shadows stretch long like the dreams of the worn.
No neighbor in sight, just the hawk’s circling flight,
And the creek, long dry, with its bones cracked and pale.
Here a man once dreamed of a green, working farm,
But the droughts came like thieves, and hope grew frail.
He planted his rows with a steady hand,
Fought the soil like a lover betrayed.
Now the fence posts sag like old soldiers fallen,
And the silence is thick with the debts that were made.
Yet at dusk, when the sky bleeds apricot and ash,
A kookaburra laughs from the edge of the scrub—
A sound so alive in that vast, watching hush,
It might be the land saying, *Enough. Stay. Love me, though I am hard.*

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the sun hammers down on red, open plains,
A woman walks slow with a bucket in hand,
Her face lined with dust, her heart full of rains
That never arrived. The horizon is bare,
A shimmering lie of lakes long since gone.
She hums an old tune her mother once sang,
A lullaby stitched from the threads of the dawn.
Her children play near a rusted-out car,
Drawing maps in the dirt with a stick and a dream.
They speak of the city with wide, eager eyes,
But she knows the cost of a faraway gleam.
For this land, though it starves and withers the soul,
Still holds them with roots deeper than fear.
And when night folds the world in a velvet embrace,
She whispers, "We’re here. We are still here," 
To the stars, to the wind, to the ghosts in the trees—
A prayer and a promise beneath the wide sky.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the mulga stands sentinel, twisted and gray,
A dog barks once into the gathering dark,
Then stills—ears pricked at a sound far away.
No stock in the paddocks, no smoke from the flue,
Just the creak of a sign with letters half-gone:
"Callahan"—faded, like memories worn thin
By the grind of the years and the bite of the sun.
A diary lies open on a splintered stump,
Ink blurred by rain or perhaps by a tear.
"Day seventy-three: not a drop from the sky.
The sheep all gone, and the water tank’s near
Empty. Mary left with the youngest last week.
Said she couldn’t bear one more season like this.
I stay. This is home, though it kills me slow.
I’ll die on my feet, not a ghost in a city’s abyss."
The moon rises cold over saltbush and stone,
And the wind carries words no one speaks anymore:
"I remember the rain. I remember her voice."
Then silence—deep, wide, and aching with lore.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the horizon hums with a heat-struck refrain,
A horse stands alone by a fallen windmill,
Its shadow a stain on the cracked, thirsty plain.
No rider to guide it, no hand to comb mane,
It grazes on thistles and dreams of green grass.
A photograph flutters, caught in a fence—
A family once whole, their futures in glass.
Now time has unraveled the edges, the smiles,
Like the wool that blew off in the great shearing storm,
When the shed burned down and the bank sent its man
With a ledger of losses too heavy to warm.
Yet something persists—not hope, not belief,
But the stubbornness bred in the bone and the soil.
This land does not give, but it doesn’t forget.
It holds every footstep, each sorrow, each toil.
And when comets streak through the ink of the night,
The horse lifts its head, and for once, does not flee—
As if knowing the cosmos, too, feels this plight:
Alone, but enduring, in vast liberty.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the clouds are but rumors and silence holds court,
A radio crackles with voices from towns
That might as well be on some distant port.
The signal comes in like a ghost in the wires—
A song, half a weather report, then gone.
The farmer adjusts the old dial with care,
Though he knows he’s alone on this stretch of red dawn.
He sips his black tea, watches dust devils dance
Across fields where the wheat never grew.
He thinks of his father, who broke this same ground,
Saying, "One day, son, it’ll all come through."
Now the tractor sits rusting, a metal carcass,
And the shed sags low with the weight of old grain
That never was harvested. Still, he persists—
Lights the kerosene lamp, calls out the dog’s name.
"Shep!"—just to hear a sound in the hush,
To prove he’s not vanished, not lost to the void.
And when stars pierce the velvet, so thick and so near,
He whispers, "I’m here," and the night is annoyed
By nothing—no answer, no judgment, just space—
So he says it again, soft, to himself: "I’m here."
And for a moment, the silence feels less like despair,
And more like a presence that’s always been near.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text:
On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the wind sings low through the wattle and thorn,
A homestead leans in the sun’s tired light,
Its timbers groaning, its heart worn thin.

No children's laughter breaks the hush,
Only the crow’s call, stark and brief,
And dust that dances in the slanting rays,
A waltz with shadows beneath the eaves.

The farmer walks his furrowed fields,
His boots like anchors in the red, dry clay,
Each step a memory of rain long lost,
Each breath a pact with a stubborn day.

The horizon bleeds in purple flame,
As dusk descends with silent grace,
And stars, like distant homesteads, gleam—
Each one a world, each one alone.

Yet in this silence, wide and deep,
Where solitude and courage meet,
There blooms a quiet, steadfast will—
A love too fierce for words to spill.

For though the land is harsh and spare,
And hope is measured, thin and slow,
He stands—a figure carved by wind—
Rooted where few would choose to go.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the sky stretches wide and the fences sag low,
A rusted windmill creaks its nightly hymn,
And the moon casts silver on the saltbush plain.

No telegraph wire splits the air,
No train whistle cuts the endless night—
Just the whisper of kangaroos in the scrub,
And the pulse of stars in the vaulted height.

A lantern flickers in the kitchen nook,
Where a woman mends a child’s torn sleeve,
Her hands are cracked, her eyes are old,
Though her years are barely past thirty.

She dreams of dances in city halls,
Of music, crowds, and painted lights,
But here, the only rhythm is the drip
Of water into the concrete tank at night.

Still, she hums a tune without words,
A melody spun from dust and time,
And in that sound, both soft and clear,
Lies a quiet kind of triumph.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the earth cracks like an ancient map,
A dog barks once, then falls to sleep,
Curled by the door in the evening chill.

The sky, a bowl of cooling ash,
Holds one bright star—the first to call.
No roads lead in, no tracks remain,
Just wind that shapes the dune’s slow breath.

A man sits on the veranda’s edge,
His hat pulled low, his pipe gone cold,
He watches shadows stretch and merge,
As if the land is drawing in its soul.

He thinks of words he never spoke,
Of letters folded, never sent,
Of love that faded like the paint
On gates long shut, on fences bent.

But in the silence, vast and deep,
A truth begins to softly gleam:
To hold this land, to stay and tend,
Is its own quiet, stubborn dream.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
The sun beats down on iron roofs,
Where sheep move slow through dusty haze,
And time dissolves like mirage smoke.

A child runs barefoot through the yard,
Chasing a hoop that wobbles and falls,
Her laughter echoes off the shed,
Then fades into the afternoon’s hush.

Her mother watches from the sill,
A cup of tea gone cold in hand,
Her gaze drifts past the stockyard gate,
To where the outback claims the land.

No neighbors near, no school in sight,
Just letters read a hundred times,
And photographs with faded edges,
Of city streets and distant chimes.

Yet in the stillness, something grows—
Not wealth, nor fame, nor wide acclaim,
But roots that grip the ancient soil,
And learn to flourish all the same.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the clouds are strangers, high and few,
A horse stands still in the midday glare,
Tail flicking slow at the flies that bite.

The homestead crouches, low and grey,
Its yard a sprawl of rust and stone,
A tyre swing hangs from a dead gum tree,
Still turning slightly, all alone.

No voice calls out, no dog replies,
Just wind that hums through broken wire,
And somewhere deep in the mulga shade,
A kookaburra lights its fire.

This is a place the world forgot,
Where dreams are small and hopes are lean,
Where every drop of water saved
Is sipped like wine, precise and clean.

But in the dusk, when shadows blend,
And stars ignite their ageless song,
The silence speaks of deeper things—
Of staying on, and knowing you belong.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text:
On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the wind combs through the tussock grass,
A hut of bark and broken beams stands test
Against the years, the drought, the bitter pass
Of seasons stripped to bone and sunburnt stone.
No footfall marks the dust but for the fox,
And crows like judges on a dead man’s throne
Cry out above the silence of the rocks.

Here once a dream took root in stubborn soil—
A fence line drawn, a dam to catch the rain,
A child’s laugh that echoed for a while,
Then vanished like a shadow down the plain.
Now only memory holds the fire’s glow,
The names half-lost, the reasons no one knows.

Yet in the dusk, when stars begin to rise
Like lanterns hung above the ancient land,
A presence stirs beneath the open skies—
The ghost of hope that shaped a stubborn hand,
That dared to love a country harsh and vast,
And built a home that could not, in the end, outlast.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
The horizon bleeds into a copper haze,
Where silence wears the weight of endless quest
And time erodes the markers of our days.
No church spire breaks the line of sun-scorched earth,
Just rabbit warrens and the rusted gate,
A tractor’s corpse, a testament to worth
That faltered long before it met its fate.

The homestead leans, its timbers cracked and thin,
Whispering tales of frost and failing crops,
Of children packed and taken by the kin,
Of love grown cold beneath indifferent props.
Yet in the soil, where roots still twist and fight,
A wattle blooms defiant in the light.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the sky stretches wide and the gum trees sigh,
A memory lingers, put to final test—
A weathered fence beneath a vacant sky.
No lamplight warms the windows, dark and bare,
No hoofbeats echo on the dusty track,
Just wind that tugs at weeds in the yard, a prayer
Left hanging where the homestead used to stack
Its firewood, hopes, and harvests of the year.
Now silence reigns, and kangaroos appear
At twilight, grazing where the garden stood,
While constellations map forgotten good.

This land, so vast, consumes what humans bring,
Yet holds in dust the echo of a dream’s lost wing.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the mirage dances and the rivers sleep,
A homestead crumbles into nature’s rest,
Its stories buried, secrets that won’t keep.
Once, hands dug deep to build a life from dust,
To coax green life from red and stony ground,
But drought and distance took their patient thrust,
And left but rubble and a single mound—
A grave, perhaps, or just a cairn of stone,
Marking where someone stood and faced the known
Vast emptiness, and still chose to remain,
Until the choice was taken once again.

Now only wind sings lullabies of loss,
To dreams uprooted by the arid cross.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the sun beats down on cracked and thirsty clay,
A shadow moves where human dreams were pressed
Into the earth, then faded fast away.
No name remains on any weathered post,
No photograph to prove they lived and tried,
Just remnants of a life that mattered most
When firelight danced and children danced beside.

The wind still hums a tune from long ago,
Through broken eaves and nails that rust in rows,
A melody of love, of loss, of woe,
Of seeds once sown, of how the strong man grows
Then breaks beneath the weight of sky and soil.
Here, solitude consumes the human toil.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text:
On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where silence drapes the plains like a shroud,
A wind-scoured homestead bears the test
Of time and drought and voices long unbowed.
No neighbors wave across the brittle fence,
Just emus tracking shadows in the dust,
And twilight paints the sky in recompense
With streaks of gold and violet, brief and just.
A kettle sings on iron stoves at night,
A dog barks once—a sound the darkness swallows.
Beneath the vast, unblinking stars so bright,
A woman reads by lamplight, heart full of hollows.
She dreams of cities drowned in noise and light,
Yet chooses this: the stillness, the long fight.
For in the hush, a different truth takes hold—
A love stitched deep in furrows, fierce and old.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where gum trees whisper secrets to the breeze,
A stockman rides the boundary, never blessed
With ease or rest beneath the iron skies.
His boots are cracked like earth after a year
Of sun that bleaches hope from every track.
His dog, a shadow, follows, lean and near,
Nosing through spinifex along the back.
At dusk, he lights a fire of fallen limbs,
The stars emerge like nails in blackened wood.
No letter comes, no distant violin hymns—
Just solitude, as constant as it’s good.
He knows the land will never yield its grace
To those who seek to rush or overtake.
This life is etched in slow, enduring lines,
A quiet war no history will make.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where mirages dance on heat-rippled ground,
A child once drew a house upon a chest
Of kerosene tins, with chalk and hopeful sound.
No school bell rings, no playground laughter flies,
Just wind that sings through wire, low and long.
The parents toil with patience in their eyes,
Their love a steady rhythm, slow and strong.
At night they gather, wrapped in patched-up wool,
And trace the constellations, naming each:
"That’s Orion, there—our southern jewel—
And there, the Southern Cross, beyond the reach
Of city lights that blind and never see
The quiet courage of this life, so free."

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where silence hums beneath the noonday glare,
A woman writes a letter she will never post,
Her thoughts like birds that circle, then disappear.
She speaks of rain that hasn’t touched the soil,
Of dreams that fade like footprints in the sand,
Of how the seasons grind with patient toil,
And how she still obeys love’s quiet command.
Her husband works the dam with sunburnt hands,
A figure bent against the wind’s harsh song.
They share a glance that needs no words, no plans—
Just knowing they belong, where they belong.
This land is harsh, unyielding, vast, and deep,
Yet in its grip, their promises still keep.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where dust storms roll like waves across the plain,
A radio crackles with a voice suppressed
By static, singing hymns through wind and rain.
No church stands near, no steeple cuts the sky,
But on Sunday morn, they gather just the same—
A hymn is hummed, a prayer sent drifting high,
In this raw chapel without name or frame.
The children learn their sums by candlelight,
Their lessons drawn in dirt with pointed sticks.
Their world is small, yet boundless in its might,
Rooted in soil and time and stubborn tricks
Of hope that sprouts where others see no green—
A quiet dream where few have ever been.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

responses.text:
Everyone has a fear, a shadow that clings,
Whispering doubts through invisible strings.
It curls in the chest when the lights grow dim,
A silent intruder, born deep within.
Some fear the dark, the unknown, the fall,
Others the silence that echoes in hall.
A child dreads monsters beneath the bed,
While elders fear words left unsaid.
Fear of loss, of love turned cold,
Of growing weak, of growing old.
Fear of failure, of being unseen,
Of living a life that’s merely routine.
Yet in that tremor, that pulse, that breath,
Lies courage disguised as the dance with death.
For to face the tremble, to stand and not flee,
Is to find the strength that fear sets free.
So carry your shadow, let it teach and guide,
For even in darkness, stars still reside.
And every heart, though it shakes and sways,
Still chooses its courage in countless ways.

Everyone has a fear, a secret they guard,
Buried beneath smiles, never too far.
It flickers in glances, in sudden retreat,
In the pulse at the temple, the heat in the feet.
One fears the ocean, its depth and its pull,
Another the silence when voices are dull.
Fear of the future, the unknown, the test,
Or fear of the past, of not being the best.
It lives in the breath before speaking aloud,
In the crowd where you're lonely, in grief wrapped in cloud.
But fear is not weakness—it shapes who we are,
A compass that points to our brightest star.
For courage is not born where danger is gone,
But where trembling hearts choose to carry on.
So name your fear, let it whisper its name,
Then walk through the fire, unflinching, unshamed.
For beyond every shadow that fear casts so near,
Lies a version of you—strong, whole, and clear.

Everyone has a fear, a knot in the throat,
A ghost in the hallway, a sinking boat.
It waits in the margins of daylight and dream,
A flicker of doubt, a tear in the seam.
Some fear rejection, the sting of a no,
Others the mirror that shows them too slow.
Fear of connection, of opening wide,
Of letting someone see deep inside.
Fear of success, of the weight it may bring,
Or fear of the bell that won’t ever ring.
Yet fear is a teacher, though harsh and unkind,
It reveals what we value, the ties that bind.
For every "I can't" hides an "I want to try," 
And every deep breath is a quiet "I'll fly."
So let fear remind you that you're alive,
That you care, that you hope, that you dare to survive.
And when shadows stretch long and the night feels severe,
Remember: your courage grows strongest right there.

Everyone has a fear, a silent refrain,
That echoes through moments of joy and of pain.
It hides in the rhythm of footsteps at night,
In the edge of a cliff, just out of the light.
One fears the unknown, the path never crossed,
Another the cost of being truly lost.
Fear of the body, of time’s steady creep,
Or fear of the wound that won’t let you sleep.
It coils in the chest when goodbyes must be said,
And hums in the silence that fills an empty bed.
But fear is not foe—it’s a pulse, a sign,
That you’re walking a path that is partly divine.
For bravery isn’t the absence of dread,
But moving ahead with your heart full of lead.
So hold your fear gently, don’t lock it away,
Let it shape your compassion, your words, what you say.
Because everyone carries this weight, it is clear—
And love grows the strongest when trembling with fear.

Everyone has a fear, a whisper, a chill,
A stone in the shoe, a slow uphill hill.
It lives in the pause before saying your name,
In the dread of the fire, the pull of the flame.
Some fear the heights, the edge of the roof,
Others the silence that speaks of the truth.
Fear of attachment, of hearts torn apart,
Or fear of the void, the emptiness of heart.
It stalks through the years like a shadowed guest,
Yet teaches the value of love and of rest.
For courage is not found in never feeling scared,
But in standing your ground, though your voice is impaired.
So let fear remind you that you’re not alone,
That others have trembled on this very stone.
And when your breath falters and darkness draws near,
Know this: you’re braver than fear dares appear.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

responses.text:
Everyone has a fear, a shadow that clings,
A whisper in silence where dread softly sings.
It coils in the chest when the lights fade too low,
A breath held in darkness, a nameless foe.
For some, it’s the fall from a towering height,
For others, the crushing weight of the night—
Not monsters or ghosts, but the ache of being seen,
The terror of loneliness, vast and serene.
A child fears the storm, the thunder’s cruel roar;
An elder fears silence behind a closed door.
The artist fears blankness, the writer, the page,
The lover, the moment love starts to disengage.
Yet in fear, there’s a thread of what matters most—
The depth of our caring, the things we hold close.
For courage is not born where terrors don’t tread,
But rises where fear has been fully met.
So honor the tremble, the pulse and the tear,
Because everyone has a fear—and that means we are here.

Everyone has a fear, though none may confess,
The shape in the mirror, the weight in a dress.
It hides in routines, in keys always checked,
In dreams where the ground is abruptly ejected.
One fears open windows, another, closed doors,
Some dread the loud laughter that echoes in halls.
The traveler fears stillness, the homebound, the train,
And joy often trembles with sorrow’s cold stain.
But fear is not weakness—it maps out the heart,
Reveals what we’d lose, what we never want torn apart.
It guards the deep well where our passions reside,
And whispers, "This matters," when truth must be tried.
So when your hands shake and your breath starts to freeze,
Know you're not broken—you're human, with ease
And terror entwined like roots under stone.
Everyone has a fear—but they’re never alone.

Everyone has a fear, a secret they guard,
A tremor beneath the smile, never too hard.
It lives in the pause before saying a name,
In the flinch at a shadow, the dread of the flame.
Some fear deep water, the pull of the tide;
Others fear standing tall, stuck in their pride.
The mother fears silence where giggles once rang,
The soldier, the peace that reminds them of bangs.
Fear of failure, of flying, of being too much,
Or worse—being nothing, just dust in the clutch
Of time’s indifferent fingers. Yet fear has a voice
That names what is precious, what gives us our choice.
For we brave every moment not because we are bold,
But because what we love is worth more than being controlled
By the dark, quiet monster that whispers at night.
Everyone has a fear—and still, we walk in the light.

Everyone has a fear, a knot in the thread,
A moment they freeze when the past won't stay dead.
It’s the phone call at midnight, the knock on the door,
The memory that crawls across the bedroom floor.
Some fear heights, others crowds, some the open sky,
Some fear when the truth is too loud to deny.
The student fears tests, the poet, the page,
The parent, the future they can't disengage.
But fear is a compass—it points to the core,
To the loves we protect, to the wounds we ignore.
It tells us we're alive, that we care, that we feel,
That pain is not pointless, that wounds can still heal.
So let fear have its season, its shiver, its tear,
But don’t let it silence the song you hold dear.
For courage is not fear’s absence, but near—
Everyone has a fear, yet we all persevere.

Everyone has a fear, a ghost in the wall,
A sound in the ceiling when no one’s there at all.
It’s the dread of the email, the ring of the phone,
The terror of being too deeply known.
One fears the ascent, another the fall,
Some fear the echo after the call.
The dancer fears stillness, the singer, the stage,
The heart, its own rhythm when love turns to rage.
But fear carves the shape of what we hold dear,
Like rivers that form where the bedrock is sheer.
It marks where we’re tender, where life has left marks,
And guides us through darkness with flickering sparks.
So when your breath hitches and shadows grow tall,
Remember: you’re not the first to feel small.
Bravery blooms where fears intersect—
Everyone has a fear. That’s how courage connects.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

responses.text:
Everyone has a fear, a shadow that clings,
Whispering doubts on fragile wings.
It hides in corners of daylight's gleam,
A silent intruder inside a dream.
Some fear the dark, the unknown, the fall,
Others the echo of silence in a hall.
A child dreads monsters beneath the bed,
While elders fear words left unsaid.
Fear of failure, of love turned cold,
Of growing old, of stories untold.
It coils in the chest, a cold, heavy stone,
In every heart, it finds its home.
But courage isn't the absence of dread,
But walking ahead though the path seems dead.
For in facing the tremble, the quiver, the tear,
We find strength we didn't know was there.
So honor the fear, then gently release—
Let love and boldness become your peace.
For though everyone carries this weight through the years,
We're braver together facing our fears.

Everyone has a fear, a knot in the throat,
A silent pulse in a rising note.
It flickers behind the eyes at night,
A ghost in the margins of pale moonlight.
One fears the ocean’s endless sweep,
Another the silence where memories sleep.
Fear of being seen, yet longing to be known,
Fear of facing the seeds we've never sown.
It wraps like ivy around the soul,
A whispered warning, a loss of control.
Yet in trembling hands, kindness still grows,
And in fragile hearts, resilience shows.
We build bridges across the chasm of dread,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
In shadowed vale or sunlit stone,
Through every breath, in bone and blood,
I seek Thy face, my soul's true good.
No dawn ascends without Thy light,
No star ignites beyond Thy might.
In silence deep, where sorrows roam,
I whisper still: O God! My God, my home.

Thy presence is the morning's cry,
The tide that draws the hidden sky.
When night descends with heavy shroud,
Thou art the voice that calls me loud.
Not wine, nor bread, nor earthly throne,
Can fill the void Thou only own.
My heart, a desert, longs for Thee—
A spring that flows eternally.

So let me walk where Thou dost lead,
In humble trust, in word and deed.
Though thorns may wound and trials moan,
I rest in this: Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other name I call my own.
Through storm and stillness, joy and dread,
I cling to Thee, my daily bread.
Thy love, a flame that will not cease,
Awakens in my soul its peace.
When all the world has turned to stone,
I cry: O God! Thou art my God alone.

No wealth, no fame, no fleeting crown,
Can match the glory I have found
In moments hushed, when Thou art near,
And every fear dissolves in tear.
My spirit sings, though weak and worn,
For in Thy light, new life is born.
Though mountains fall and seas up-flung,
My heart still sings: Thou art my God.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No idol carved of wood or stone,
No thought of man, no dream, no plan,
Can rival Thee, the great I AM.
From dust I rose, by Thee sustained,
In every breath, by Thee ordained.
When darkness hides the stars I've known,
I call: O God! Thou art my God alone.

Thy mercy flows like endless streams,
Thy grace fulfills my deepest dreams.
Though I have wandered, far from home,
Thy love has led me back to Thee.
And now my song shall ever be:
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not in the thunder, but the tone
Of quiet grace that heals my own.
No ritual, rite, or spoken word,
Can match the cry of this heart stirred.
In every loss, in every throne,
I know at last: Thou art my God alone.

I once sought solace in the noise,
In crowded streets and fleeting joys.
But silence taught what speech had shown—
That Thou art God, and Thou alone.
So let the world pursue the known;
My soul replies: Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not in the temple made of stone,
But in the breath, the tear, the groan,
In every seed that's overthrown.
Thy voice in wind, in fire, in rain,
In joy, in grief, in love, in pain.
No other name I've ever known
Can hold me like my God alone.

I do not grasp Thee, yet I'm held;
Not fully see, yet truth is spelled
In every wound, in every throne.
My life, a song: Thou art my God alone.
