No mortal name deserves this claim.
Thou liftest up my weary head,
When sorrow's weight has struck me dead.
In night’s long watch, my thoughts on Thee,
Like incense rise, wild, vast, and free.
Thou art the dawn, the song, the breath,
The light that conquers fear and death.
O God! My soul in Thee is known,
Thou art my God, and Thou alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other voice shall claim my own.
From dawn’s first blush to twilight’s sigh,
Beneath Thy stars, I live, I die.
The mountains bow, the oceans roar,
Yet in my heart, I hear You more.
Not gold, nor fame, nor fleeting bliss,
Can match the peace I find in this:
To kneel where grace has torn the veil,
And in the hush, to tell my tale.
No idol carved by human hand,
Can stand where You have made Your stand.
My soul once wandered, lost, unknown,
But now, O Lord, I am Your own.
O God! Thou art my God alone;
In You, I’ve found my flesh, my bone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other throne shall be my home.
Through storm and fire, through grief and song,
I’ve walked where You have led me long.
Each breath a hymn, each step a prayer,
Each wound a mark of tender care.
I sought You first in youth’s bold flame,
Now find You deeper, still the same.
No love on earth compares to Thine,
No truth so vast, so bright, so fine.
You broke the chains I could not see,
And drew my soul to follow Thee.
In joy and want, in praise and groan,
I claim no other God but One.
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My heart, my life, my cornerstone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
This truth has shaped my flesh and bone.
From cradle’s cry to aging breath,
You’ve walked with me through life and death.
No fleeting star, no mortal guide,
Could match the path where You preside.
I’ve chased the wind, I’ve loved the shade,
But only You have never frayed.
In silent woods and city noise,
I hear Your voice above all joys.
No temple built by hands can hold
The love that makes my spirit bold.
You are the root, the seed, the stone,
The ache, the answer, all my own.
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My soul has found its final home.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other name shall be my own.
Through years that fade like morning dew,
I’ve clung to every word from You.
Not wealth, nor power, nor praise, nor song,
Can match the peace where You belong.
You shaped the stars, yet know my tears,
You span the sky, yet calm my fears.
In every wound, in every sigh,
I feel Your presence drawing nigh.
No idol stands where You have trod,
No other name deserves this nod.
My heart, once wild, now beats for Thee,
My soul, once blind, now dares to see.
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My breath, my hope, my flesh, my bone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text: Rewind life and remember the creek behind the house where we dared to wade barefoot through summer’s gold. Sunlight dripped like honey on the mossy stones, and time was not a clock but the breath between laughter and splash. We were small, but the world was vast — a kingdom of dandelions, dragonflies, and secrets whispered into the wind. Now, I press pause on the noise, rewind past failures and farewells, back to that slow, green hush. I remember how your hand felt in mine, how the sky blushed at dusk, how nothing mattered but the now. Memory is a fragile film, flickering in the mind’s projector, but I guard each frame. To rewind is not to escape — it is to honor what shaped me. So I return, not to stay, but to salute the child who believed in magic, in endless days, in love that never fades. I rewind to remember I was once unafraid.

Rewind life and remember the scent of rain on warm pavement, the hush before thunder cracked the sky. I was sixteen, heart tangled in chords of a half-learned song, fingers fumbling on guitar strings, dreaming of stages and names in lights. You sat on the porch step, watching, smiling like you knew my soul. Now years spin forward like a film reel gone wild, but I clutch that moment — still, golden, true. Rewind to first kisses under streetlamps, to handwritten letters tucked in book spines, to quiet mornings with coffee and silence that wasn’t empty but full. Remember the dog who waited by the door, the grandmother who hummed old hymns, the way stars felt closer then. To rewind is not regret — it is reverence. A pilgrimage to the self I was, to thank her for surviving, for hoping. I press play again, carrying those echoes forward, stitching past joy into present courage. Memory is the compass; love, the map. And I, still learning, still becoming, remember who I’ve always been.

Rewind life and remember the kitchen at dawn — steam curling from the kettle, the clink of porcelain, your voice humming a tune older than words. I was small, wrapped in a blanket like a secret, watching you move through light like a prayer. Flour dusted your wrists; the world outside was dark, but in that room, everything glowed. I didn’t know then that such moments were sacred — that one day, I’d rewind them like fragile tape, frame by frame, just to hear your voice again. Time steals gently at first: a year here, a goodbye there. But memory fights back. I remember the way you laughed with your whole body, how you said my name like a blessing. Now I stand in my own kitchen, making tea the same way, and for a breath, you’re here. Rewind not to change the past, but to feel its warmth, to carry it like a flame through winter. To remember is to keep loving. To rewind is to say: I was seen. I was held. I am still yours.

Rewind life and remember walking home from school, backpack heavy with books but heart light with daydreams. The sidewalk cracked in patterns like ancient maps, and I’d hopscotch fate, believing every choice led to magic. Dandelions grew in the cracks — weeds to some, wishes to me. I’d blow them into the wind and watch hope scatter. Back then, time stretched like taffy — afternoons endless, summers eternal. I didn’t know loss yet, or loneliness, or the weight of becoming. I just knew the taste of lemonade on hot days, the sound of my mother calling me in for dinner, the dog barking at squirrels like a hero. Now I press rewind not to escape the present, but to thank the child who trusted joy so easily. To remember is to reclaim innocence, not as denial, but as compass. That girl still lives in me — barefoot, believing, brave. So I rewind, then step forward, carrying her light like a lantern through the darker woods.

Rewind life and remember the train at midnight — you waving from the platform, face half-lit by yellow lamps, growing smaller as the tracks pulled me away. I didn’t know it then, but that was the last time I’d see you whole, unbroken by years and distance. Now I scroll backward through mental footage: your smile in sunlight, the way you paused before answering questions, like you weighed each word in your soul. I rewind to the picnic in the rain, to shared headphones singing off-key, to promises made under stars we thought were listening. Memory is imperfect — some frames blurred, others sharp as glass — but I keep rewinding, not to rewrite endings, but to honor beginnings. To remember is to resist forgetting, to say: you mattered. Even now, in silence, I play those moments like songs on repeat. And though time moves forward, love loops back. I rewind, remember, and carry you with me — not as a ghost, but as a guide.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
In twilight's hush, where shadows creep,
I press the past's invisible deep.
A breath, a spark—the moments turn,
Like autumn leaves in quiet burn.
Rewind life and remember the dawn,
When laughter bloomed on fields of fawn.
A mother's voice, a father's hand,
Footprints etched in sunlit sand.

The bicycle ride, the scraped-up knee,
The whispered dream beneath the tree.
Each frame rewound with tender grace,
A silent film of time and space.
I see the love I failed to name,
The fleeting joy, the unspoken blame.
Now every second slows, takes flight,
Bathed in the glow of borrowed light.

I pause upon a winter's night,
Two lovers framed in candlelight.
A promise made, a vow undone—
A chapter lost, a setting sun.
But still, I hold the ember's glow,
The warmth that even silence knows.
For in this rewind, I finally see:
The beauty was in being free
To live, to love, to lose, to try—
And in remembering, learn to fly.

Rewind life and remember the rain,
That fell like tears on windowpanes.
When I was young and didn't know
The weight of words I'd come to owe.

Back to the porch where fireflies danced,
And time was just a fleeting glance.
Grandma’s stories, slow and sweet,
Swaying gently on creaking feet.

Rewind the years, the choices made,
The promises that start to fade.
A kiss not given, words unsaid,
Now echo loud inside my head.

But in this loop, I don’t resist—
I let the past reclaim its twist.
Not to change what came to be,
But feel the soul of memory.

The schoolyard laugh, the midnight train,
The joy, the grief, the sun, the rain.
Each moment stitched in fragile thread,
A tapestry inside my head.

So rewind life, let visions climb,
And in the past, I find my time.
Not to stay, but just to see:
How every end held part of me.

Spin the reel of silent years,
Through laughter, loss, and quiet tears.
Rewind life and remember how
The present once was simple now.

A bicycle chained to a tree,
A notebook full of poetry.
The crush that never got confessed,
The journey east to prove I'm blessed.

But time, it hums a backward tune,
Beneath the harvest moon.
I see the fights I thought were won,
The battles lost before begun.

The airport wave, the final call,
The silence after losing all.
Yet in this rewind, soft and slow,
I find the love I used to know.

Not in the grand or loud or bright,
But in the calm, the small, the light
Of kitchen lamps and lullabies,
Of starlit dreams and goodbyes.

So let me linger, just a while,
On every lost and sacred mile.
For in remembering, I understand—
Life’s truest gift is time in hand.

Rewind life and remember the sound—
Of childhood steps on hallowed ground.
Bare feet on grass, a dog’s soft bark,
The spark of youth in summer’s arc.

The classroom clock, the chalk’s soft trace,
A first red pen’s uncertain grace.
A note passed under wooden desks,
A secret smile, a heart’s soft risk.

Rewind the storm, the break, the fall,
The time I gave up, lost it all.
The job, the love, the city left,
The dreams that quietly bereft.

But in this rewind, I don’t erase—
I hold each wound, each tender space.
For every scar, a story grows,
A river through the soul it flows.

I see the hands that held me tight,
The ones I failed to hold at night.
The words I swallowed, cold and deep,
The promises I couldn’t keep.

Yet still, the past begins to glow,
Not as a wound, but as a show
Of being human, raw and real—
A life once lived, now made to feel.

So rewind, rewind, and let me see
The truth in what has come to be.

Rewind life and remember the sky—
That endless blue where dreams dared fly.
A kite unspooled, a paper plane,
Chasing clouds like joy’s refrain.

The summer nights on trampoline,
Counting stars, escaping routine.
A father’s laugh, a sister’s song,
A place where I felt I belonged.

But time rewinds with softer hands,
Through broken plans and shifting sands.
The job I quit, the flight delayed,
The love I lost, the price I paid.

Yet in the rewind, I don’t flee—
I face the pain, the doubt, the plea
That echoed in my silent core:
"Just be enough. Just be. No more."

And in remembering, I find
Not guilt, but grace of humankind.
Each stumble shaped the man I am,
Each shadow lit a guiding flame.

So rewind life, let memories start—
Not to undo, but heal the heart.
For in the past, I come to see:
The best of me was born in me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind life and remember—
threads of moments, soft and ember,
the laughter spun in kitchen light,
the hush of stars on winter night.
Pull the tape of time back slow,
watch young hands in gardens grow,
feel the weight of words unsaid,
ghosts that haunt the heart instead.
A backward tide through halls of years,
where joy and sorrow coalesce in tears.
I see her face before the storm,
her voice a lullaby, warm and worn.
Rewind—but not too far, I plead—
let me stay where love still feeds.
For memory is not a cure,
but a quiet hearth, enduring, pure.
And in the playback, faint and clear,
a self I almost disappeared.
So I remember, though it stings,
the song the past on silent wings still sings.

Rewind life and remember—
the scent of rain on summer ember,
the crush of leaves beneath my tread,
the things I thought I’d keep instead.
A carousel of faded frames:
morning light and whispered names,
a train ride lost in teenage dreams,
the crackle of forgotten seams.
I scroll through time like old film reels,
where every wound still subtly heals.
That glance across a crowded room,
the bloom of grief, the scent of bloom.
Rewind to when the world felt wide,
before the turn, the fall, the tide.
But memory bends, it twists, it lies,
still, in its glow, my spirit flies.
For though I cannot change the scene,
I find the child who once was keen.
So I rewind, not to erase,
but to reclaim that quiet grace.

Rewind life and remember—
not to fix, but to dismember
the weight of choices, sharp and deep,
the secrets time refused to keep.
Go back to porch swings, slow and low,
where fireflies in jars would glow,
to scraped knees and lemonade,
to plans the future never made.
Back to the day the letter came,
the voice that called, the whispered name.
To hands held tight on hospital floors,
and promises behind closed doors.
Rewind to when the music played,
and grief was just a distant shade.
Now memory flickers, thin and worn,
like film degraded, tattered, torn.
But still I press the unseen key,
and live what used to be.
For in the echo, soft and dim,
lives the rhythm, lives the hymn.

Rewind life and remember—
the taste of bread still warm in ember,
the dog that barked at passing bikes,
the weight of snow on frozen dykes.
Go back to schoolyard games and fears,
to tangled hair and childhood tears,
to bedtime tales and lullabies,
to stars that mapped the open skies.
Rewind to when the world was kind,
or so my mind insists on seeing,
before the cracks began to show,
before I learned to fake and feign.
Back to the park, the swing, the fall,
the mother’s voice that called through hall.
Now time’s a river, rushing, wide,
but memory is the turning tide.
I press rewind in silent prayer,
to breathe the air, to simply be there.
Not to change, but just to know,
I was once that long-ago.

Rewind life and remember—
the flicker of a dying ember,
the train that left without a sound,
the love that slipped through trembling hands.
Back through the blur of hurried days,
to quiet nights and old essays
of dreams I sketched in margins wide,
before the world said, 'Set aside.'
Rewind to when the music soared,
before the silence, locked the door.
To faces lost to time and space,
and smiles I can’t replace.
A film reversed in muted tones,
where I walk backward through my bones.
Each frame a ghost, each scene a plea—
remember me, remember me.
Not for glory, not for fame,
but for the whisper of a name
that once belonged to who I was,
before the weight of living’s laws.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind life and remember—
the scent of rain on summer grass,
the way your mother called your name
like a song she’d known since birth.
Pull the thread back through the needle,
undo the stumble, the fall, the fracture,
and find that moment on the porch swing
where laughter tangled in the breeze.
Rewind to the first dare, the first kiss,
the train ride with no destination,
the quiet when the music stopped
and you realized you were home.
Memory is a film we splice and rerun,
frayed at the edges but glowing still.
We are editors of our own past,
cutting, splicing, choosing what to keep.
So rewind, not to change the ending,
but to honor the script that shaped you—
every typo, every pause, every breath
that led you here, remembering.

Rewind life and remember—
the weight of snow on bare branches,
the silence before the world woke.
Go back to the kitchen at midnight,
where your father hummed off-key
and stirred soup like a spell.
Back to the notebook filled with dreams,
the ones you folded into paper planes
and launched toward uncertain skies.
Rewind past the arguments,
the doors slammed like thunder,
and rest instead on the hand
that once held yours through grief.
Let time unspool like thread,
let moments rise like ghosts
not to haunt, but to whisper:
You were loved. You were seen.
Remember the way sunlight
painted your bedroom wall each dawn,
how even sorrow had a rhythm,
and how, even broken,
the heart kept beating—
rewinding, remembering,
still here.

Rewind life and remember—
the chalk lines on the sidewalk,
the jump rope’s steady slap,
the bicycle with training wheels
wobbling toward freedom.
Turn the reel backward,
frame by grainy frame,
through schoolyard bruises,
first heartbreaks, silent tears.
Back to the lullaby hummed off-key,
the blanket stitched with care,
the voice that said, 'You’re safe now,'
even when the world trembled.
Rewind past the choices
you wished you could unmake,
and linger where joy was simple:
a shared ice cream, a dog’s wag,
a sky full of fireflies.
Memory is not just archive,
but compass—pointing not to what was lost,
but to what remained: love,
fragile and fierce.
So rewind, not to escape,
but to reclaim the light
that never truly faded.

Rewind life and remember—
not the grand gestures,
but the quiet: steam rising from tea,
the cat curled on your lap,
the way your best friend laughed
until milk came out her nose.
Spin the timeline backward,
through job rejections, lonely nights,
missed trains, unanswered texts,
and find the morning you woke up
and the sun felt like a promise.
Rewind to the walk home from school,
the dandelions you picked for Mom,
the time you danced in the rain
just because the sky opened up.
Memory is a time machine
we all carry inside,
powered by scent, sound, a single word.
It doesn’t fix the cracks,
but it shows us where the light got in.
So rewind, not to rewrite,
but to recognize: you were always becoming.
And every scar, every smile,
every 'I’m sorry' and 'I love you'
still echoes in the rewind.

Rewind life and remember—
the texture of your childhood blanket,
the creak of the third stair,
the way your dog waited at the door
like you were the whole world.
Turn back the hours, not to fix,
but to feel: the hug that lingered,
the joke that needed no explanation,
the silence that wasn’t empty,
but full of understanding.
Rewind through lost years,
missed chances, paths not taken,
and pause where courage whispered,
and you listened.
Memory is not perfect,
it blurs, it bends,
yet still it holds the truth:
you were alive, deeply,
with all your flaws and fire.
So rewind, not to dwell,
but to gather the pieces
that made you—who you were,
who you are.
Remember, and keep going.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind life and remember the scent of rain on summer’s edge,
the way laughter curled through childhood halls,
and fireflies blinked their fragile lanterns in the dusk.
Go back to mother’s lullaby, half-heard through dreams,
to scraped knees and promises whispered beneath trees.
Each moment, a thread pulled gently from time’s spool—
innocence, love, small sorrows—unspooled with care.
Let memory be the hand that turns the wheel,
playing again the quiet mornings, the unspoken goodbyes,
the touch of a hand now gone.
Rewind to when hope wore no mask,
and the future was a road unwalked but bright.
Remember not just the peaks, but the valleys where you learned to breathe,
where silence taught you to listen.
Let the past be a compass, not an anchor.
Rewind life and remember—not to stay,
but to carry forward the light that shaped you.

Rewind life and remember the train at dawn,
steam curling like old thoughts from the tracks,
the station empty except for echoes.
Back to first heartbreak, sharp as shattered glass,
and the way you stitched yourself with poetry.
Remember the dog-eared book, the favorite song,
the night you danced alone beneath a full moon.
Rewind through seasons—autumn’s gold,
winter’s hush, spring’s reckless bloom.
Find the version of you who still believed in forever,
who wrote letters never sent, who dreamed in color.
Let memory be the mirror that shows not age,
but depth—the cracks where light got in.
Rewind not to change, but to honor
the choices, the stumbles, the quiet courage.
Remember the smell of bread in your grandmother’s kitchen,
the weight of a child’s hand in yours.
Rewind life and remember: you’ve always been becoming.

Rewind life and remember the quiet before speech,
the pulse of the world in your mother’s womb,
the first breath, the first cry.
Scroll backward through schoolyard games,
the taste of snowflakes on your tongue,
the treehouse where you planned to live forever.
Remember the friend who vanished like mist,
the love that burned bright and brief,
the silence after the phone call that changed everything.
Rewind to handwritten notes, mixtapes,
the way sunlight fell across the floor at 3 p.m.
Memory is a fragile film, scratched and fading,
but still it plays—moments stitched with meaning.
Rewind not to escape the present,
but to gather the pieces that made you.
Remember the courage it took to keep going,
even when no one was watching.
Rewind life and remember: every ending was a seed,
every loss, a lesson wrapped in sorrow.
You are the sum of all you’ve carried.

Rewind life and remember the streetlights flickering on,
the hum of crickets in July,
the way your father’s voice softened at bedtime.
Go back to the porch swing, the shared ice cream,
the dog that waited by the door each day.
Remember the teacher who saw you,
the book that made you feel less alone.
Rewind through heartaches and healings,
the nights you thought you wouldn’t survive,
and how dawn came anyway.
Let memory be the river that flows backward,
carrying not regret, but recognition.
See the younger you—scared, hopeful, trying.
Forgive the missteps, honor the effort.
Rewind life and remember the small mercies:
a warm cup, a kind word, a sudden laugh.
These are the stars in your personal sky.
Rewind not to dwell, but to thank.
Remember, and carry on with softer eyes.

Rewind life and remember the first time you saw the ocean,
its roar filling your chest like a second heartbeat.
Go back to chalk drawings on pavement,
to secrets traded under blanket forts.
Remember the scent of pine on a winter hike,
the way your best friend knew when you lied.
Rewind to missed chances, yes,
but also to quiet triumphs no one witnessed.
The poem you wrote at seventeen,
the day you stood up for someone small.
Let memory be the curator of your soul,
displaying not perfection, but truth.
Rewind through moves, losses, rebirths,
the versions of you that no longer fit.
Remember the hands that held you,
and the ones you had to let go.
Rewind life and remember: even the cracks
are where your light learned to shine.
Not to return, but to reclaim
the love woven through every year.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text: Rewind life and remember the creek behind the house where minnows darted through sunlit ripples. Bare feet on warm stone, the scent of cut grass clinging to summer’s breath. A bicycle left on its side, handlebars twisted like forgotten promises. The laughter of a sibling now distant, muffled by years and silence. Rewind to the kitchen table, where steam rose from tea like whispered confessions. Mother’s hands, cracked and sure, kneading dough into comfort. Father humming off-key, a tune now lost but felt in the bones. Rewind to first heartbreak beneath a streetlamp’s amber glow—naive sorrow, pure and sharp. Remember how the stars didn’t care, yet watched anyway. Rewind to mornings when the world was unwritten, every choice a door ajar. Remember the weight of small moments, how they gather like dust in the corners of memory. Rewind not to change, but to honor what shaped you. To stand once more in the current of being, and whisper: I was here. I lived. I loved.

Rewind life and remember the hush before dawn, when shadows still hugged the trees and the air tasted of dew and secrets. A porch swing creaking with the rhythm of your grandfather’s breath. His pipe smoke curling like questions into the gray. Rewind to your first word caught on a parent’s delighted gasp—how sound became bond. Remember the dog that waited at the gate, tail beating time like a metronome of loyalty. Rewind to the classroom where you raised your hand, voice trembling but true. That moment of courage, small but seismic. Remember the friend who vanished, whose name now echoes in empty hallways of the mind. Rewind to the kiss that tasted of rain and uncertainty, electric in its impermanence. Remember the day you forgave someone—or didn’t—and how it carved a canyon in your chest. Rewind not with regret, but reverence. Let the tape of years unspool, frame by fragile frame. See the child you were, the choices you made, the love you gave and lost. Remember not to dwell, but to carry. For every memory, a thread in the tapestry of becoming. And when the reel ends, you’ll know: you were alive in the most sacred sense.

Rewind life and remember the quiet rebellion of staying up past midnight, flashlight beneath the blanket, lost in worlds between pages. The hum of the refrigerator, the only witness. Rewind to scraped knees and the medicinal sting of peroxide, mother’s sigh hovering above. Remember the treehouse that collapsed in autumn, built on dreams and loose nails. Rewind to the train ride with headphones on, music swelling as landscapes blurred—feeling both nowhere and exactly where you needed to be. Remember the letter you never sent, folded and hidden like a secret wound. Rewind to your reflection in a rain-streaked bus window, wondering who you’d become. Remember the stranger who smiled at you on a bad day—their kindness a flare in the dark. Rewind to the moment you realized your parents were people, flawed and fragile, trying. Remember your hands—how they’ve held joy, clenched grief, offered peace. Rewind not to alter the past, but to feel its pulse. To honor the journey, not just the destination. Let memory be a river, not a cage. In remembering, you resurrect moments that shaped your soul. And in that sacred act, you learn: every second was a gift, even the ones that broke you.

Rewind life and remember the sound of your name called from a screen door—dinner ready, time to come in. The sky painted in sherbet hues, summer fading. Rewind to the first time you held a newborn cousin, their breath soft as moth wings against your neck. Remember the song that played when you danced alone in your room, blinds closed, heart open. Rewind to the argument that cracked the foundation of a friendship—words like shards, impossible to gather. Remember the walk home in silence, the weight of what was said and unsaid. Rewind to the morning you woke up and forgot a loved one was gone—then remembered all over again. Remember the smell of old books, of gasoline after rain, of your grandmother’s perfume lingering on a scarf. Rewind to the decision that changed everything: a yes, a no, a leap, a pause. Remember the stars above a lake, reflected so clearly you could walk on them. Rewind not to escape the present, but to understand it. Each memory a compass point. In remembering, you reclaim fragments of yourself scattered across time. You see the pattern in the chaos. And when the reel stops, you find yourself here—older, wiser, still becoming.

Rewind life and remember the cat that slept on your homework, purring like a tiny engine of warmth. The way snow fell silently outside your window, wrapping the world in hush. Rewind to the bus stop where you stood alone, backpack heavy with books and loneliness. Remember the teacher who saw you, really saw you, and said, 'You matter.' Rewind to the first time you tasted coffee, bitter and bold, sipped from a chipped mug at a roadside diner. Remember the road trip with windows down, singing off-key to songs you barely knew. Rewind to the night you cried under the covers, muffling sobs so no one would hear. Remember the sunrise after that long night—how it painted the sky in hope you didn’t feel but believed in anyway. Rewind to the moment you chose kindness over anger, silence over cruelty. Remember your hands typing these words, alive with memory and meaning. Rewind not to fix, but to feel. To let the past breathe in your chest. For in remembering, you honor the journey—the stumbles, the flights, the quiet miracles. And you realize: every moment, even the forgotten ones, led you here. To this breath. This poem. This life.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
With eyes cast low to shadowed ground,
Where every step was laced with fear,
And silence was the only sound.

I traced the cracks in weathered stone,
And bowed to voices sharp and cold,
Believing I was meant to kneel,
A story ancient, oft retold.

But in the hush, a spark took flame,
Not loud, but steady, deep within;
A whisper: 'Rise, though limbs may shake,
There is a world that longs to win.'

So I uncurled my aching hands,
Felt sunlight kiss my upturned face,
No longer bound by dust and dread,
But walking now with measured grace.

The past remains—a scar, a song—
A ghost that hums when nights are long.
Yet here I stand, both bruised and bold,
No longer grovelling, but whole.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Who fed on crumbs and called them bread,
Who smiled when struck, who wept in hush,
And bowed for words left cold and dead.

The world was wide, but I was small,
A shadow shrinking from the light,
Afraid to speak, afraid to stand,
Convinced I wasn't worth the fight.

But time, that thief and gentle sage,
Stole silence and returned a cry—
A single breath that broke the chain,
A question: 'Why must I comply?'

Now I walk with shoulders high,
Not proud, but free from borrowed shame.
The creature crouched is not erased,
But folded softly into flame.

I was a groveller, yes, it's true,
But now I rise, and now I choose.
And though the past may pull and plead,
I answer not to guilt or need.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A wisp of want in hollow halls,
Who scraped the floor for kindness tossed,
And thanked the hand that bruised at all.

My spine had learned the shape of 'no',
My voice had learned to disappear,
While masters praised their mercy shown
To one who lived in constant fear.

But in the dark, a thought took root:
'What if I am not meant to crawl?'
It trembled, faint, but would not die—
A seed that split the dungeon wall.

Now I speak, though voice may shake,
Now I stand, though legs protest.
The past is mine, but not my throne;
I wear my scars, but not my chains.

The creature once upon the floor
Still whispers from a distant door.
But I—now tall, now softly lit—
No longer answer to that script.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Who kissed the boots that kicked me down,
Who called the storm a gentle breeze,
And wore my sorrow like a crown.

I praised the hands that held the whip,
Believed the lie that I was less,
That love was earned by being small,
By swallowing my own distress.

But seasons turned, and so did I,
Not fast, not bold, but inch by inch.
A single word, then two, then three—
Until I found my proper voice to flinch
Not from the truth, but from the lie
That I was meant to disappear.

Now I plant my feet in soil,
No longer begging, no longer blind.
The past is real, but not my guide;
I walk a different, sturdier line.

Grovelling shaped me, yes, it’s true,
But not the whole, not all I do.
I was that creature—once, I swear—
But now I breathe the cleaner air.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A shadow trained to shrink and serve,
Who mistook silence for consent,
And thought survival was the nerve.

I memorized the art of small,
The tilt of head, the hushed reply,
Believed my worth was what they gave,
And never dared to ask 'why?'

But in the quiet, something stirred—
Not rage, not pride, but quiet doubt:
'If I am nothing when I kneel,
Then what might rise if I stood out?'

So slowly, like a wounded bird,
I tested wings I thought were torn.
One step, then two, then facing front,
No longer braced for being scorned.

The world did not collapse, nor roar;
It simply let me take the floor.
I was a groveller, it’s true,
But now—I choose a different view.

The past is there, a faded stain,
But not the map, not the refrain.
I rise not to defy or boast,
But simply—finally—be my ghost.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent beneath the weight of doubt,
Kneeling where the cold winds吹,
With no star to lead me out.
My hands scraped the stony ground,
Searching for a truth unnamed,
While shadows mocked the smallest sound
Of hope, too frail to be claimed.

But in the hush between the fears,
A whisper rose—not loud, but clear:
‘You are more than dust and tears.’
And though I trembled, half in dread,
I lifted up my aching head.

Now I walk with scars that gleam,
Not as proof of where I fell,
But as light along the seam
Where grace pulled me from the well.
No longer bent, no longer blind,
I carry dignity refined—
A soul once crushed, now unconfined,
And love, at last, the guiding sign.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Licking boots and begging grace,
Trusting every iron fence
To keep me safe in that dark place.
I praised the hands that struck my face,
And called the chains a kind embrace.

But silence grew too loud to bear,
A fire sparked behind my eyes.
The more they tried to clip my hair,
The more I learned to recognize
The lie that told me I was less—
A myth to serve their loneliness.

Now I rise on wings of scorn,
No longer theirs to break or bind.
The meek may inherit morn,
But I—I claim the storm, the wind,
The lightning cracking through the sky,
The thunder of my battle cry.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But from that ash, a phoenix runs.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A shadow crawling on the floor,
Apologizing for my scent,
For breathing near the gilded door.
I folded myself small and thin,
So I might not take up space,
Let my voice grow faint within,
A ghost without a face.

But one day, the mirror cracked,
And I saw not shame, but flame—
A flicker in the frozen act,
A name I dared to claim.
No longer would I kiss the boot
That crushed my spine into the dirt.
I pulled my roots from poisoned fruit,
And chose a different birth.

Now I stand with spine uncurled,
Not queen, nor saint—but free.
The groveller was not the world,
Just one lost part of me.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Crawling through the garden’s muck,
Offering my soul for cents,
While they feasted, fat and stuck
In gilded lies and velvet lies.
I bowed to every petty throne,
Blinded by their hollow eyes,
Afraid to face the unknown.

But seasons turn, and worms grow wings.
The soil that held me now gives birth
To something wild the world now sings—
Not praised for worth, but known for worth.

I shed the skin of shame and fear,
Let silence scream until it broke.
The creature gone, the path is clear:
I speak my name, and it is no joke.

No more on knees, no more in dust,
I rise—a bloom from rot and rust.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A whisper lost in thunder’s wake,
Drowning in a world immense,
For every breath a risk I’d take.
I learned to shrink, to smile, to lie,
To serve with eyes cast to the ground,
While giants passed me by,
Unseeing, deaf, without a sound.

But deep within, a pulse remained,
A quiet drum beneath the shame.
It called me by a truer name,
And fanned a slow, unyielding flame.

One dawn, I stood. Not tall, not proud,
But upright, raw, and trembling.
The silence screamed into a cloud
That broke with rain like healing.

Now I walk with head held high,
Not to mock, nor to defy—
But to say, with steady breath:
I was… but now, I am not death.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Crawling through dust and dread,
With eyes cast down, my spirit hunched,
By shame and silence led.

The world above was loud and bright,
But I knew only the floor—
Each whisper cut like sharpened light,
Each shadow begged for more.

Then came a voice, not loud, but clear,
That pierced my ear like dawn:
"Rise, trembling one, I see you here,
You are not meant to be withdrawn."

So slowly, I uncurled my frame,
Felt muscles long unused.
The weight that bound me bore my name,
But now I stand, confused—

Not by the height, but by the grace
That lifted me from mire.
No longer bound to that dark place,
I sing with new desire.

For though I once did grovel low,
I've learned to kneel for love,
And from that depth, a truth does grow:
The stars watch from above,

Not judging, but inviting in
The creature I became—
No longer bent, but wearing skin
That bears both wound and flame.

I was a grovelling creature once,
With fingers stained by clay,
Bowing to every passing prince,
And begging for their praise.

My back a bridge for prideful feet,
My voice a muffled sigh.
I measured worth in scraps to eat,
And called it destiny.

But in the dark, a spark took hold—
Not fierce, but firm and small.
It whispered, 'You were forged, not sold,
And you can want it all.'

So inch by inch, I pulled myself
From under ancient chains.
The world still looms, its towers pelf,
But I no longer feign.

I stand—though shaky, though afraid—
And meet the wind with chest.
The past is not a cage, but aid,
A wound that taught me best.

Now when I speak, I do not plead,
My words are sharp, not thin.
The creature once on hands and knee
Has learned to walk on wind.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A shadow in the hall,
Whose every breath was penitence,
And every hope, a fall.

I kissed the boots of hollow gods,
And called their scorn a gift.
My soul was wrapped in guilt's tight cords,
And every dream did drift.

But time, that thief and tender sage,
Unwound the knots I wore.
It taught me rage, it taught me page,
It taught me to want more.

Now I do not kneel for fear,
Nor flinch at thunder's call.
The voice that once was thin and clear
Now echoes through the wall.

The creature low, the one who crawled,
Has risen, scarred, aware.
Not flawless, but no longer thrall—
Just human, standing there.

I was a grovelling creature once,
With eyes that never rose,
Believing I was paid in cents
For virtues no one chose.

I scraped the ground for kindness dropped,
Like crumbs from tables wide.
My dignity, a thread, soon popped,
And pride, I set aside.

But seasons turn, and so did I,
Not fast, not without pain.
I watched the sky, began to try,
To stand up in the rain.

The world still tilts, still tests my spine,
But now I speak my name.
The creature once on hands and knee
Now walks through fire and flame.

Not perfect, but no longer small,
Not broken, just alive.
The past is not a shroud, but wall
From which new wings derive.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A wisp beneath the door,
Whose laughter came as afterthought,
And love, a distant war.

I served the ones who never stayed,
And called it loyalty.
My dreams were debts I never paid,
And hope, a luxury.

But deep within, a pulse remained,
A beat beneath the stone.
It didn't shout, it didn't strain,
But would not leave me lone.

And so I rose, not in a leap,
But like the morning grass—
Unnoticed at first, but bold and deep,
Defying all that pass.

Now I do not beg for light,
I kindle it myself.
The creature once in endless night
Has claimed a different shelf.

Not high, not grand, but standing tall
In truth, in skin, in breath.
I was a groveller—no more.
I am, at last, my death.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent beneath the weight of doubt,
Crawling through the thorned expanse,
Whispering prayers I lived without.

The earth was cold, the sky a vault
Of stars that never cast a light;
I bore the lash of silent fault,
And called the darkness my quiet rite.

But in the hush, a spark took hold—
Not flame, not fury, just a glow,
A breath that warmed my ashen soul,
And taught my broken bones to grow.

Now I rise, not tall in pride,
But lifted by a gentler grace;
The creature once who crawled and cried
Walks upright in a wider space.

No throne, no crown, no grand design,
Just hands that open to the rain,
And eyes that meet the sun’s bright sign—
Not healed, but healing all the same.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Kneeling in the dust of dreams denied,
Where shadows stretched and hope was tense,
And every breath was bought with pride.

I scraped the soil for scraps of worth,
Apologized for taking space,
Believed the world was built for mirth
That I was never meant to taste.

But time, that thief and tender sage,
Stole silence from my aching chest;
Lit candles in my rusted cage,
And whispered, "You may rise. Be blessed."

Now I stand, not flawless, not unscarred,
But taller than the fear I knew.
The past remains, but not as guard—
A lesson carved in gentle hue.

For even those who crawl and weep
May learn the rhythm of their feet,
And trade the dark they used to keep
For skies where softer winds now meet.

I was a grovelling creature once,
With eyes cast low and voice a thread,
Afraid to stir, to make offense,
And bowed beneath unspoken dread.

The world was loud, too sharp, too wide,
I shrank to fit a smaller skin;
Survival was my only guide,
And trust a risk I’d not let in.

But in the quiet, something stirred—
A pulse beneath the weight of years,
A wordless cry, a single word:
"Enough. I will no longer kneel here."

Now I walk with shoulders bare,
Not fearless, but no longer bound.
The air feels different, light and fair,
On ground where I have newly found

That dignity need not be earned,
But claimed, like breath, like morning dew.
Though old wounds ache and doubts return,
I choose to stand. I choose to be true.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A shadow licking boots of stone,
Whispering yes when I meant no,
And calling it my nature, my own.

I polished shame like a sacred charm,
Bowed for crumbs, for glance, for name,
Believed my worth was owed to harm,
And pain was just a different flame.

But one day, wind broke through the door,
Not loud, not grand, but soft and clear,
It brushed my neck, touched the core—
And I forgot how to fear.

Now I speak, though voice may shake,
Now I reach, though hands may bleed.
The past is real, but not my stake.
I plant my soul. I plant my seed.

No longer bent, no longer small,
I learn the shape of being seen.
The groveller fades—he meant no call—
But I, I choose what I have been.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Dwelling in the margins of the loud,
Where silence was my defense,
And longing wore a modest shroud.

I flinched at gestures, read between
The lines of laughter sharp as knives,
Convinced that I was never seen,
And love was not for lives like mine.

But seasons turn, and so do hearts,
And something deep began to shift—
A quiet courage played its parts,
A fragile will began to lift.

Now I speak without a plea,
Stand without apology’s chain.
The world still hums its cruelty,
But I am not the same.

For though the past may shape my tread,
It does not own the path I trace.
The creature once so bowed and dead
Now walks with quiet, steady grace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Crawling through dust and doubt,
Kissing the boots of hollow men,
While silence choked my shout.

The world was made of stone and spite,
Where kindness dared not bloom,
And every dream I dared to keep
Was buried in a tomb.

But in the dark, a spark remained,
A whisper, thin and slight—
A name I once had carved in stars
Before I lost the light.

I rose not with a battle cry,
Nor thunder in my veins,
But with the quiet of the dawn
That follows longest rains.

Now I stand, not tall from pride,
But from the weight I've known,
And though my hands still bear the scars,
They carry seeds, not stones.

I was a grovelling creature once,
With eyes fixed on the ground,
Collecting crumbs of borrowed grace
From voices without sound.

My spine was bent by other wills,
My voice a stolen thing,
I wore compliance like a cloak
And called it offering.

But in the hush between heartbeats,
A question took its root:
What if I lifted up my gaze
And dared to be the truth?

So slowly, like a bud in frost,
I stretched toward the sun,
Not perfect, not unbroken,
But no longer undone.

Now when I walk, the earth feels firm,
No longer stained with shame.
I was a shadow once, it's true—
But shadows prove there’s flame.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Licking boots for bread,
Believing love was earned through ache,
And praise was paid in dread.

I mapped my worth in frowns appeased,
In storms I’d calm alone,
A ghost within my own skin,
A throne usurped, overthrown.

But one night, staring at the moon,
I heard a voice arise—
Not thunderous, not commanding,
But soft between my thighs.

It said: You need not kneel to be
Of value, dear, or seen.
You are not less for standing up,
Nor flawed for being keen.

Now I walk with head unbowed,
Though memories still creep.
I was a worm, it's true—but worms
Turn soil so flowers leap.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A shadow at the gate,
Whispering apologies
For merely being late.

I folded myself small,
A paper boat adrift,
Hoping not to capsize
In glances swift and stiff.

My voice? A moth-wing tremble.
My will? A buried seed.
I thought devotion meant
To bleed when others feed.

But time, that quiet rebel,
Unraveled what was false.
Taught me that grace begins
Not on knees, but on pulse.

Now I speak without permission.
Now I take up space.
I was a whisper once—
Now I am the grace.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Kneeling at altars cold,
Offering my breath as tax
To gods who never told

If sacrifice would ever earn
A glance, a nod, a sign.
I measured hope in sighs withheld,
In moments not malign.

My body learned the shape of 'less',
The grammar of the small,
A pupil trained in vanishing,
The quietest of all.

But one dawn, light fell differently—
Not golden, not divine,
But plain, and warm, and meant for me
Without a need to climb.

I stood. Not tall, not flawless,
But upright, unashamed.
I was a beggar once—
Now I am named.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
With eyes cast low and spirit thin,
Creeping through shadows, mute and dense,
Beneath the weight of every sin.

I kissed the boots of hollow kings,
And praised the lies that choked my breath,
Worshipping false, unfeeling things,
While dreaming of a life with death.

But something stirred beneath the dust—
A spark, a hum, a whispered name—
And slowly, from the mire I thrust,
No longer bent by shame or blame.

Now I stand tall, though scarred and worn,
No supplicant to gods of stone.
The creature bowed is now outgrown;
I claim the self I've always known.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A whisper in the dark, afraid,
Who traded dignity for cents,
And bowed where I was never paid.

I licked the boots of colder men,
And smiled while bleeding from within,
Accepted chains I called them friends,
And let my fire dwindle thin.

But time, that thief and midwife both,
Unraveled lies I used to wear.
I found my voice beneath my oath,
And learned the weight of righteous air.

Now I walk with lifted chin,
Not perfect, but no longer small.
The past is deep, but not my sin—
I was a worm. I am not all.

I was a grovelling creature once,
With hands in dirt and heart in chains,
Who danced when masters gave their glance,
And starved while serving banquet trains.

I wore compliance like a skin,
And flinched at every raised command,
Believed that mercy lived within
The fist that crushed my trembling hand.

But seasons turn, and so did I,
Not with a roar, but quiet grace.
I met my gaze, refused to die,
And stepped into a truer place.

No longer crawling, cold and blind,
I rise—not flawless, but unbound.
The past still echoes in my mind,
But I am not that man on ground.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A shadow fed on scraps of praise,
Who built my home on shifting fence,
And called obedience my praise.

I bowed to voices sharp and loud,
To frowns that cut and eyes that lied,
And wore my silence like a shroud,

But one day, wind carried a tune

I stood. My knees cracked with the strain.

I was a grovelling creature once,
