There’s no name, no past, no fear—
Just the now, wide and bright.
A child’s laugh, a deer
Stepping softly from the light.
I become the space where music lives,
The pause before a kiss.
All that binds and grieves
Unravels into bliss.
And though it fades, as all things do,
I remember: I was light, and flew.

When I am happy, the clock forgets,
Dishes pile high and dinner burns.
I spin in circles with no regrets,
While firelight flickers and softly turns.
My cat blinks slow, as if he knows,
That joy is messy, loud, and wild.
I sing off-key to radio shows,
And dance with my child.
We build castles out of sofa throws,
And crown each other king and queen.
No need for diamonds, no need for clothes—
Just this moment, bright and clean.
Happiness isn’t earned or owed—
It blooms when you carry a lighter load.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy, the world turns gold—
Sunlight drips like honey on the trees,
And every shadow lifts to dance and fold
Into the breeze with whispered melodies.

The birds compose in keys of sky and flame,
Each note a spark that lingers in the air;
Even the pavement hums a different name,
No longer cold, no longer stripped of care.

My laughter rides the wind to meet the clouds,
And they, in kindness, blush a gentle pink.
The smallest things—untied shoelaces, crowds—
Become a song I didn’t stop to think.

The clock forgets to chide, the stars appear
Before their time, just to see me here.

And when the night arrives with softer tread,
I know such joy was never mine to keep—
Yet still, I carry where the light has led,
A quiet pulse that hums beneath my sleep.

When I am happy, rivers run uphill,
And dandelions recite Shakespearean sonnets.
The moon wears sunglasses made of stardust and style,
While squirrels debate philosophy in Latin.

Laundry folds itself, socks reunite,
And traffic lights turn green for no one but me.
Even my shadow dances with delight,
A tap-dancing echo wild and free.

The coffee knows my name before I speak,
And every sidewalk crack becomes a map
To buried laughter, strong enough to leak
Through concrete and into my heart's deep gap.

I sing off-key, and birds applaud in tune,
While gravity forgets to weigh me down.

But most of all, beneath the sun or moon,
I wear my joy like a familiar gown—
No need to hide, no need to explain,
Just breath, and light, and love, and rain.

When I am happy, silence sings.
Not with voices, but with space—
The pause between the clock’s heartbeats,
The hush that drapes the sky’s soft face.

A cup of tea remembers warmth,
And steam draws spirals in the air;
Each curl a memory reborn,
A whispered dream beyond compare.

The bookshelf leans a little closer,
As if to listen, page by page,
While dust motes waltz in slanted light,
Performing on a sunlit stage.

My hands forget their usual tremor,
And even scars seem less defined—
For joy, when true, does not demand a roar,
But blooms in stillness, deep and kind.

So when I am happy, nothing shouts,
Yet everything begins to glow—
A quiet fire the world knows nothing of,
But burns, unseen, and will not go.

When I am happy, time forgets its name.
Seconds stretch into long, golden threads,
Weaving moments without aim or claim,
Where even silence sings in soft echoes.

I walk barefoot on sidewalks that feel like sand,
And strangers smile as if they know my song.
The sky wears colors never seen by hand,
A watercolor where I do belong.

My breath becomes a melody, light and clear,
Each inhale pulling stardust through my chest.
The weight I carried for so many years
Dissolves like mist beneath a morning’s zest.

I do not need to speak, to prove, to strive—
Just be, and let the universe arrive.

A sparrow perched on a rusted wire
Sings just for me, a brief, bright fire.

And though this joy may fade like evening light,
It leaves a map behind—my soul’s true north—
A compass drawn from pure delight,
That guides me back, again, to worth.

When I am happy, the air tastes like lemonade,
Cold and sweet with a fizz of light.
Clouds shape themselves into lemon slices, laid
Across a blue so bold it feels like flight.

My shadow wears a party hat,
And skips ahead on walls and floors.
Even my frown lines take a nap for that
One perfect hour behind closed doors.

The toaster burns my bread just right,
Charred edges framing golden centers.
I don’t mind—I eat it with delight,
A crunch that hums with tiny splendors.

My phone stays silent, and I don’t care,
No messages can pierce this gilded haze.
I dance alone without a prayer,
Just swaying through the afternoon’s soft blaze.

When I am happy, the world winks,
As if we share a secret no one else can drink.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy, the world hums a tune,
A quiet melody beneath the moon.
Leaves dance in rhythm on whispered air,
And sunlight lingers without a care.
My breath becomes a lullaby,
Soft and warm, a gentle sigh.
Birds stitch the sky with silver thread,
And even silence feels well-fed.
The pavement glimmers like scattered stars,
Reflecting joy from afar.
I walk as if I’m barely touching ground,
Each step a note in a wordless sound.
The grocery clerk, the stray dog near,
All glow with a kindness I suddenly hear.
When I am happy, the mundane takes flight,
Turned to gold by inner light.
No grand event, no fanfare loud—
Just peace that wraps me like a cloud.
And if it fades, as feelings do,
I carry the melody, quiet and true,
A secret song that still will start
Whenever I open my heart.

When I am happy, I forget my name,
Dissolved in light, no two ways the same.
Colors speak in fluent hues,
And time dissolves like morning dews.
I am the breeze that lifts the wheat,
The pulse beneath the city street.
A child’s laugh, a cat’s soft purr,
A book half-read, a window stir.
I do not seek, I do not ask,
I simply drift through joy’s soft task.
No need for reason, no need for why—
I am the gleam in a sparrow’s eye.
The kettle sings, the toast turns gold,
And stories in the cracks unfold.
The neighbor’s radio, faint and sweet,
Plays a tune from the past, complete.
When I am happy, I am not me,
But everything, wild and free.
A fleeting moment, vast and deep,
Where even silence starts to leap.
And when it ends, I do not grieve—
I know the light will still believe
That joy, once felt, can always start
Again within a single heart.

When I am happy, the air tastes sweet,
Like berries crushed beneath bare feet.
I notice how the shadow leans
Across the bricks in quiet scenes.
A pigeon struts with comic pride,
A balloon escapes, no one to guide.
I smile at cracks in the sidewalk art,
And hum a tune from the depths of my heart.
The weight I carried starts to lift,
As though on wings, both frail and swift.
I see the world in softer tones,
No longer walking through brittle bones.
Even the traffic’s angry blare
Turns into music hanging in air.
I text a friend just to say hello,
No agenda, just a gentle glow.
When I am happy, I am found,
Not lost in thought or heavy ground.
I stand still, yet I still move—
A quiet bloom, a gift of love.
And though it fades like ocean foam,
It leaves behind a sense of home,
A knowing that beneath the gray,
Joy waits to dance another day.

When I am happy, I forget the clock,
And thoughts of failure turn to flock—
Not crows of dread, but doves in flight,
Soaring through a calm, blue light.
I brew my tea without a plan,
Letting stillness fill the pan.
Steam writes poems on the glass,
Echoes of a quiet pass.
I watch a spider weave its lace,
A masterpiece in time and space.
No need to rush, no need to speak,
Just being is the song I seek.
The cat stretches in a sunlit square,
A moment caught in golden air.
I breathe in slow, I breathe out deep,
Letting every worry sleep.
When I am happy, I am whole,
Not chasing after fame or gold.
I find the sacred in the small—
The way the rain begins to fall,
The scent of bread, the dog’s soft gaze—
All part of a luminous haze.
And if the clouds return to loom,
I carry this calm inner room,
Where peace resides, a quiet spark,
Lit bright within the deepest dark.

When I am happy, I talk to trees,
Whispering secrets on the breeze.
They nod in rhythm, leaves aglow,
As if they, too, have come to know
The weightless joy that fills my chest,
A fluttering bird put to rest.
I name the clouds—"Wanderer," "Ship," "Fox"—
And laugh at my own silly thoughts.
I skip across the parkway line,
A child reborn at thirty-nine.
My shadow dances, loose and wide,
A partner in this joyful ride.
I buy a flower with no reason,
Give a stranger my season.
When I am happy, rules unwind,
And logic fades, left far behind.
I sing off-key, I spin in place,
Unashamed, unbound by space.
Time stretches soft, a rubber band,
Held gently in a loving hand.
And though the world may call it small,
This lightness lifts me over all.
For happiness needs no grand stage—
Just heart, and time, and turning page.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy, the world hums a tune,
A melody spun from the sun and the moon.
Dandelion seeds float on the breeze,
Carrying laughter through flowering trees.
The pavement glistens with rain-washed light,
And every shadow feels soft and bright.
Birds stitch the sky with threads of song,
And I know, for once, I belong.
Even silence sings in gentle refrain,
As joy slips through the cracks of pain.
My breath is deep, my steps are slow,
Tracing the rhythm that makes me glow.
When I am happy, the smallest things—
A cat’s soft purr, the way sunlight clings—
Become small miracles, pure and true,
And the heart remembers how to renew.
No grand gesture, no fanfare or call,
Just the quiet joy of being small,
Yet deeply seen, and softly known,
A seed in fertile earth, fully grown.

When I am happy, colors breathe,
Crimson rivers beneath my feet.
Clouds wear hats of spun gold light,
And stars blink awake in broad daylight.
I skip syllables in my stride,
Turn sidewalk cracks into ocean tide.
My shadow dances ahead of me,
Waving like an old friend, wild and free.
The wind composes sonnets in my hair,
And every breath feels like a prayer.
I speak in petals, think in bloom,
Drowning in sweet, sunlit gloom.
Time uncurls like a fern in spring,
And even sorrow forgets to sting.
When I am happy, the world winks—
A secret smile on the edge of things.

When I am happy, I forget my name,
Become a flicker, a dancing flame.
I rise with kites on warm air's sigh,
Beneath a dome of fathomless sky.
My hands are full of invisible wings,
My heart a bell that no one rings,
Yet chimes with joy that needs no sound,
A quiet pulse beneath the ground.
I walk through fields of whispered grace,
Where time dissolves without a trace.
Even shadows smile in gentle hue,
And every moment feels brand new.
When I am happy, I am not here—
I'm everywhere, yet crystal clear.
A breath, a breeze, a fleeting spark,
The universe aglow inside the dark.

When I am happy, the kettle sings,
And toast pops up with golden wings.
The cat blinks slow from her sunlit chair,
And dust motes waltz in the morning air.
I stir my tea with gentle care,
Watch sugar swirl without a prayer.
Laughter bubbles from deep within,
A quiet joy that’s always been.
No need for mountains, oceans, skies—
Just this small room where stillness lies.
A book half-read, a window wide,
The peace of nowhere left to hide.
When I am happy, I simply am,
No past, no future—just the calm.

When I am happy, I vanish whole,
Become the wind, the sky, the soul
Of every leaf that dares to spin,
Every ripple drawn deep within.
I am the hush between two notes,
The spark that flares in silent throats.
No name, no form, just pure release,
A moment carved from time’s decrease.
I float beyond both joy and grief,
A quiet leaf on an endless reef.
When I am happy, I am gone,
Returned to where all light is drawn.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy, the sky wears a grin,
And clouds like cotton candy spin.
The breeze hums tunes I used to know,
A lullaby from long ago.
Birds stitch melodies through the trees,
And sunlight dances on the breeze.
Each blade of grass sings out with glee,
A chorus born of purity.
Even the stones seem light and warm,
As if they’ve weathered every storm.
My shadow leaps, no longer shy,
It waltzes underneath the sky.
Laughter blooms in quiet ways—
A dandelion in a maze.
Time slows, not heavy, but soft and thin,
As joy pours gently from within.
No need for reasons, none to name,
Just this: the world is bright with flame.
And when I’m happy, truly so,
The universe begins to glow.

When I am happy, I forget my name,
Become the wind, the flickering flame.
I am the rustle in the autumn leaves,
The hush a falling teardrop weaves.
A sparrow perched on a telephone wire,
Humming desires that never expire.
I am the glint in a stranger’s eye,
The echo of a lullaby.
No chains of thought, no weight of years,
Just color blooming through my tears.
Not sad, but full—so overfull,
Like moonlight spilling from a cup.
I touch the world but leave no print,
A ghost of joy, a soft ascent.
And if you look, you won’t see me,
Just golden light on every tree.
When I am happy, I disappear,
And reappear in every sphere.

When I am happy, the clock unwinds,
And seconds stretch like chewing gum.
I sip the air in slow, deep gulps,
While silence hums a steady drum.
My thoughts turn soft, like kitten paws,
No edges sharp, no need to rush.
The world becomes a watercolor,
Blending sky and street and soul.
A dog barks joy from down the block,
A child laughs without a why.
Even the traffic’s grumble fades
To rhythm underneath the sky.
I don’t need answers, don’t need plans,
Just this breath, these outstretched hands.
When I am happy, I belong—
Not to a place, but to the song
That rises when the heart forgets
The weight of all its quiet regrets.

When I am happy, I vanish into light,
A flicker where the shadows fight.
Not loud, not bold, but quietly there,
Like petals floating on evening air.
I need no crown, no grand display,
Just sun-warmed stone and birds at play.
A cup of tea, a book half-read,
A quiet word, a nod, a thread
Of understanding, thin and true,
That stitches me to all of you.
No fireworks, no fanfare loud,
But peace that wraps me like a shroud—
Though not for death, but for rebirth,
For seeing magic on this earth.
When I am happy, I am small,
And that’s the truest joy of all.

When I am happy, I speak in colors—
Crimson giggles, sapphire hours.
My voice a brushstroke on the dawn,
A quiet hymn without a cause.
I walk barefoot on dew-kissed lawns,
Where dreams unspool like cotton thread.
Each step a note, each breath a chord,
A symphony inside my chest unzipped.
I don’t need reasons, don’t need proof,
Just golden light and morning’s sniff.
The world leans in, as if to hear
The song I’ve carried all year.
And when I’m happy, I become
Not someone, but a sudden hum
Within the earth, the air, the stream—
The quiet pulse behind the dream.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy, the world hums a tune,
A soft melody beneath the moon,
Where fireflies dance in golden light,
And stars blink gently through the night.
The wind carries laughter, warm and clear,
Whispering secrets only the heart can hear.
Trees sway like friends in a joyful ring,
And every small bird begins to sing.
Even the shadows seem light and kind,
Painted in hues of peace and mind.
My breath becomes rhythm, my step a rhyme,
Caught in the magic of borrowed time.
When I am happy, the sky wears blue,
And every cloud has a silver hue.
I walk barefoot through fields of green,
Where wildflowers bloom, serene and keen.
Time slows down, yet flies away,
A fleeting moment I long to stay.
But happiness lingers, a quiet flame,
Not needing reason, just being the same.
So when I am happy, I know it’s true—
The world sings back every note from me to you.

When I am happy, colors speak,
In vibrant tones the quiet peaks
Of ordinary moments rise,
Painted wide across the skies.
A yellow sun on windowpanes,
The purple hush after summer rains,
Crimson leaves that twirl and glide—
Nature’s joy I cannot hide.
I taste the sweetness in the air,
Like honeyed bread and jasmine there.
My hands reach out to touch the glow
Of moments soft and moving slow.
When I am happy, silence sings,
And even sorrow takes on wings,
Transformed by light into a dove,
A quiet miracle of love.
I write no verses, yet they form
In every heartbeat, calm and warm.
For happiness needs no disguise—
It blooms in glances, laughs, and sighs.
And when I am happy, I understand
Life’s quiet beauty, close at hand.

When I am happy, the pavement gleams,
Reflecting sun in liquid streams.
A busker plays on cobbled stone,
His music mine, and mine alone.
I spin once, twice—no one complains,
As joy surges through my veins.
A child laughs, a dog runs free,
And suddenly the world’s with me.
I buy a peach from a roadside stand,
Juice on my fingers, warm, unplanned.
I watch the clouds shape-shift and flow,
One looks like a sheep, one like a crow.
When I am happy, time dissolves,
Routine unravels, stress evolves
Into a hum, a gentle beat,
A dance of pulses, light and sweet.
I don’t need much—just sky and sound,
A patch of grass, this hallowed ground.
For in this moment, I am whole,
A quiet fire within my soul.

When I am happy, the kettle sings,
The toast pops up with golden wings.
Steam writes poems on the kitchen glass,
Memories forming as moments pass.
I stir my tea and watch it swirl,
A tiny galaxy in a porcelain world.
The cat stretches, the dog sighs,
Sunlight pools in sleepy eyes.
I hum a tune my mother knew,
A melody both old and new.
When I am happy, small things shine—
A chipped mug, a tangled line
Of yarn on the floor, a book half-read,
Pillow forts built from blankets spread.
There’s no grand gesture, no fanfare,
Just peace that settles in the air.
And in that stillness, I am found,
Safe and smiling on common ground.

When I am happy, the clock forgets,
No past to mourn, no future debts.
I float between breath and bloom,
A flower opening in a quiet room.
My skin remembers sunlight’s kiss,
A lover’s hand, a moment’s bliss.
But happiness isn’t always loud—
Sometimes it hides in a passing cloud,
In laundry flapping on a line,
Or steam that curls from cocoa fine.
I write your name in sugar dust,
A fleeting mark, a fragile trust.
When I am happy, I don’t need
To plant a seed or win or lead.
I simply am, and that is more
Than all the world has asked before.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see, a shadow shaped like me,
With eyes that hold the storms of years I cannot flee.
It wears my face, yet wears it wrong—
A crooked smile, a whispered song.
Each breath it draws I once denied,
Dreams buried deep where none could find.
It carries scars I never claimed,
And speaks in words I’ve long been shamed.

I reach a hand, but space betrays—
A mirror cracked through time and haze.
This ghost of self, both near and far,
Is who I was, and who we are.
Not future’s hope, nor past’s regret,
But truth unspoken, silhouette.
Before me stands I see, at last,
The version that was meant to last.

Before me stands I see a door,
Unmarked, unlit, yet known before.
A threshold drawn in silent breath,
Between the life I’ve lived and death
Of old desires, worn-out names,
The echo of forgotten flames.

I do not knock, I do not wait,
But step through as I sealed my fate.
Inside, a room of endless night,
Lit only by the moon’s pale light,
Where shadows dance in patient rows,
And whisper all the truths I chose
To leave behind, to hide, to flee—
Before me stands I see.

Before me stands I see a tree,
Its roots entwined with memory.
Each leaf a thought I let unfold,
Each branch a path my heart once told.

It sways with winds from distant lands,
From childhood shores and shifting sands.
Its bark is etched with names I knew,
And some I’ve lost, or never drew.

I touch its trunk and feel the years,
The laughter drowned in silent tears.
It grows not forward, nor behind,
But in the space where souls are twined.
Before me stands I see, and know,
The only truth I need to show.

Before me stands I see a flame,
Dancing soft without a name.
It flickers with a voice I knew,
A version lost in what I do.

Not bright with pride, nor sharp with pain,
But calm, like rain on windowpane.
It does not beg, it does not plead,
Just burns with what I failed to need.

No judgment in its gentle glow,
Just warmth for seeds I let not grow.
It asks no pardon, seeks no place,
Yet fills the air with quiet grace.
Before me stands I see, and start
To recognize my hidden heart.

Before me stands I see the sea,
Vast, murmuring eternally.
Its waves repeat a name I knew,
A rhythm lost in all I do.

It pulls with tides of silent thought,
Of chances missed and battles fought
Not with swords, but with the mind,
Where peace and war are intertwined.

The salt air stings, the gulls cry low,
As secrets only oceans know
Rise in foam and fall away—
Before me stands I see, and stay.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see, a shadow shaped like me,
A silhouette of moments lost beneath the sea.
It wears my face but speaks in echoes,
Whispers of choices I refused to follow.
Its eyes hold storms I never faced,
Dreams I folded, time erased.
Yet in its gaze, a kindred light—
A soul that stumbled, still stood upright.
We do not speak, but understand,
The weight of life in shifting sand.
One step forward, I break the line,
And merge with that reflection divine.
No longer two, but one made whole,
Before me stands I see—the end, the goal.

Before me stands I see, a door of glass and sky,
A threshold where my breath and silence lie.
The world behind me fades to gray,
While colors bloom where I delay.
I reach a hand, it reaches too,
A mirror forged from morning dew.
But when I blink, the image shifts—
A version of me the current lifts.
One who danced where I stood still,
Who climbed the hill I feared to will.
Still, no regret, no shame, no blame,
Just quiet awe at different flame.
Before me stands I see, not ghost nor foe,
But possibility in softest glow.

Before me stands I see, a tree with roots in air,
Branches buried deep in prayer.
Leaves fall upward into night,
Stars bloom blossoms, soft and white.
A paradox in silent stance,
Time unwound in one long dance.
I question not the strange design,
But taste the nectar of the vine
That spirals round what should be ground,
Where lost and found are homeward bound.
Before me stands I see, and knows,
The truth that no one dares disclose:
That I am not who I began,
But who I meet beyond the man.

Before me stands I see, a clock without a face,
Hands dissolved in time and space.
No numbers mark the hours gone,
Just humming silence, dusk to dawn.
I try to speak, but sound takes flight,
Transformed to color, shaped by light.
Each pulse becomes a painted stair,
Ascending into thinning air.
And there, at steps I didn’t climb,
A version of me in stolen rhyme.
We nod, as those who know the cost,
Of all the things we almost lost.
Before me stands I see, and waits,
The self I’ll meet beyond the gates.

Before me stands I see, a flame without a spark,
A quiet blaze inside the dark.
It casts no shadow, makes no sound,
Yet warms the frost upon the ground.
I wonder if it knows my name,
Or if it burns with different flame.
It flickers once, a knowing wink—
A soul that walked a steeper brink.
We share the air, but not the past,
Though both of us were forged to last.
Before me stands I see, and though
We walk alone, we’re one and so.
A mirror not of glass or steel,
But of the truth that time reveals.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see, a shadow carved from time,
A figure draped in echoes, bearing silence as a rhyme.
Not ghost, nor dream, but something in between—
A self once lost within the in-between.

The eyes I meet are mine, yet strangely worn,
As if by years of sorrow newly born.
Each breath a bridge across forgotten years,
Each glance a flood of unshed, salted tears.

I reach, but touch no flesh—only the air,
A phantom woven from my deepest care.
Was this the path I chose, or one I fled?
The life I lived, or one left for the dead?

Before me stands I see, and cannot speak,
For words would break the spell, or make it weak.
And so we stand, two souls in single frame,
One shaped by fire, one by silent flame.

A mirror shows not glass, but what's concealed—
The truth we bury, yet is never healed.
Before me stands I see, and now I know:
To face oneself is both the wound and glow.

Before me stands I see a door ajar,
A silhouette against a distant star.
No face defined, yet known in every line,
A version of a life that might have been mine.

The air is thick with choices left behind,
With roads untraveled and unvoiced lines.
A whisper rises, soft yet unbearably loud—
"You could have been this, but you chose the cloud."

I step closer, not in fear but grace,
Meeting the self I never let take place.
Not better, not worse—just different in form,
A life shaped by storm, not by norm.

Before me stands I see, and we exchange
A look that holds no blame, no strange demand.
Just understanding, deep and slow:
We are both real. We both still grow.

And though I turn and walk away,
I carry him—the might-have-been—today.
For every path not taken still remains,
Not in regret, but in the heart’s soft stains.

Before me stands I see a glassy sheen,
A ripple in the world, a fractured scene.
My form reflected, yet not quite aligned—
A self displaced, by fate or mind.

The ground beneath us neither here nor there,
A threshold stretched on trembling air.
No words are spoken, yet the silence sings
Of buried hopes and muted wings.

I wonder if it's me, or some disguise—
A borrowed shape beneath these skies.
Or maybe I am the illusion here,
And he’s the truth, both far and near.

We mirror gestures, slow and deep,
Like tides that rise while others sleep.
A dance of seconds, perfectly in time,
Two beats of one enduring chime.

Before me stands I see, and do not flee.
I nod, and he nods back at me.
No need for names, no need to explain—
We share the same unspoken pain.

And when the vision fades into the mist,
I know I’m not the only one who’s missed
The chance to be, the will to stay—
Before me stands I see… and walks away.

Before me stands I see a child with dirt on hands,
Smiling wide with no demands.
Barefoot on a sunlit floor,
Laughing at a world he knows no war.

But time has bent, and I am here—
A man shaped by doubt and fear.
Yet in his eyes, so bright and clear,
I glimpse the one I used to revere.

He doesn’t flinch, he doesn’t hide,
He greets me like an old, dear guide.
"I’ve waited long," his silence says,
"To see you now, to clear the haze."

Before me stands I see my core,
Not broken, not behind a door.
Just pure, unshaped, and unaware
Of all the weight I’ve learned to bear.

And though I cannot stay, nor kneel,
I whisper thanks—he knows how real.
For in that glance, so soft and true,
I find the self I thought I’d lose.

Before me stands I see, and smiles,
And for a breath, my heart revives.

Before me stands I see a tree—
Its roots run deep, its branches free.
Not wood and leaf, but blood and bone,
A life long grown, yet still unknown.

Its bark is lined with stories told,
Of winters harsh and summers bold.
Each knot a scar, each limb a choice,
A symphony of silent voice.

I circle slow, in quiet awe,
This self that time has shaped with law.
Not carved by hands, but by the years,
By joy and grief, by hopes and fears.

The wind stirs leaves that hum my name,
A song without a need for flame.
It speaks of growth, of standing tall,
Of weathering the fiercest squall.

Before me stands I see not face, but form,
A living truth, both wild and warm.
No judgment here, no right or wrong—
Just being, ancient, deep, and strong.

And as I merge into its shade,
No longer lost, no longer afraid,
I breathe as one with root and sky—
Before me stands I see… and sigh.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see, a shadow tall and deep,
A silhouette of echoes where my promises still sleep.
Not stranger, not a phantom, but a self I’ve left behind,
With eyes that hold the storms I’ve weathered, and the peace I’ve failed to find.

It wears the scars I never named, the grief I called strength,
And speaks in quiet syllables the years have stretched to length.
Its hands are cracked with labor, yet they cradle gentle light,
As if forgiveness grows in wounds where silence used to bite.

I ask, "Who are you, mirror, in this uninvited frame?"
It answers not in language, but in breath that bears my name.
A lifetime folded into posture, memory in stance,
The future and the past now locked in one long, quiet dance.

Before me stands I see—not ghost, nor dream, nor lie—
But all I was, and am, and shall be, wearing my own sky.

Before me stands I see a door ajar in mist,
A breath between two worlds where memory persists.
Not quite reflection, not a vision, but a hum,
The sound of self unraveling, the drumbeat of what's come.

It does not speak in sentences, but glances, faint and low,
A flicker in the corner where forgotten feelings grow.
Like footprints in the attic, like letters left unsent,
It carries all the versions that my soul has ever meant.

I reach, but do not touch it; the space is thick with time,
With choices turned to rivers and rhythms lost to rhyme.
Yet in its quiet posture, a kinship starts to bloom—
A recognition deeper than the shelter of a room.

Before me stands I see the echo of my tread,
The me that walks beside me, though I thought I walked ahead.

Before me stands I see a tree with roots in sky,
Its leaves are made of letters from the letters I let die.
Each branch a different pathway where I almost chose to stay,
Now whispering in breezes what I never had the say.

Its bark is etched with laughter, with tears I locked away,
A living archive pulsing at the breaking edge of day.
It does not judge my absence, nor demand I make amends—
It simply is, unblinking, as the present softly bends.

I wonder if it waters on the rain I never cried,
If in its rings, my sorrows are preserved, not petrified.
Before me stands I see not man, nor ghost, nor muse,
But time made flesh in foliage, wearing all my hues.

Before me stands I see a clock with hands that do not move,
A moment crystallized in air, a pause I can't disprove.
Its face is mine, yet altered—softer lines, a different gaze—
As if the world continued on a different, unseen phase.

The seconds sleep like sparrows in the eaves of yesterday,
And in its silent ticking, I forget which way I stray.
This figure made of stillness wears the clothes I might have worn,
In lives that slipped like sand through fingers clenched and torn.

It does not speak, but knows me—knows the dreams I shelved in drawers,
The love I let go quiet, the truth behind closed doors.
Before me stands I see the ghost of paths I didn’t take,
A mirror of the maybe, for the soul’s own sake.

Before me stands I see a flame that casts no shadow near,
A quiet, constant burning, untouched by wind or fear.
It flickers not in motion, but in depth, a steady glow,
Revealing layers underneath the skin I think I know.

This fire does not consume, but clarifies the dark,
Illuminating corners where I’ve left my quiet mark.
Not pride, nor shame, but presence—naked, raw, and true—
A version stripped of armor, speaking without a cue.

It breathes the air of honesty, where masks are shed like skin,
And in its gentle radiance, I let my walls give in.
Before me stands I see the core no time can steal—
The self that waits in silence, patient, warm, and real.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see, a shadow carved in light,
A silhouette of who I was, and who I might become.
Reflections ripple on a glassy stream,
Whispering secrets only silence knows.

The wind does not speak, yet it carries my name,
Through hollow trees and forgotten stones.
Each step I take, my echo walks ahead,
A phantom wearing my face, leading the way.

Before me stands I see—no stranger, no foe,
But the sum of every choice I’ve left behind.
A mirror forged not by silver, but by time,
Holding eyes that have seen too much and still wait.

I reach out, trembling, not to touch, but to understand,
How one soul can stretch across so many years.
And in that gaze, both distant and near,
I find the courage to meet myself halfway.

Before me stands I see a door ajar,
Lit by moonlight spilling through cracked walls.
No handle, no key, just breathless air
And the scent of old books and distant rain.

I do not knock. I do not enter.
Instead, I watch the shadow dance,
A figure shaped like me, yet freer,
Moving without weight, without chains.

It sings a song I almost recall,
From childhood dreams or half-remembered prayers.
A melody stitched with sorrow and gold,
That tugs at the seams of my careful disguise.

Before me stands I see not flesh, but truth,
Not a man, but the ghost of his becoming.
And though I tremble, I do not turn away,
For to flee is to lose myself again.

Before me stands I see a tree,
Rooted deep in the soil of yesteryears.
Its bark etched with names I once called mine,
Leaves trembling with unspoken fears.

Branches stretch toward a clouded sky,
Not in plea, but in quiet defiance.
Each limb a path I chose or denied,
A life lived, or one left in silence.

Birds nest in the crooks of memory,
Singing lullabies of loss and grace.
Their wings beat in rhythm with my pulse,
A symphony of time and space.

Before me stands I see not just wood,
But the forest I’ve grown with every breath.
And though storms have bent me nearly broken,
I stand—alive, aware, and undenied.

Before me stands I see a flame,
Flickering in the hollow of night.
Not born of match or wick or name,
But kindled from an inner light.

It dances with a knowing gaze,
Reflecting all I’ve tried to hide—
Regrets like smoke, hopes in blaze,
Moments lost, and love denied.

I do not fear its hungry glow,
For it burns not to erase,
But to reveal what lies below,
The self beneath the mask and face.

Before me stands I see the fire,
Not to judge, nor to consume,
But to warm the soul’s desire,
And guide me through the gathering gloom.

Before me stands I see a stone,
Weathered smooth by tides of years.
No grandeur, no throne, no mournful moan,
Just quiet strength that knows no fears.

It bears the marks of wind and rain,
Of footsteps passed and hands that fell.
Yet it does not break, does not complain,
Holding its place in silent spell.

Moss creeps gently up its side,
A green embrace of tender time.
Even in stillness, it does provide
A kind of rhythm, slow and prime.

Before me stands I see not rock, but soul,
Worn yet unwavering, tried yet true.
And in its calm, I feel made whole,
An ancient peace reflected in me, too.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see a shadow tall,
A silhouette etched upon the wall,
Not cast by light, but by time’s deep stain,
A ghost of choices made in joy and pain.
It wears my face, yet speaks no name,
Whispers in echoes, not quite the same.
Its eyes hold storms I’ve never confessed,
Dreams buried deep in silence and stress.
I reach to touch, but the air turns thin,
As if memory dissolves from within.
This figure, this mirror, this strange refrain—
Before me stands I see… myself again.
Not as I am, but as I have been,
And as I might be, worn thin by sin.
A thousand lives in one form appear,
Fragments of love, of loss, of fear.
Yet in its gaze, a quiet grace,
A hand held out through time and space.
Before me stands I see, at last,
Not future bright nor shadows past,
But now—the breath, the heart, the spark—
A soul alight against the dark.

Before me stands I see a door of glass,
Reflecting not the now, but what may pass.
A figure shaped like me, yet undefined,
As though the future’s still reluctant, blind.
It reaches out, but does not speak,
A version born from courage, not from weak.
I wonder if it knows the path I’ll take,
Or if it waits, for my own soul’s sake.
The air between us hums with quiet might,
A bridge of seconds stretching into night.
Before me stands I see a silent plea—
Become the self you’re meant to be.
Not flawless, not without a scar,
But bold enough to wander, near or far.
I step ahead, the glass begins to fade,
No longer bound by doubt’s charade.
For in that glance, that moment’s spark,
Before me stands I see… my own true mark.

Before me stands I see a tree grown old,
Its bark inscribed with stories never told.
Roots tangled deep in soil of regret,
Branches stretched toward a sun not met.
Leaves whisper names I once called mine—
Lover, believer, runaway, liar, shrine.
Each ring a year I thought I’d lost,
Each knot a cost, a victory, a cost.
A bird alights upon a crooked limb,
Sings a tune both foreign and grim.
It sings of roads that split and bend,
Of how the broken still can mend.
Before me stands I see not just decay,
But life that fights its way through gray.
Sap still runs, though slow and deep,
And secrets that the roots will keep.
This tree, this self, this weathered face—
Holds quiet strength, enduring grace.
Before me stands I see, and understand:
I am not finished. I am land.

Before me stands I see a fractured pane,
A hundred shards, each showing different rain.
One has me laughing in a summer field,
Another weeps where no one else can see.
One dances barefoot on a city street,
One kneels in prayer with tired, calloused feet.
Each version breathes, each lives apart,
Yet all are stitched into this single heart.
I try to merge them, make them whole,
But wholeness isn’t found in being whole.
Before me stands I see the truth at last:
To be is not to fit, but to hold fast—
To joy and grief, to rise and fall,
To answer neither rise nor fall.
This mosaic, cracked and incomplete,
Is more alive than perfect, neat.
Before me stands I see, with quiet pride:
I am not one. I am multiplied.

Before me stands I see a flame,
Not roaring loud, but whispering my name.
It flickers low, as if afraid,
Of shadows cast or debts unpaid.
Yet in its glow, a color bright—
A stubborn hue of inner light.
It does not warm, it does not guide,
But simply burns with quiet pride.
No grand display, no leap, no spark,
Just presence felt within the dark.
Before me stands I see a spark,
Not born of joy, nor lit in dark,
But kindled long in silent years,
Through doubt and loss, through hope and fears.
It asks no praise, it seeks no end,
It simply is—my truest friend.
And though the wind may howl and sigh,
Before me stands I see… I.
Not fixed, not sure, not quite defined,
But burning still. And still aligned.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

responses.text:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When moonlight drowned in a silver woe,
I wandered through the whispering trees,
That hummed with secrets carried on the breeze.

The stars were veiled, as if in fear,
Of shadows creeping ever near,
And in the hush, a raven cried,
A mournful sound the wind belied.

I passed a gate of rusted iron,
Where silence grew, and hope was torn,
And deep within that garden old,
A story of love and sorrow told.

A woman stood in a tattered gown,
Her eyes like embers falling down,
She sang of a vow beneath the oak,
And a heart that time could never broke.

The night has fled, the years have flown,
But still her song in me is known.
Though decades pass, I feel it true—
That dark, dark night still speaks to you.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I watched the embers of a fire glow,
Not with warmth, but a ghostly hue,
As if the flames remembered you.

The clock had stopped at half past three,
And silence pressed like a heavy sea.
No crickets sang, no owls took flight,
Just the echo of a lost soul's plight.

I climbed the stairs, each creak a name,
Whispered in guilt, soaked in shame.
At the top, a mirror cracked in two,
Reflecting all I’d never do.

The past stood there, not in disguise,
With my own face and sorrowed eyes.
It said, 'You left what you should keep—
The love, the trust, the dreams, the sleep.'

Now every year, when winds blow low,
And shadows stretch where no lights go,
I feel that night—its weight, its woe—
One dark, dark night… so long ago.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When time slipped loose and let dreams go.
I walked a path of fallen leaves,
Beneath the hush that twilight weaves.

The air was thick with unspoken words,
Like songs unsung, like love deferred.
A lantern flickered in a distant shed,
Where memories sleep and the restless tread.

I met a child with eyes so wide,
Holding a key he could not hide.
'What does it open?' I softly said,
He whispered, 'The door inside your head.'

I followed him through fog and thorn,
Past fields where sorrow had been born,
Until we reached a sunken well,
Where echoes of old farewells dwell.

He dropped the key. It sank from view.
'Don’t worry,' he said, 'it was meant for you.'
Then vanished into the misty glow—
One dark, dark night… so long ago.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I heard the sea begin to growl below.
The cliffs were black, the wind was keen,
And waves like wolves gnawed at the green.

I stood alone where lovers met,
Before the war, before regret.
Her letters burned inside my coat,
Each word a knife, each line a note
Of music lost, of time undone,
Of battles fought, and battles won,
But never hers. She sailed away,
On tides of duty, not of play.

Now salt still stings upon my cheek—
Though whether sea-spray, none can speak.
The lighthouse beam cuts through the shroud,
But not enough to call her proud.

The years have turned, my hair is snow,
Yet still I watch where tides ebb low.
For one dark night—it calls me so—
One dark, dark night… so long ago.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When lanterns dimmed and rivers slowed.
I found a book beneath the floor,
With pages stained and covered in lore.

Its ink was red, though not with dye,
And every line made spirits sigh.
It spoke of kings who ruled in fear,
Of maidens lost, of years too dear.

But one tale stood, apart, alone—
A story carved in brittle bone.
It told of me, in future years,
With laughter gone and salted tears.

I slammed it shut, but not before
I saw my name on the final door.
And now I write, though time may show,
This truth I know, this truth I know:
That fate is written, soft and slow,
One dark, dark night… so long ago.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

responses.text:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
Beneath a sky where no stars dared to glow,
I wandered through a wood of twisted thorn,
Where silence wore a garment, worn and torn.

The wind did not stir, nor owl take flight,
As if the world had vanished into night.
A lantern flickered in my trembling hand,
Casting long shadows I could not understand.

Then, from the hush, a whisper rose so low,
It seemed the very earth had started to speak.
It told of love lost, of promises broken,
Of oaths turned to ash and hearts unspoken.

I followed the voice through roots and stone,
To a clearing where time had ceased to roam.
There stood a figure, cloaked and thin,
With eyes like embers buried within.

No words were said, yet I knew its name,
The ghost of who I was, consumed by flame.
We stared in silence, two halves of one soul,
Then darkness reclaimed its ancient role.

Now every year, when the moon is low,
I feel that night begin to grow.
For though it was long ago, it's never gone—
That dark, dark night still lingers on.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When candles wept and clocks moved slow,
I sat beside the attic's door,
Listening to the floorboards creak and roar.

The house, it breathed like something old,
With stories trapped in beams of cold.
A trunk lay cracked, its secrets spilled—
Yellowed letters, a locket, a child's lost smile.

I read the words in trembling hands,
Of war and ships and foreign sands.
A soldier wrote to his dearest May,
But never lived to see her again.

The wind cried out like a mourning dove,
Echoing the sorrow of unkept love.
I closed my eyes and saw the fight,
The flash of steel, the fall of night.

And then a hand—so cold, so slight—
Pressed my shoulder in the quiet night.
I turned, but nothing stood behind,
Only the past, unkind, unlined.

Now each year when shadows start to creep,
I wake to hear the old house weep.
For though it was long ago, I know,
That dark, dark night still walks below.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When frost first kissed the fields of snow,
I walked alone beside the stream,
Lost inside a fractured dream.

The water black, it barely flowed,
As if the world had let go.
Beneath the ice, a face appeared—
Pale, familiar, yet disappeared.

I called its name, but sound was gone,
Swallowed whole by the dawnless dawn.
My breath hung still, a ghostly thread,
While silence wrapped me, cold and dead.

Then from the bank, a willow sighed,
Its branches reaching far and wide.
They brushed my cheek like fingers known,
A touch from someone turned to stone.

Memories surged—our stolen walks,
Our whispered vows beneath the oaks.
But you had vanished, no trace, no clue,
And I was left with only blue.

Now every winter, when winds descend,
I feel you near, my ghostly friend.
Though long ago, you never go—
That dark, dark night still breathes below.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When thunder split the sky in two,
I stood upon the cliff's sharp edge,
Staring down at the sea's cold pledge.

The waves like wolves with teeth of foam,
Cried out for flesh, for bone, for home.
The storm had come without a sign,
Erasing stars, erasing time.

I wore a dress of silver thread,
Now soaked and heavy, clinging dead.
My hair flew wild, a storm untamed,
While guilt and grief remained unnamed.

For I had loved a sailor bold,
Whose ship was lost in waters cold.
They said he drowned, no trace, no cry,
But I still saw him in the sky.

A flash—not lightning—but his face,
In cloud and wind, in time and space.
He beckoned once, then sank from view,
And I leapt after, into blue.

They say I washed ashore next morn,
But part of me was never reborn.
For though it was long ago, I know,
That dark, dark night still drags me low.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When children feared what shadows show,
I hid beneath my quilt so tight,
Convinced that monsters ruled the night.

The hallway stretched like endless deep,
Where every creak could make you weep.
The moon hid shy behind a cloud,
And silence screamed too loud, too loud.

I heard a footfall—soft, then near—
A breath upon my childish ear.
I froze, too scared to turn and see,
What stood beside my bed for me.

But then a hand, so warm, so known,
Lifted the cloth and smoothed my own.
"It's just the wind," my mother said,
"And I am here," her voice like thread.

She sang a tune from long ago,
Of fields and lambs and soft moon glow.
The monsters fled, the shadows thinned,
And peace once more crept deep within.

Now I am grown, with children mine,
And I still walk that midnight line.
For though it was long ago, I know,
That dark, dark night still taught me so.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

responses.text:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
Beneath a sky where no stars dared to glow,
I wandered paths of whispering pine and thorn,
Where silence wore a face both worn and worn.
A lantern flickered, weak against the cold,
Its trembling light a story left untold.
The wind spoke names I’d buried deep in sleep,
And shadows danced where memories dare not creep.
I met a figure draped in velvet gloom,
Whose eyes held echoes of a vanished room.
It said no word, yet knew my secret name,
And pointed toward a hill without a flame.
I followed, not in courage, but in dread,
To where a door stood open, carved in lead.
Beyond, a garden frozen in its prime,
With roses black as sin and out of time.
And there, I saw myself—so young, so lost—
Still counting every cost, no matter the cost.
Now every night, though years have come and gone,
I hear the creak of that unyielding door.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But never leaves me, though I beg it go.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When rivers wept and willows bowed low,
I stood upon the bridge of creaking wood,
Where dreams were swallowed, never understood.
A voice arose from underneath the stone,
A lullaby in tones of blood and bone.
It sang of love that turned to frost and frost,
Of promises that counted up the cost.
I dropped a coin into the water’s keep,
And watched it sink too deep for soul to reap.
Then ripples showed a face I used to know—
My mother’s eyes, drowned in a tide of woe.
She mouthed a word, but sound refused to form,
As if the night had stolen every norm.
I reached, I screamed, but silence pulled her down,
Beneath the current’s unforgiving crown.
Now every midnight, when the world’s asleep,
I walk that bridge and whisper secrets deep.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But in my heart, the river still runs slow.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When time itself moved soft and slow,
I found a door within a hollow tree,
Carved with runes of what must never be.
No handle turned, yet it began to part,
Revealing not a room, but a fractured heart—
A landscape built from sorrow and regret,
Where suns had died and debts were never met.
Figures in cloaks of ash and ember passed,
Each bearing chains from lifetimes they amass.
They spoke in sighs, in echoes faint and thin,
Of chances lost and where they might have been.
I saw a child—my younger, hopeful self—
Still clutching dreams upon a dusty shelf.
I tried to speak, but time reversed its flow,
And slammed the door before I’d let love show.
Now every storm, when thunder shakes the ground,
I feel that pull, that ancient, hollow sound.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But still I wonder what I left below.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When moonlight drowned in rivers thick and slow,
I rowed a boat with oars of splintered bone,
Across a lake of whispers, chilled to stone.
No shore in sight, just mist and memory,
And faces rising up from deep debris.
They called my name with voices thin and worn,
Like pages torn from books long since outborn.
A crown of reeds sat heavy on my head,
A king of loss, by no one ever led.
I bore the weight of choices turned to rust,
Of loving wrong, of breaking sacred trust.
Then from the depths, a melody arose—
A lullaby my mother used to close.
It wrapped around me, warm yet full of pain,
And drowned me softly in a sweet refrain.
I let the waters take me, limb by limb,
No fight, no fear—just a requiem hymn.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But in my dreams, the currents still ebb and flow.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
Before the world began to truly know
The weight of silence, thick as winter snow,
I saw a light where no light ought to glow.
It flickered in the attic of an inn,
Where travelers vanished, never to return.
I climbed the stairs, each step a breath held tight,
Drawn by a force that drowned both day and night.
Inside, a woman sat with silver hair,
Stirring a pot beyond all reason there.
She smiled and said, “You’ve come to taste the past,
To drink what’s gone, to breathe what couldn’t last.”
She poured a cup of smoke and shadowed wine,
And as I drank, I saw each stolen sign—
My father’s laugh before the war took him,
My sister’s song the night the roof gave in.
I wept, I begged to stay within that room,
But dawn arrived too soon, too harsh, too doomed.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But still I search for that inn in the snow.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

responses.text:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
Beneath a sky where no stars dared to glow,
I wandered through a wood of twisted boughs,
Where silence wore a crown of broken vows.

The wind, a whisper laced with ancient pain,
Spoke names I’d buried deep in soil and rain.
Each step I took a memory unspooled—
A lover’s laugh, a child that was not cooled.

A lantern flickered in the hollow far,
Its glow a wound, a solitary scar.
I moved toward it, drawn by ghostly thread,
To find a figure standing, bowed and dead.

Yet when I reached, no body met my hand—
Only a mirror, cracked and close at hand.
And in it, eyes I’d lost to time’s cruel flow
Stared back, and whispered, "This is where you go."

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But still it lives where all lost things must grow.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When time stood still beneath a breathless sky,
I met a shadow wearing human woe,
With hollow eyes and sorrow drawn nearby.

We spoke no words, yet shared a thousand years,
Of wars unwon and dreams that turned to dust,
Of lovers lost to unforgiving tears,
And hope dissolved in silence and mistrust.

The moon, a shard, hung low above the hill,
Its light too weak to pierce the forest gloom.
Yet in that dark, a quiet warmth stood still—
A single candle blooming in the tomb.

Not all was lost. Not all had turned to shade.
For love once lit, can never quite be stayed.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But in my heart, its embers still now glow.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I walked a shore where tides refused to flow.
The sea was black, the air thick with regret,
And every wave a memory I’d not forget.

Footprints I made were swallowed by the sand,
As if the world erased me where I stand.
Then out upon the water, far and dim,
A lantern rose, not borne by boat or limb.

It floated slow, with purpose all its own,
And as it neared, a voice came, soft as stone:
"You asked for truth when youth still lit your face,
Now come, and see the cost of such a grace."

The light revealed a ship with sails of ash,
Its deck lined deep with echoes of my past.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But time, it seems, is never truly slow.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I found a door where no door should have been.
It stood in fields I’d known since long ago,
Of golden wheat and skies of softest green.

But now the crops were gone, the earth turned gray,
And ivy clung like fingers grasping bone.
The door was old, of oak and iron gray,
With symbols carved in tongues I’d never known.

I pushed it wide. Beyond, a hall stretched far,
Lit by the glow of candles without flame.
Portraits there of people I once were,
Each face a life I never played the same.

A clock upon the wall had stopped at three,
The hour, I recalled, she left for good.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
And still I wander where I never should.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I heard a song from hills I couldn’t see.
The notes were low, like winds that mourn and go,
A lullaby meant only for me.

No instrument, no voice—just air that sighed,
And yet the melody clung to my chest,
A tune that pulled the tears I’d long denied,
And laid them bare, like bones stripped by the west.

I followed it through brambles sharp and deep,
Through ruins where the ivy wore a crown,
Until I came to where the song would sleep—
A well, its mouth sealed with a mossy stone.

I dared not lift it. Knew what lay below:
The voice, the tune, the self I used to know.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

responses.text:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
Beneath a sky where no stars dared glow,
I wandered paths of moss and thorn,
Where silence wore a face of scorn.

The wind, a whisperer full of dread,
Spoke names of those the world had fled.
An owl cried once—a hollow sound—
As if the earth had cracked and drowned.

I passed a cottage, low and old,
Its timbers bent, its story untold.
A candle flickered, frail and thin,
Like hope about to give up within.

A shadow crossed the windowpane—
Not mine, though still I felt the stain.
And from within, a lullaby,
Sung low, as if to make death sigh.

I do not know why I recall
That night, that house, that spectral call.
But still, when darkness wraps me tight,
I feel that tune—the same, that night.

And though years have bled into the past,
That moment holds me, firm, steadfast.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
And yet, it lives. I know. I know.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When rivers froze beneath a breathless sky,
And time itself seemed caught in frozen flow,
As moonless shadows taught the crows to cry.

I walked a field where once a village stood,
Now swallowed by the hunger of the fen.
The earth was soft, as if it understood
The weight of ghosts who'd walked there now and then.

A voice arose—not loud, but deep and near—
Reciting names no history has kept.
Each syllable a wound, each pause a tear,
The kind of truth the living must have wept.

I turned to flee, but roots had gripped my feet.
The voice grew kind, as if it meant no harm.
It spoke of love, of loss, of lives complete,
And sang a song that bore no title, form, or name.

When dawn arrived, I stood upon a hill,
With no recall of how I’d gotten there.
But in my coat, a feather—cold and still—
And in my heart, a silence thick as prayer.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
Yet in my bones, the memory will grow.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I found a door where no house should appear.
It stood alone in snow that fell too slow,
And creaked as if it knew I’d come this year.

No handle, yet it opened at a sigh,
Revealing stairs that spiraled into stone.
I stepped inside, though reason begged me fly,
Drawn by a murmur from the undergrown.

The walls were lined with clocks, all stopped at three,
Each face reflecting eyes that weren’t my own.
A child’s voice sang a half-remembered plea:
"Don’t leave me here, I’m not quite dead—just alone."

I climbed the stairs, though every step was dread,
Until I reached a room with just one chair.
There sat myself—ten years gone, unsaid—
We stared, and neither spoke, for both knew the air.

Then light cracked through, and all had disappeared.
No door, no snow, no clocks, no song, no fear.
But sometimes, when the world has disappeared,
I hear that voice—still waiting, still so near.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
And yet it lives in every dream I know.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I rowed a boat across a glassy mere.
The oars were muffled, moving soft and slow,
And all the world was hushed, devoid of fear.

No moon, no stars, yet something lit the way—
A pale glow rising from the water’s skin.
It showed the reeds, the banks, the disarray
Of dreams abandoned, sinking deep within.

I saw a figure standing on the shore,
Cloaked, motionless, with eyes like dying coal.
It raised one hand, but asked for nothing more
Than just my shadow as I passed the shoal.

I gave it freely—what was shadow worth
When body and breath still warmed my skin?
But when I reached the other side of earth,
I found I’d lost the power to let love in.

No face could stir me, no hand could hold,
For shadows house the soul’s true shape.
And though I’ve lived a hundred lives, grown old,
I miss that part I gave to escape.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
And still the water waits. I know.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I danced beneath a willow, bent and bare.
The music came from somewhere down below,
A fiddle played by fingers not quite there.

The air was thick with lilacs out of time,
And partners turned in gowns of silver mist.
No face I knew, yet all felt like a rhyme
From some old ballad I had once been kissed by.

We spun and stepped as centuries collapsed,
Our feet not touching ground, but riding air.
I laughed until my ribs began to crack,
And tasted blood, yet kept on dancing there.

Then silence—sharp, like glass across the skin.
The fiddle broke, the willow wept and sighed.
A voice said, "You may never dance again,
For joy like this is never twice supplied."

I woke in dew, my clothes still damp with sweat,
No trace of music, partners, or the tree.
But when the wind moves certain ways, I get
A shiver—like a step I used to be.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
And still I ache to waltz with what I know.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

responses.text:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
Beneath a sky where no stars dared to glow,
I wandered through a wood of whispering trees,
Their branches clawing at the moaning breeze.
A lantern flickered in my trembling hand,
Its pale light drawn by some unseen command.
Footsteps echoed, though I walked alone,
And in the silence, I was never shown
The face behind the breath upon my neck,
Or why the shadows started to reflect
Not me—but someone cloaked and tall and thin,
With hollow eyes that pulled me deep within.
I woke at dawn upon the forest floor,
With moss upon my lips and thorns for more.
No trace of path, no sign of where I’d been,
But still I hear the voice: 'Come back again.'

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When laughter died and embers ceased to glow.
A child tucked tight beneath a quilted sky,
Dreamt not of love, but of a lullaby
That slithered through the cracks beneath the door,
A tune half-remembered, never heard before.
It sang of oceans drowned beneath the land,
Of clocks that ran with backward-sanded hands.
The wind replied in syllables of frost,
And time, unknotted, paid its heavy cost.
I woke with tears like diamonds on my cheek,
The morning sun too bright, too bold, too weak
To burn away the chill that still remains,
When memory hums that song through sudden rains.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I watched the moon dissolve in yellow snow.
The streets were made of breath and broken glass,
And every shadow wore a human face.
A clock struck thirteen—no one dared to flinch,
We danced in silence, never missing lunch
Though none had eaten in a hundred years.
Our eyes held galaxies of frozen tears.
We knew the world had ended, soft and slow,
Yet still we bowed and kissed the undertow.
And when the dawn came cloaked in ashen light,
We vanished—not a soul remained in sight.
Now only echoes hum beneath the eaves,
Of how we lived, and died, and wouldn’t leave.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I found a door where no door meant to go.
It stood in a field of ash and thistle bloom,
Lit by the ghost of a dead man’s moon.
I turned the knob—no sound, no creak, no fear—
And stepped into a room that wasn’t there.
A chair faced west, a letter on the seat,
In my own hand, but sealed with bitter heat.
It read: 'You left yourself behind that year.'
I wept, for every truth was written clear.
Now I return each night, though time has flown,
To sit and wait for me—to claim the throne
Of absence, where the lost are most at home,
And no one ever truly leaves, or comes.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I followed footsteps only I could know.
They led me down a lane of rusted wire,
Beneath a sky of slowly dying fire.
Each step I took, the past grew more alive:
A mother’s voice, a kiss, a lost man’s dive
Into the river where his sorrows drowned.
I saw it all—no sight, no sound, just found.
The air grew thick with names I’d sworn to keep,
And love that rusted shut like ancient sleep.
I reached the end—there was no end to find—
Only the echo of my own left behind.
Now every night, the darkness starts to call,
And I must walk the lane—or risk it all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a tongue of gold that licks the sky,
Dancing wild where shadows flee.
It hums in silence, breathes a sigh,
A waltz of ash and energy.
Born from spark, it climbs the night,
A beacon fierce, a lover’s flame.
It warms the hands, consumes the light,
And whispers secrets without name.
In hearths it cradles ancient dreams,
In forests, rages like a beast.
It glows in hearts, in lovers’ schemes,
And grants both comfort and the feast.
Oh fire, fleeting, fierce, and bright,
You mark the edge of dark and dawn.
You burn the wrong and bless the right,
A paradox that presses on.
From candle’s glow to sun’s great pyre,
You are both ruin and desire.

Fire: a pulse beneath the skin of night,
A flicker that defies the cold.
It paints the walls with amber light,
A story in colors bold.
Not just destruction, not just heat,
But memory wrapped in flame—
The scent of pine on summer streets,
The voice that called a hidden name.
It leaps in laughter, crackles low,
A rhythm only hearts can hear.
It guards the past we used to know,
And burns away what brought the fear.
In every spark, a soul takes flight,
A phoenix born from embered breath.
Fire is both the wrong and right,
The quiet kiss, the dance with death.
So let it burn, let shadows fall,
For in its glow, we see it all.

Fire: the first word spoken into void,
The shout that split the silent air.
It crawled from stone, was slowly deployed,
A gift too bright, too bold, too rare.
It forged the plow, it lit the page,
It turned the night to working day.
Yet in its heart, a hunger grew—
A beast that feasts on all we knew.
From campfires where the hunters prayed,
To cities lost in orange shade,
It serves, it saves, it takes, it kills,
A force that bends to human wills.
Oh fire, mirror of our soul,
Both kindled hope and scorched control,
You rise, you rage, you fade, you cease,
A fleeting god that brings us peace.

Fire: a flicker in the hollow dark,
A spark that dares to disobey.
It curls like smoke, leaves its mark,
Then vanishes in disarray.
Not always roaring, not always grand,
Sometimes just a trembling glow—
The steady beat of a trembling hand,
A single light where no lights go.
It warms the soup, it chars the bread,
It catches sleeve or paper edge.
It dances on the overhead,
A fleeting guest, a passing pledge.
And when it dies, it leaves behind
A scent of loss, a trace of grace,
The ghost of heat within the mind,
The memory of a warm embrace.
Fire: brief, bright, and bittersweet,
The pulse beneath the world’s heartbeat.

Fire: the blush across the eastern rim,
The sun that spills its molten core.
It starts with spark, then swells to hymn,
A roar behind a trembling door.
It paints the clouds in crimson fear,
It gilds the trees with fleeting gold.
It draws the deer, dispels the deer,
A force both gentle and untold.
In temples, it is bowed to, fed,
With oils, with prayers, with silent breath.
In war, it sings above the dead,
A harbinger of pain and death.
Yet in the end, when flames subside,
Beneath the ash, new green appears.
From every loss, new life will ride—
Fire destroys, yet also steers.
So praise its power, dread its might,
For fire births both day and night.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a tongue of gold that licks the sky,
Devouring night with ravenous grace.
It dances wild where shadows lie,
A fleeting god no hands can brace.
It sings in crackles, low and deep,
A lullaby of ancient breath,
While embers spiral into sleep,
And ash becomes the dust of death.
Yet in its glow, a promise gleams—
Not just the end, but birth anew.
For forests fall to feed the dreams
Of green that climbs on charcoal's hue.
So fear its rage, but honor flame,
That both destroys and lights the frame.

Fire: the whisper in the hearth’s soft core,
Where shadows gather, lean, and sigh.
A keeper of secrets, asking no more
Than silence beneath a smoke-blue sky.
It curls like a cat on winter’s edge,
Warms the bones of weary souls,
And paints the walls with stories pledged
In flickers, flames, and fading coals.
It speaks of home, of bread, of kin,
Of laughter spun from ember-light.
But turn away, and it begins—
A hunger sharp, a sudden blight.
So tend it well, this gift we hold,
A tale of warmth and tales untold.

Fire: a spark that splits the dark,
A rebel cry from flint and steel.
It races fast through sleeping bark,
A force no mortal can conceal.
It paints the clouds in orange dread,
Commands the wind to fan its pride,
Leaves cities kneeling, charred and dead,
With only smoke as place to hide.
Yet soldiers warm their trembling hands
Beside its glow on frozen ground,
And poets trace its shifting brands
To find the words that must be found.
Oh, fire—both tyrant and ally,
You burn the world, yet teach us why.

Fire: the pulse beneath the sun,
The core that turns the planet’s wheel.
It births the stars, outshines the one,
And makes the molten mountains kneel.
It flows in veins we cannot see,
In passion, rage, and love’s first spark,
A force that sets the spirit free,
That lights the way through endless dark.
It does not care for right or wrong,
It simply is—a primal call.
It writes its name in ancient song,
And answers none, destroys them all.
So stand in awe, but do not trust—
This flame that gives, and takes like dust.

Fire: a match struck on a wall,
A sudden bloom of fleeting light.
It trembles, then begins to crawl,
A tiny sun that dares the night.
It warms the cup, it chars the meat,
It curls the page, it seals the fate.
One breath can kill it, soft and sweet,
Or fan it into wrathful state.
It flickers once, then fades to gray—
A memory in the cooling air.
But in its wake, we softly say
The things we dared not when it’s there.
For fire listens, never speaks,
And guards the truth our silence keeps.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a tongue of gold in the throat of night,
Licking shadows from the walls of the world.
It hums in the hearth like an old lullaby,
A pulse beneath the skin of winter’s hold.
Once, we gathered close, faces glowing,
Telling tales of gods and wolves and stars.
Now, it flickers in distant screens,
A coded spark behind glass and steel.
Yet still, when storms cut the power lines,
We huddle again around candlelight,
Our eyes remembering what warmth means.
Fire: not just destruction, but communion—
The breath that binds us to ember and bone,
The quiet flame that refuses to die,
Even when the wind howls its coldest lie.

Fire: a whisper that becomes a scream,
Igniting the hush between breath and breath.
It dances on matchstick altars,
Devouring oxygen like a starving god.
Ash falls like snow on forgotten letters,
Love notes, regrets, the names of the lost.
In its light, time bends and blackens,
Moments charred into memory’s crust.
We are drawn to it—hands outstretched,
Seeking both pain and salvation.
Fire: the first tool, the final judge,
A lover that burns as it gives,
A mirror that shows us glowing from within,
Then turns us to dust, unflinching.

Fire: a red eye in the dark woods,
Watching, waiting, hungry.
It leaps from branch to branch,
A wild thing with no master.
Smoke writes obituaries in the sky,
While roots weep beneath the soil.
But in the clearing, a different fire—
Small, tended, singing with soup and stories.
Here, hands pass bread, not blame.
Fire: both executioner and healer,
A paradox wrapped in flame.
It reminds us that to live,
We must consume, must burn,
But also gather, share, and return.

Fire: the first word the world ever spoke,
A syllable of light in the void.
It forged mountains, cracked open skies,
Danced in the veins of molten earth.
Then came hands to cup its power,
To cook, to craft, to keep the night at bay.
Now it lives in engines, wires, bombs—
A caged fury we pretend to control.
But sometimes, in a backyard pit,
Or a campsite beneath pines,
We whisper to it again, softly,
Remembering we are not its master,
But kin to the spark, the flash, the flare.

Fire: a secret we stole from the sun,
And tried to hide in boxes.
But it escapes—through vents, through rage,
Through the cigarette trembling in midnight hands.
It paints the sky orange over cities,
And glows in the eyes of revolution.
We fear it, feed it, flee from it,
Yet kneel before its altar each winter.
Fire: the keeper of stories,
The destroyer of homes,
The heartbeat beneath skin when two bodies meet.
It does not care what we name it—
It burns. It lives. It remembers.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a whisper in the dark, 
A spark that dares the night to hush. 
It licks the air with golden tongues, 
And sings a hymn no wind can crush. 

It dances on forgotten logs, 
A waltz of ember, ash, and breath, 
Each flicker writes a secret oath 
Between the cold and fiery death. 

It warms the hands of weary souls, 
Yet brands the skin that draws too near. 
A lover’s kiss, a tyrant’s toll—
Both comfort and the thing we fear. 

It feeds on silence, feeds on pine, 
On memories stacked like brittle bone. 
It climbs the sky in red design, 
And turns the forest into stone. 

O fire, you are not merely flame, 
But time unspooling in a wick—
A fragile, fierce, eternal name 
That burns, and burns, and will not quit.

Fire: a word that cracks the air, 
A pulse beneath the frozen ground. 
It stirs the roots of ancient trees 
And wakes the sleeping thunder’s sound. 

In caves of time, it first was drawn 
From stone on stone, a desperate plea—
Now it flickers on every lawn, 
In candles lit for memory. 

It shapes the iron, melts the glass, 
Turns ore to tools and sand to light. 
It warms the bread, it seals the pass, 
It guards the world from endless night. 

But oh, when fury finds its breath, 
It leaps with jaws of orange flame, 
Devours homes, defies all death, 
And whispers every builder’s name. 

We kneel before it, both in dread 
And gratitude—we are its kin. 
For in our hearts, the same spark spread: 
The will to burn, to love, to begin.

Fire: a flicker in the void, 
A rebel against the deep. 
It paints the walls where shadows toyed, 
And makes the hidden secrets leap. 

It curls like smoke from yesteryear, 
From letters burned, from love once bright. 
It feeds on what we held most dear, 
And glows with stolen, ghostly light. 

It crackles low, a lullaby 
For those who’ve lost and still remain. 
It lifts its voice to starless sky, 
A mourner wrapped in golden chain. 

We gather round its fragile blaze, 
Our faces touched by amber grace. 
It tells no lies, it knows no praise—
Just warmth, and time, and quiet space. 

And when it fades to ashen sleep, 
We feel the chill of truth descend. 
For fire does not promise keep—
It gives, then goes, and calls no end.

Fire: a shout in silent snow, 
A red revolt against the white. 
It leaps and lunges, bold and low, 
A beast unchained from endless night. 

It scars the earth with molten veins, 
And paints the clouds with breath of dread. 
It dances through abandoned lanes, 
Where once the living bowed their head. 

It forged the sword, it broke the chain, 
It lit the scroll, it warmed the cave. 
It burns the field to grow again, 
A killer and a savior, brave. 

It flickers in the smoker’s hand, 
In birthday cakes, in campfire tales. 
It guards the coast, it marks the land, 
It rides the rocket through the gales. 

O fire, neither good nor ill—
You are the force that will not bend. 
You are the spark, the flame, the will, 
The start, the end, the means, the friend.

Fire: a syllable of heat, 
A tongue that speaks without a sound. 
It pulses where the cold and beat 
Of winter’s heart is most profound. 

It curls in irons, twists in wires, 
Flows through the veins of engines’ dreams. 
It fuels the stars, inspires 
The poet’s mind, the lover’s schemes. 

It burns the stubble, clears the way 
For green to rise from blackened ground. 
It takes the old, the worn, the gray, 
And turns destruction into crown. 

We fear its rage, its wild release, 
Its hunger that no water quells. 
Yet in its glow, we find our peace, 
Our stories told, our spirits swell. 

So light the match, let embers fly—
For fire is not just flame and fall. 
It is the question, and the why, 
The rise, the fall, the heart of all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire: a tongue of gold licks the night,
Crimson whispers dance in delight.
It hums through ash and shadowed pine,
A pulse, a breath, a sacred sign.
Born from friction, spark, and need,
It feeds on silence, sows the seed
Of warmth where frost once held its reign,
A fleeting god on charred terrain.
It paints the faces huddled near,
With stories only flames can hear.
But oh, beware its hungry eye—
What it adores, it dooms to die.
It gives the cookfire, forge, and light,
Yet steals the home, the starless night.
Fire: both creator and the pyre,
A fleeting blaze, a soul’s desire.

Fire: a flicker in the dark,
A sudden bloom, a living spark.
It curls like smoke from memory’s page,
Igniting youth, a bygone age.
I saw it leap from granddad’s pipe,
A tiny sun, about to thrive.
Then bonfires where we tossed the sticks,
And watched our dreams ride up in wicks
Of glowing orange, swirling high—
As if the stars leaned down to spy.
Now candlelight upon the sill
Reflects the calm my heart holds still.
Fire: not just the roar and flare,
But quiet glow in evening air,
A symbol of the soul’s own might,
That burns, endures, and turns to light.

Fire: a crackle in the void,
A language only night employs.
It speaks in tongues of orange flame,
Calling each shadow by its name.
It dances with a feral grace,
Tracing time upon my face.
No clock can mark what fire knows—
How embers fall like fading snows.
It warms the hands, but burns the mind,
With visions left too far behind.
A campfire song, a lover’s gaze,
Both born beneath its golden blaze.
Yet in its core, a warning lies:
To touch is to be compromised.
Fire: both hearth and homicide,
The turning of the world inside.

Fire: a shout in silence’s keep,
A wound that glows too bright to sleep.
It climbs the timber, swallows air,
A beast unchained, beyond repair.
No prayer can quench its ravenous need,
No river halt its forward speed.
It paints the sky in panicked red,
And writes its name above the dead.
Forests bow to its decree,

Yet from the ash, green shoots appear—
Life rising from the atmosphere.
Fire: destroyer, grim and dire,
But also midwife to the pyre

Fire: a match-strike in the brain,

It starts as itch, then sudden bloom,

Of reason. Passion, wild and raw,
