prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the morning light
Finds its way through blinds in stripes of gold,
That the coffee brews just right,
And silence hums a story yet untold.
I always see to it the books stay stacked
In crooked rows that only I can read,
That the garden path, though overgrown, tracks
A path through weeds where memories feed.
I always see to it the door stays unlocked
For shadows that return when skies turn thin,
That a candle burns when night is socked
With thunder, and the world caves in.
I always see to it love is unspoken,
But woven in the fabric of unbroken.

Not grand gestures, not loud decree,
But quiet acts that anchor me.
I always see to it, though none may know,
That the embers glow, and steady, slow.

I always see to it—the clock is wound,
The kettle sings at half past nine,
That the truth, though rarely spoken, is sound,
And the stars align in patterns divine.
I always see to it the table’s set
For one, or two, or none at all,
That regret won’t find a foothold yet,
And silence answers when I call.
I always see to it the letters burn,
Their ashes scattered where winds may go,
That lessons ache, but still I learn,
And broken things still softly glow.
I always see to it, though scars remain,
That hope is watered like a stubborn vine,
That joy returns after the rain,
And your name stays where it’s always been—
Not spoken, but never quite erased,
A whisper time could not outpace.

I always see to it the lights stay low,
That the coffee’s strong and the tea’s gone cold,
That the world outside moves too fast to know
The stories my hands have quietly told.
I always see to it the door stays clean
Of fingerprints, the bed made tight,
That the spaces between what’s seen and unseen
Hold secrets folded just right.
I always see to it the garden grows
With weeds and roses tangled as one,
That the past, though buried, still softly glows,
And the damage is never quite undone.
I always see to it, though no one asks,
That balance tilts just enough to hold,
That love wears practical, scuffed-up tasks,
And loyalty speaks in habits, not gold.
And if one day you finally see,
It’s because I always saw to it quietly.

I always see to it the sky remembers,
The moon keeps watch with its silver eye,
That December stays just short of December,
And hope flickers, though it won’t deny.
I always see to it the song repeats,
A melody hummed beneath the breath,
That defeat tastes only of temporary sweets,
And life rebuilds, even after death.
I always see to it the fire stays,
Not roaring, but a steady, hidden spark,
That sorrow walks, but never stays,
And light returns through the smallest dark.
I always see to it, not for praise,
But because the world feels less adrift
When small hands steady fragile days,
And love persists in every shift.
So when you feel a calm, unseen hand,
Know—I always see to it, and stand.

I always see to it the dishes pile,
The socks mismatch, the laundry spills,
That laughter breaks through every trial,
And nonsense cures the deepest ills.
I always see to it the dog gets fed,
The plants get water (once a week),
That dreams are shared before bed,
And flaws feel soft, not sharp or bleak.
I always see to it that hugs are long,
That 'sorry' comes before the storm,
That right and wrong aren’t cast too strong,
And warmth outlasts the coldest norm.
I always see to it, in my clumsy way,
That love feels lived, not just displayed.
For though I fumble, drop, and spill,
My heart keeps tending, calm and still.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the kettle sings at dawn,
steam curling like a promise I can’t unmake.
I light the stove, I stir the porridge slow,
trace the cracks in the bowl I still use, the one you left behind.
I always see to it: the windows wiped,
the keys in their saucer, the clock wound,
though time forgets to chime. I sweep the porch
where your shadow once pooled like oil.
I always see to it that your name
isn’t spoken, yet it hums in the floorboards,
a vibration beneath every measured step.
I water the geraniums you never liked,
just to prove I can tend what you’d have abandoned.
I always see to it that the bed is made,
even when I haven’t slept, even when
the pillow still holds the shape of your absence.
I always see to it—this ritual of silence,
this devotion to the undone.

I always see to it that the stars are counted,
one by one, like stitches in a wound that won’t close.
I name them in whispers—yours, mine, ours—
though the sky no longer listens.
I always see to it that the gate latches shut,
even when the hinges scream, even when
the wind mocks my diligence.
I always see to it that the letters remain unopened,
sealed with the dust of years, tied with fraying ribbon.
Their edges cut the air like accusations.
I always see to it that the garden grows wild,
thistles choking the roses you planted in April.
Let the bees forget their song. Let the soil sour.
I always see to it that the mirror stays covered,
so I won’t meet the ghost who wears my face.
I always see to it that the lights go out at ten,
though the dark is louder than the day.
This is my hymn: a litany of small obediences,
this hollow care, this love that outlives its object.

I always see to it that the coffee is black,
no sugar, no cream—just bitterness steeped in memory.
I always see to it that the front step is swept,
though no one comes, though the dust returns by noon.
I always see to it that your coat stays on the hook,
its pockets still holding ticket stubs and lint,
a fossil of your hurry.
I always see to it that the radio plays static,
the closest sound to your voice now.
I always see to it that the bills are paid,
the world spinning on without your hands to steady it.
I always see to it that the dog is fed,
though he whines at your empty chair each evening.
I always see to it that the truth stays buried:
that I burn one match each night for you,
that I whisper your name into the sink,
that I keep your toothbrush damp, just in case.
I always see to it—that the world believes I’m fine.

I always see to it that the door is unlocked,
just a crack, in case you find your way back
through the storm of years, the fog of forgetting.
I always see to it that the porch light burns,
though moths batter themselves against the glass,
their tiny deaths ignored.
I always see to it that your favorite cup
sits clean and waiting on the shelf,
though the shelf gathers dust, though the cup
hasn’t felt warmth in seasons.
I always see to it that the bed on your side
is turned down each night—sheets crisp, pillow fluffed—
as if sleep might lure you home.
I always see to it that the silence
is thick enough to smother questions,
that no one asks why I speak to the air,
why I set two places at the table.
I always see to it that hope is small,
but never extinguished. A pilot light
in the furnace of my chest.

I always see to it that the clock stops at 3:17,
the hour the call came, the minute the world cracked.
I wind it backward each morning, a penance.
I always see to it that the mailbox stays empty,
though I check it three times a day,
my fingers brushing the cold metal like prayer beads.
I always see to it that the photo albums stay closed,
their spines unbroken, their images locked in amber.
I always see to it that the song you loved
never plays on the radio, though I hum it
in the shower, where sound dissolves.
I always see to it that your shoes remain by the door,
laces untied, as if you just stepped out.
I always see to it that the candles are lit
on the anniversary, seven flames for seven years,
each one a vow: I remember. I remember. I remember.
I always see to it that the truth is softened—
that I say you moved away, not gone,
that I say I’m waiting, not mourning.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the kettle sings at dawn, 
the curtains drawn just so, the garden weeded. 
I mend the seams that fray in silence, 
and water the ferns before they beg. 
There’s comfort in the ritual of care, 
in folding laundry, wiping counters, 
answering emails with a smile I don’t feel. 
I always see to it the world runs smoothly, 
even when my bones ache with the weight of it. 
I am the quiet architect of order, 
the unseen hand that rights the crooked frame, 
that stirs the soup, that checks the locks at night. 
No one praises the clock for keeping time, 
nor the sun for rising. Still, I do it. 
I always see to it the lights stay on, 
even when my own flickers low.

I always see to it—the stars are named, 
the constellations traced with patient thread. 
I tally the comets, chart their silver trails, 
and soothe the moon when shadows cross her face. 
The universe hums under my gentle touch, 
a lullaby woven through dark matter. 
I mend black holes with whispers, 
and teach dying stars to burn a little longer. 
I always see to it the balance holds, 
though no one knows my name among the galaxies. 
But when you gaze upward, breath caught in wonder, 
that’s me—brushing stardust from your eyes, 
whispering, 'Don’t worry, I’ve got this.' 
I always see to it the night feels safe, 
even as I vanish into the quiet.

I always see to it the coffee’s hot, 
the toast not burned, the dog fed on time. 
I tie my child’s shoes with practiced fingers, 
and kiss each bruise like it’s sacred. 
The world is small in these morning moments—
just socks to find, lunch to pack, a song to hum. 
I always see to it the chaos bends 
to the rhythm of love disguised as duty. 
No grand gestures, just the quiet magic 
of showing up, again and again. 
I am the keeper of tiny flames, 
the one who remembers the library book, 
the birthday card, the vet appointment. 
I always see to it you feel held, 
even when no one sees the cost.

I always see to it the silence speaks—
in the space between notes, in the breath before words. 
I tend to the unsaid, the almost-shared, 
the glances that linger too long. 
I polish the mirrors so truths may surface, 
and sweep the corners where secrets gather dust. 
I always see to it the heart has room 
to break, to heal, to beat in its own time. 
I am the gardener of buried feelings, 
coaxing roots from cracked earth. 
I light candles for grief that won’t name itself, 
and pour wine for joy too shy to knock. 
I always see to it the soul is heard, 
even when the body pretends not to listen.

I always see to it the fire stays lit—
in hearths, in hearts, in the cold hollows of night. 
I gather kindling from forgotten dreams, 
and blow gently on embers of hope. 
I shield the flame from harsh winds, 
from doubt’s downpour, from time’s slow ash. 
I always see to it the warmth spreads, 
though my hands grow numb from the effort. 
Legends may praise the spark, the blaze, the glory—
but I honor the steady glow, the quiet burn. 
I am the keeper no poem remembers, 
yet every light owes me a debt. 
I always see to it the dark doesn’t win, 
even when I’m the only one who knows.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the morning light
Unfurls like silk across the bedroom wall.
I always see to it the kettle sings,
The toast not burned, the sugar in the cup.
A ritual of care, small and precise,
Like folding corners of a letter sealed.
I always see to it the plants are watered,
Even the one that doesn’t want to live.
I always see to it the doors are locked,
The lights extinguished, one by one by one.
And when the world begins to fray at edges,
I stitch it back with quiet, steady hands.
No praise required, no witness needed—
Just the hush of duty softly kept.
I always see to it the stars stay fixed,
Though I am trembling, though I am alone.

I always see to it the silence speaks
In volumes when no one else is near.
I always see to it the shadows bend
To hide the cracks I don’t want seen.
A smile adjusted just in time,
A laugh that doesn’t reach the eyes.
I always see to it the table’s set,
Though no one comes to break the bread.
The clock keeps time, but I keep secrets—
Folded in coats, buried in drawers.
I always see to it the mirror lies,
Reflecting strength I’ve borrowed, not my own.
And when the night grows thick with doubt,
I whisper promises I can’t fulfill.
I always see to it… I always see…
But who sees to me?

I always see to it the garden blooms,
Though frost has bitten every tender stem.
I always see to it the seeds take root,
Press palm to soil and hum a lullaby.
I train the vines to climb the weathered fence,
Guide blossoms toward the hesitant sun.
I always see to it the weeds are pulled,
The pests dispatched, the borders clean.
Not for glory, not for praise or gain,
But for the quiet joy of growth I’ve nurtured.
I always see to it the petals hold
Their color through the waning afternoon.
And when the season folds into itself,
I still stand guard, a keeper of the green.
For in tending what the world forgets,
I find the truth of what it means to care.

I always see to it the stars are named,
Though no one asks or looks up anymore.
I always see to it the old songs play
On scratched records in the attic’s gloom.
I mend the coat with threads from yesterday,
Preserve the letters tied in faded blue.
I always see to it the past stays warm,
Fed by embers no one else can feel.
The world rushes, forgets, moves on, erases—
But I remain, a keeper of the trace.
I always see to it the photograph
Still shows your smile, untouched by time.
And if one day I’m gone, perhaps the wind
Will hum the tune I used to sing to dust.
I always see to it… I always see…
Because forgetting feels too much like death.

I always see to it the coffee's hot,
The dog is walked, the bills are paid on time.
I always see to it the kids are fed,
Backpacks zipped, lunches in the cooler bag.
I always see to it the laundry's done,
The teacher emails answered by noon.
Life hums along, a well-oiled machine,
Polished by hands that rarely rest.
I always see to it the chaos stays
Confined to closets, hidden in drawers.
And when I lie down, bone-tired and spent,
I still see to it my breathing slows.
No fanfare, no pause, no moment’s grace—
Just the quiet pride of holding space.
I always see to it… because if I don’t,
Who then will see to us?

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the kettle sings at dawn, 
the toast never burns, the blinds rise just so. 
A ritual of care stitched into morning light, 
where silence hums with what goes unspoken. 
I always see to it the plants are watered, 
their leaves brushing secrets against the sill. 
Even the dust is banished with quiet intent, 
as if order could keep sorrow at bay. 
I always see to it the door is locked, 
the lights extinguished, the world shut out. 
But no vigil holds back the ache that slips in—
soft as breath, heavy as years. 
I always see to it everything’s fine, 
while the heart, untended, learns to survive on air.

I always see to it the stars are named, 
their silver tags pinned to the velvet dark. 
I catalog comets, chart lunar sighs, 
and polish each orbit until it gleams. 
I always see to it the wind is polite, 
that thunder knocks before it enters dreams. 
Clockwork clouds march in perfect rows, 
and rainbows fold themselves when dismissed. 
I always see to it the moon stays full, 
its pale face pressed against my windowpane. 
But one night, the sky forgets its script—
meteors crash, constellations unravel. 
And I, who always see to it all, 
finally let the universe breathe wild.

I always see to it the coffee's hot, 
the bills are paid, the dog is walked at five. 
I check the stove, the locks, the weather app—
a hundred tiny duties keep the chaos at bay. 
I always see to it your coat is brushed, 
that your favorite mug is waiting by the sink. 
I map your moods like tides, adjust my orbit, 
so the silence never grows too loud. 
I always see to it the world runs smooth, 
while my own needs gather dust in corners. 
But what if one day I let the kettle boil over, 
left the door ajar, the stars uncounted? 
Would you still know me if I stopped seeing to it all—
if I simply let myself be seen?

I always see to it the garden blooms, 
roses spilling their perfume like borrowed prayers. 
I trim the hedges into perfect lines, 
chase weeds like ghosts from fertile ground. 
I always see to it the fountain sings, 
its water clear, its rhythm never lagging. 
But beneath the soil, roots twist in silence, 
reaching for cracks I’ve sworn not to notice. 
I always see to it the surface gleams, 
while something wild stirs underfoot. 
One day, the earth will split its seams, 
and bloom with colors I never planned. 
I always see to it nothing changes—
but the garden has its own will.

I always see to it the clock keeps time, 
its hands marching like obedient soldiers. 
I wind it daily, polish its face, 
whisper promises to the gears within. 
I always see to it the past stays past, 
buried beneath routines and quiet chores. 
But sometimes, a chime rings out of turn—
a memory slipping through the cracks. 
I always see to it my smile is fixed, 
that my voice stays steady, my eyes stay dry. 
The world believes me, maybe even trusts me. 
But the clock knows the truth in its hidden ticks—
how I beg the hours to reverse, just once. 
I always see to it I’m holding on, 
but the hands are slipping through my fingers.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the kettle sings at dawn,
steam curling prayers above the chipped blue mug.
I always see to it—the porch light stays on,
though the path is overgrown and no one comes.
I fold your shirts though they’ve long lost their scent,
press creases into cotton like I’m pressing time.
I always see to it the garden remembers,
watering seeds you planted in April of ’99.
Even the clock ticks in your rhythm,
its pendulum swaying like a metronome of loss.
I always see to it the world runs smooth,
though mine cracked quietly the day you left.
I feed the cat you never knew,
name the stars after things you loved.
I always see to it—because if I stop,
the silence might finally catch me.

I always see to it the stars align,
not in the sky, but in my ledger of tasks.
Laundry folded by 7, soup simmering by 8,
appointments color-coded, life compartmentalized.
I always see to it the bills are paid,
the plants watered, the dog walked, the doubts erased.
Perfection is a promise I make each morning,
brushing my teeth with resolve, flossing out fear.
I always see to it the smile stays,
even when the mirror reflects a stranger.
Because if I falter, if I forget,
the whole fragile architecture might collapse.
So I tighten the screws of routine,
hammer discipline into every hour.
I always see to it—because chaos
lurks just beyond the edge of order.

I always see to it the fire burns low,
in the hearth, in the chest, in the quiet between words.
I bank the embers of what we once were,
tending them like a secret vow.
I always see to it the letters remain unopened,
sealed with time and hesitation.
Each envelope a gravity well, pulling me toward
memories I can’t afford to revisit.
I always see to it the music plays softly,
old jazz that hums like your voice.
And when the rain comes, I always see to it
the window stays cracked—just enough
for the scent of wet earth to slip in,
reminding me of walks we never took.
I always see to it the light fades gently,
never sudden, never harsh—
like the way you left: not with a shout,
but a whisper I still strain to hear.

I always see to it the coffee’s strong,
the toast golden, the news unread.
I always see to it the cat’s bowl is full,
the mail gathered, the world kept at bay.
Routine is my religion, precision my prayer.
I measure out sugar like sacrament,
fold the newspaper with ceremonial care.
I always see to it the door is locked,
the stove off, the dreams suppressed.
Because if I let one thing slip,
the avalanche might begin.
I always see to it the calendar marks time,
but not the kind that heals.
This is the time of maintenance, of surface calm,
of pretending the depths aren’t shifting.
I always see to it—because to stop
would be to admit I’m not okay.
And I can’t see to that.

I always see to it the garden blooms,
roses climbing the fence you built in June.
I always see to it the birds are fed,
though you’re not here to watch them gather.
Your favorite chair faces the lake,
I leave it empty, but dust it daily.
I always see to it the wind chimes sing,
their silver voices calling your name.
Even the moon seems to pause above the hill,
as if remembering how we stood there once,
shoulders touching, breaths in sync.
I always see to it the candles are lit at dusk,
small flames reaching for a sky you now inhabit.
And when the stars blink awake,
I always see to it I whisper your name—
not as a plea, but a promise:
I’m still here. I’m still tending. I’m still yours.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold, the world slows down,
A hush wraps round like woolen thread.
The sky outside wears a misty frown,
And thoughts drift soft, half-born, half-dead.
I sip my tea where silence grows,
Steam curling tales in quiet rows.
Each breath a battle, soft and low,
A rhythm only sickness knows.
My nose is red, my eyes are sore,
But in this ache, I find a door
To dreams I'd lost beneath the noise—
To stillness wrapped in tissue folds,
To stories told in sniffles and sighs,
To warmth that only fever holds.
Now when I have a cold, I see
The beauty in what used to be
A nuisance, curse, or bitter toll—
Now when I have a cold.

Now when I have a cold, I cough and groan,
My voice a croak, my throat a stone.
The tissue box is half-dead, drained,
Each sneeze a drum, each sniff a chain.
I curse the germ, the draft, the rain,
The handshake passed, the bus, the train.
But in this haze of mucus and moan,
A strange peace settles, all on its own.
For work is paused, the world feels far,
I watch the clouds through window bars.
No plans to keep, no need to strive—
Just tea, a blanket, and how I survive.
Now when I have a cold, I find
A slower beat, a gentler mind.
Not strength, but rest. Not speed, but sighs.
Now when I have a cold, I realize
That sometimes healing wears a sniffling face,
And grace arrives in a Kleenex case.

Now when I have a cold, I dream in snot,
Of jungles thick and frozen plots,
Of dragons snoring in my chest,
Their fiery breath a blocked-up quest.
I blow my nose—a trumpet blast!
The pillows quake, the mirrors frost.
My body's turned to swamp and sand,
A kingdom ruled by sniff and hand.
I wage war with tea and pills,
While fever paints the windowills.
But deep inside, a poet sings:
"This mucus holds the voice of springs,
These coughs are verses, raw and bold—
Now when I have a cold."

Now when I have a cold, I stay in bed,
Watch dust float slow where sunlight's spread.
My breath is thick, my head is tight,
Yet something hums—a quiet light.
Not joy, not pain, but in-between,
Where memories flicker, soft and lean.
I think of winters, childhood nights,
Of soup my mother warmed just right.
Of how each illness, sharp and slow,
Once meant her hand upon my brow.
Now no one comes, yet still I feel
The ghost of care, the love that's real.
So even here, with nose so sore,
I'm not alone. I've felt before.
Now when I have a cold.

Now when I have a cold, I write bad poems,
About runny noses and sniffly domes.
My brain is fog, my rhymes are weak,
My metaphors make critics shriek.
I blame the virus, blame the air,
Blame winter's breath, blame doghair, stairs,
And every person who dared to breathe
Too close. My tissues start to teethe.
But still, I type with one hand curled,
While coughing shakes the sleeping world.
For even sick, the soul takes flight—
In fevered lines, in clumsy might.
Now when I have a cold, I find
A muse with germs and clogged-up mind.
Now when I have a cold.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:

Now when I have a cold, I dream in sniffs—

I blow my nose with opera’s grand flair,

Who croaks instead of speaks, who shivers barefoot.
Yet still, I laugh—because what else to do?
When life hands you a virus, build a fort.
Blankets and books, a thermos of weak tea,
And Netflix buffering through my heavy head.
Now when I have a cold, I am a king
Of sniffles, sovereign of the sick day bed.

Now when I have a cold, the sky feels thick,
As if the clouds have settled in my chest.
Each breath a battle, each cough a tiny war.
I wrap myself in layers, still I freeze.
The world outside moves on with urgent feet,

I write these words with fingers slow and stiff,

But in this illness, something soft takes root—
A pause, a breath, a moment to reflect.
Now when I have a cold, I touch my soul,
And find it tired, tender, and quite real.

Now when I have a cold, I talk in honks,
A goose ungraceful, waddling through the week.
My throat’s a desert, scraped by sandstorm words,
My voice a croak that startles even cats.
I drink my lemon water, grim and sweet,

Yet still, I smile—because the fever dreams
Were full of flying, oceans made of light.
Now when I have a cold, I touch the edge

Now when I have a cold, I type with one hand,

Now when I have a cold, I see more clear:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold, the world turns slow—
my thoughts like wool, my breath a fragile thread.

where steam from tea ascends like whispered prayer.
I wrap myself in quilts of faded blue,

and I recall the colds of childhood days—

the touch of cloth upon my fevered brow.
Now when I have a cold, I drift between
the present ache and memories long held.

when silence speaks and fever starts to creep.

where love was warmth and time moved so slow.

but hers, returned in a breath I’ve known.

Now when I have a cold, I talk to ghosts—
the ones who nursed me with soup and song,

I blow my mind into crumpled tissues,
dreaming of peppermint and ginger tea.

while my voice cracks like a broken record.

miss the soft hands, the forehead check,
the way someone once said, 'Rest now, dear.'
Now when I have a cold, I feel small,
small and soft, like tissue paper soaked in rain.
And though I’m grown, I whisper into the dark:
'Would someone please bring me a glass of water?'

Now when I have a cold, the sky forgets its blue.
Clouds clot like mucus, gray and low.
I sip lukewarm water, taste the ache in my throat,
and wonder if silence is also sick.
My keyboard clacks like bones in a dry wind,
each word a struggle, each breath a battle.
I used to run through rain with laughter;
now I flinch at drafts beneath the door.
But in this weakness, something hums—
a quiet truth the healthy never hear.
Now when I have a cold, I listen:
to clocks, to breath, to the creak of the house.
I hear the rhythm beneath the noise,
the pulse of stillness, deep and slow.
Perhaps illness is not just loss,
but a door cracked open to what we ignore.
Now when I have a cold, I am not whole—
but strangely, more myself than before.

Now when I have a cold, I dream in tissues—
white squares blooming like sad flowers in my hands.
I wrap myself in sweaters two sizes too big,
and watch dust dance in the afternoon light.
My nose glows like a lantern, my voice a croak,
but the cat still curls beside me, unimpressed.
I sip tea that tastes like honeyed steam,
and remember how colds felt when I was small:
mom’s hand on my forehead, the beep of the thermometer,
the world reduced to bed, book, and bowl.
Now I care for myself, but part of me longs
for someone else to say, 'You’re burning up.'
Now when I have a cold, I am both child and parent,
both nurse and patient, both weak and strong.
I blow my nose with dignity, then laugh—
this body, flawed and fighting, still sings on.

Now when I have a cold, the air turns thick—
each breath a labor, each sniff a small defeat.
I move through rooms like a ghost in flannel,
haunting my own life with sniffles and sighs.
The world outside buzzes with urgent plans,
but I am stuck in the kingdom of Kleenex,
where time dissolves in steam and throat lozenges.
I watch the clock, not for minutes, but naps.
My thoughts fog over like bathroom mirrors,
and clarity feels like a distant country.
Yet in this haze, something tender stirs—
a memory of being held, of soup spooned slow,

Now when I have a cold, I am not productive,
but I am present, in a way I rarely allow.

but in surrender—to rest, to breath, to now.

My voice, once bold, now takes the road
Of whispers scraped from larynx overtones.
The world keeps spinning, loud and full of sound,
While I retreat to blankets, books, and tea.
No grand adventure treads on this hushed ground,
Just me, my thoughts, and sniffles endlessly.
Yet in this quiet, something starts to bloom—
A poem shaped by fever, thin and strange.
It hums beneath the silence of the room,
A fragile bird escaping from a cage.
So let the cold wind howl, let temperatures dip—
From illness, art can sometimes rise and skip.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold, I wrap myself in quiet, 
A quilt of hush drawn close against the light. 
Steam curls from tea like whispers, rising slowly, 
As thoughts unravel in the hush of night. 
Each breath is thick, a labor through the fog, 
And words come slow, like footsteps in the snow. 
The world outside still bustles, sharp and bold, 
But here, inside, the fevered silence grows. 
I count the beats between each tick of time, 
And watch the shadows dance along the wall. 
Now when I have a cold, I don’t just rhyme—
I listen to the spaces, after all. 
For in this stillness, stripped of haste and show, 
I find the songs the busy never know.

Now when I have a cold, the tissues pile, 
A monument to sniffles, damp and white. 
I cough like thunder, startle every mile, 
And dream of soup that warms me just right. 
My voice is gravel, dragged across the floor, 
My nose a faucet I can’t quite turn off. 
I curse the germs that left me wanting more—
Of sleep, of breath, of any kind of cough-free off. 
Yet still, I laugh, though it makes me wheeze, 
At how absurd this human form can be. 
Now when I have a cold, I find some ease 
In knowing even I must slow for me. 
For health’s a gift we often take as owed—
This cold reminds me how it’s earned, not owed.

Now when I have a cold, I speak in sighs, 
A mist of words that falter, faint, and fade. 
The sky wears gray, reflecting my own eyes, 
And time itself seems slightly misbehaved. 
I sip my tea and watch the rain descend, 
Each drop a drumbeat on the windowpane. 
I think of all the places I might mend, 
If healing came from stillness, not from strain. 
My books lie open, pages slightly bent, 
My thoughts meander, thick as winter mud. 
Now when I have a cold, I don’t repent—
I welcome this enforced, reflective flood. 
For in the ache, a gentle truth takes hold: 
Sometimes the body needs a story told.

Now when I have a cold, I blow my nose 
With such a force, it startles even me. 
I’m wrapped in scarves like some unwellly rose, 
A bloom too damp for any healthy tree. 
I dream of mountains, crisp and clean and high, 
Where every breath is sharp and free and clear. 
Instead, I cough beneath a leaden sky, 
And sip warm lemon water, year by year. 
But still, I smile at how the body fights, 
This tiny war beneath the skin and bone. 
Now when I have a cold, I see the lights—
Not stars, but fevers flickering on their own. 
And though I’m weak, I’m not without my song—
A croaky hum, but steady, deep, and long.

Now when I have a cold, I talk to ghosts—
The ones of health, of running, jumping, free. 
They mock me softly from their distant posts, 
While I’m confined to couch and reverie. 
I write bad poems, sneeze into my sleeve, 
And curse the season, weather, air, and dust. 
But in this ache, I start to truly grieve 
For all the moments I took breath for trust. 
Now when I have a cold, I learn to pray 
In whispers, not in shouts or grand displays. 
I thank my lungs, though clogged, still find their way 
To pull the air through foggy, stubborn maze. 
This illness, brief, is not a thief, but sage—
It teaches breath, and rest, and turning page.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold, the world turns muffled, slow—
a symphony of sniffles in the quiet morning's glow.
The kettle sings a softer tune, the sky wears pale attire,
and I, wrapped in a quilt of blue, breathe steam into the fire.
Each cough a pause between the lines of thoughts I try to write,
a staccato rhythm tapping through the fading light.
My nose runs like a river lost, my head a foggy hill,
but in this weakened stillness, something tender settles still.
I watch the dust motes dance above the sunlit wooden floor,
and wonder if this fragility might open a different door—
where strength isn’t measured by how fast I climb the steep,
but by how deeply I can rest while the body learns to sleep.
Now when I have a cold, I learn to let things be,
to cradle my own quiet, like tea grown cold, yet free.

Now when I have a cold, I dream in tissues white,
a fortress built of pillows, bathed in dim lamplight.
My voice, a croak of protest from a throat both raw and tight,
while dreams of soup and silence merge into the night.
I scroll through memes and medicine, half-awake, half-gone,
the world outside a distant hum, a radio on low.
My dog stares with concern, then licks my hand with care,
as if to say, 'Your sniffling is simply part of here.'
I miss the rush, the run, the leap, the places I once strode,
but in this slowed-down season, I reconnect with code—
not ones and zeros, but the pulse beneath the skin,
the quiet fight that rages as new strength begins.
Now when I have a cold, I'm not behind, just slow,
a seed beneath the surface, waiting for the snow to go.

Now when I have a cold, I speak in hushed defeat,
a whisper lost in blanket folds, a pulse beneath the sheet.
The mirror shows a puffy face, a nose like overripe peach,
and yet, within this swollen shell, my thoughts stretch out of reach.
Not toward work or duty, but to stars and ancient trees,
to childhood beds where mothers came with honeyed, warm decrees.
I sip my tea like sacred wine, each breath a battle won,
my body—temple, battleground, where fever has its run.
I curse the tickle in my chest, the ache behind my eyes,
but also find a softer grace in these subdued goodbyes.
For in the hush of illness, where ambition dares not tread,
a gentler kind of wisdom rises, warm and half-undressed.
Now when I have a cold, I learn to be,
not do—and isn’t that the kindest truth?

Now when I have a cold, I sneeze with cosmic force,
a blast that shakes the windowpane and throws my cat off course.
My tissues bloom like flowers, discarded, soft, and white,
a garden of my suffering beneath the bedroom light.
I curse the world, the weather, and the person on the train
who coughed without a covering—such careless, germy pain!
But then, between the headaches, in the silence after sips
of ginger root and lemon, my spirit starts to dip
into a deeper current, where the noise begins to fade,
and all that's left is breathing, and the choices that I've made.
To rest, to wait, to listen—not to push, but to receive.
Perhaps this cold’s a teacher, though I'd rather it would leave.
Now when I have a cold, I'm taught to yield,
to let the body heal in its own quiet field.

Now when I have a cold, I type with one hand only,
the other clutching tissues, soft and loyal, nearly holy.
My nose runs like a faucet, my head a drum of pain,
but still, I laugh at memes that show the same sad, snotty strain.
I drink my tea too scalding, just to feel the burn inside,
a counter-flame to fever, a warmth I can't deny.
Outside, the rain keeps falling, matching tears I didn’t plan,
while Netflix drones its comfort to this weakened, aching man.
I miss the gym, the sunshine, the crisp air in my lungs,
but here, in this soft prison, a different song is sung—
of patience, and of presence, of the self beneath the skin,
who doesn’t need achievements just to let the healing begin.
Now when I have a cold, I learn to be small,
and in that smallness, find I have it all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Hath stolen the bloom from cheek and brow,
And left in place the quiet truth
Of lines that mark the present, not the vow
Of spring's return. The mirror shows
A face once bright with dawn's first hue,
Now shaded where the soft light grows,
And wisdom traded for the new.

The hours slip like sand through fingers clenched,
Though fists are tight, they cannot hold
The golden moments, long since drenched
In dusk. The stories once untold
Now echo in the hollows of the mind,
Where dreams once danced, now slow and thinned.

Yet in this theft, a gift remains—
Not beauty's flush, but depth that stays.
For Time may steal the springtime rains,
But gives the strength that autumn weighs.
And though my youth is but a name,
My soul still burns with quieter flame.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept through the garden of my early days,
And plucked each blossom, leaving only truth
In withered stems and faintly fading praise.

I counted moments like a miser's gold,
Yet none were spared his silent, steady hand.
My dreams, once bold, now timidly unfold
In quieter rooms of this more thoughtful land.

The laughter that once rang from hill to hill
Now hums beneath the surface of my breath.
I trade the thrill of motion for the still,
The dance of life for lessons learned in death.

Yet in his theft, I find a strange accord—
He takes the shell, but leaves the growing word.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen the fire from my eager gaze?
Where once I sprinted, now I walk in truth,
And measure steps through memory's soft maze.

The mirror holds a stranger's gentle eyes,
Etched with the tales of seasons I have crossed.
No longer ruled by passion's sharp surprise,
But shaped by winds that shaped me at great cost.

I mourn the loss of what I used to be,
The careless joy, the rush of untried roads.
Yet in this change, I find identity—
A deeper self beneath the quiet codes.

For though Time steals the bloom, he plants the root,
And from the fall, a richer life takes shoot.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Slipped through my grasp like morning mist?
I reached for joy, but found instead the truth—
That every moment's fleeting, never tryst.

The songs I sang with unlined face and free
Now tremble in a voice more worn, more wise.
My heart still beats, though not as loud, as he
Has dimmed the flame behind my younger eyes.

Yet in this quiet, something starts to grow—
Not loud, not rash, but steady, like the tide.
I've learned to love the pace of seeds below,
The grace of roots where dreams reside.

So let him steal the blush, the bound, the leap—
My soul still sings, and sings more true and deep.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen the light from my morning sky?
I woke to find the bloom of careless truth
Now folded, like a letter left to die.

The years unspool like thread from spindles old,
Each twist a choice, each knot a silent cost.
I traded gold for stories to be told,
And wonder now what all was truly lost.

But in the hush where youthful echoes fade,
A different music starts to take its place—
Not loud, not proud, but gently serenade
Of peace that time cannot erase.

So though he steals the spring, he gives the tree,
And in the growth, I come to more than be.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Slipped through my hands like sand at ebbing tide. / The songs I sang in reckless, boundless truth / Now echo soft, where dreams and silence bide. / I marked the hours with passion, not with care, / And woke to find my spring had turned to gray. / The mirror wears a face not mine, but bare— / A map of nights I did not mean to stay. / Yet in this quiet, something still survives: / A steady flame that age cannot consume. / Though joy once leapt, now gently it arrives, / A deeper calm within the gathering gloom. / For Time may steal the bloom, but not the root— / My heart still beats, though shaped by time’s pursuit.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Stolen the colors from my brightest days. / The fire that burned with unrelenting truth / Now flickers low in dim and quiet ways. / I chased the sun, believing it my own, / But shadows stretch where once the light was wide. / The seeds I sowed now bear a heavier stone, / And hope walks slow with wisdom by its side. / No curse, this change, though grief may sometimes call— / For every year that strips, another gives. / The body fades, but spirit stands through all, / And deeper love from deeper loss now lives. / Though youth departs, the soul may still renew— / And find its strength in skies of darker blue.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Hath stolen the bloom that graced my early morn;
Each fleeting hour, a whispering truth,
That bids my spirit greet the coming thorn.

The spring of life, once vibrant, fresh, and bold,
Now yields to shadows lengthening on the plain;
The dreams I cherished, stories to be told,
Lie folded gently in memory's chain.

Yet though my hair is touched with silvered frost,
And though my steps no longer lightly tread,
I find in quiet moments, never lost,
The fire that time cannot leave for dead.

For wisdom walks where youth once danced in flame,
And peace outshines the glory of a name.

So let Time steal what hours he may,
My soul still sings at break of day.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Slipped through my hands like sand at ebbing tide;
I chased the sun, pursued the wind in truth,
Yet found my vigor waning, set aside.

The mirror shows a face I barely know,
With lines that map the laughter, grief, and years;
Where once swift rivers in my pulses flow,
Now quieter streams dispel my former fears.

But in this stillness, deeper truths arise—
Not lost, the days, though changed in tone and pace;
The fire of passion dims, yet never dies,
Transmuted into grace, into embrace.

O Time, though you may steal the bloom and speed,
You gift the depth that only age can feed.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept in with silence, robed in shadowed gray?
I woke to find the season passed in truth,
No fanfare marking night’s encroaching day.

The songs I sang now echo far away,
My limbs grown slow, my vision dimmed with years;
Yet in the dusk, a gentler light holds sway—
A calm that tempers sorrow, doubt, and fears.

For though the bloom has faded from the rose,
And spring’s wild joy no longer fills my chest,
The heart still beats with wisdom time bestows,
And love endures beyond the body’s rest.

So let the thief take what he deems his due—
My soul remains, and that he cannot subdue.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen the dawn before I learned its name?
I reached for stars that flickered into truth,
But found them dimmed by age’s quiet flame.

The fields I ran now lie behind a wall,
And voices from my past are faint and few;
Yet in the hush, I hear a deeper call—
A peace that time, in taking, gave anew.

For every wrinkle marks a story told,
Each silver strand a chapter, rich and deep;
Though youth’s bright colors fade into the old,
The soul still dances while the body sleeps.

So steal, O Time, the skin, the strength, the breath—
You cannot steal the triumph over death.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Left footprints on the canvas of my face?
I searched for permanence, for ageless truth,
But found instead a slow, embracing grace.

The world once moved too fast for me to see,
Now every moment lingers, sharp and clear;
Not loss, but gain, in what has come to be—
A mind uncluttered, void of doubt or fear.

The passions burned, the tempests rose and fell,
And in their wake, a steady light remains;
Not youth’s brief spark, but something deeper, well—
A calm that flows through life’s enduring veins.

So welcome, Time, though you may steal and steal—
You teach the heart what never can congeal.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, 
Stolen the bloom that graced my early morn, 
And left in place the weight of silent truth—
That dreams once bright now tremble, worn and torn. 
Each fleeting hour, a whisper soft and low, 
Creeps through the chambers where my passions sleep, 
While shadows stretch where eager footsteps go,

Yet in this grasp of moments slipped away, 
A quiet fire still dares to beat and glow; 
Not all is lost beneath the pallid day—
Some embers of my spirit fiercely grow. 
Though Time may steal the face that once was known,

Stolen the songs my careless heart once knew? 
Where laughter danced in reckless, boundless truth, 
Now thoughtful silence wears a grayer hue. 
I mark the lines that time has gently traced, 
Not scars of sorrow, but of stories told—
Of love that burned, of chances I embraced, 
Of winters faced and summers fiercely bold. 
Though youth departs on wings I cannot hold, 
Its echoes linger in the choices made. 
Each year bestows a wisdom more than gold, 
A deeper light that shadows cannot shade. 
So let Time steal what it was born to claim—
My soul remains unyielding, still aflame.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, 
Slipped through my hands like sand at break of day? 
I chased the sun, ignored the voice of truth, 
And now the twilight steals my breath away. 
My mirror shows a stranger’s quiet gaze, 
Where once a boy looked out with fire and flight. 
I count the years in silent, solemn praise, 
For each brought both delight and quiet night. 
The games I played, the dreams I dared to keep, 
Now rest like leaves beneath autumn’s hush. 
Yet in this calm, a promise starts to creep—
That age may soften, but not turn to mush. 
Though Time may steal the bloom, it plants a seed: 
The ripened mind outgrows the careless creed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:
Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through the mist, the shadows creep.
Dew-laced grass and silent thorn,
Herald light from night forlorn.
No bugle sounds, no captain's call,
Yet duty stirs beyond the wall.
Your coat is worn, your boots are torn,
But still the path ahead is sworn.

Beyond the trench, beyond the flame,
Lies a world not quite the same.
Where children laugh on sunlit lanes,
And peace returns to scarred domains.
But here, where silence hums with dread,
You lift your head, though filled with lead.
For honor walks on wounded feet,
And courage speaks in heartbeats beat.

So rise, not to glory's drum,
But to the quiet work to come.
To guard the dreams that others keep,
While you stand watch where shadows sleep.
Soldier, wake - the dawn is breaking,
And in your eyes, a world's sake quaking.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Softly through the cracks of sleep.
Not with joy, nor fanfare bright,
But with gray and solemn light.

The world outside is hushed and still,
Yet burdened by unspoken will.
Your fingers brush the rifle’s frame,
A silent vow, no words to name.

Memories flicker—home, a kiss,
A mother’s voice, a moment’s bliss.
But now the field, the frost, the fear,
And comrades lost, forever near.

You rise, not eager, not afraid,
But bound by oaths that must be paid.
The sun ascends, a hesitant glow,
Reflecting on the blood below.

So march, not toward fame or gold,
But truths too heavy to unfold.
For in your step, the earth keeps score—
A nation’s hope, a silent war.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through the fog where silence lies.
A breath, a stir, the world is creeping,
Under ashen, watchful skies.

No birdsong marks this dawning hour,
Only wind through broken trees.
Yet in your chest, a steady power—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes, where shadows stretch long,
And the wind carries echoes of forgotten songs,
I walk with a heart both heavy and slow,
Beneath a sky where no stars dare to glow.

Each mile a memory, each signpost a cry,
Of dreams that were lost, of love let it die.
Trucks rumble past like the years slipping through,
Their headlights like eyes that see nothing true.

Yet in the dust where the silence takes hold,
A whisper persists—brave, stubborn, and bold.
Not all is abandoned, not all is undone;
Even sorrow must yield to the rising sun.

So I press on, though the road bends and breaks,
Through storms and through sleepless, aching wakes.
For every deep wound, a story is sown,
And I am not lost—I am finding my home.

At the highways of woes, the asphalt runs deep,
Where silence is loud and the watchful stars sleep.
No map can direct through this labyrinth of pain,
Where each exit leads deeper, not out of the rain.

I meet ghostly travelers with eyes full of years,
Who speak without voices and vanish in tears.
Their burdens, like mine, are strapped to the spine,
A caravan moving through spaces not mine.

But somewhere, a radio hums an old tune,
A fragment of joy beneath a blood-orange moon.
It flickers like hope in a world made of gray,
A promise that night cannot claim the day.

And though the road climbs with a merciless grade,
And every turn threatens a new masquerade,
I carry a light that no darkness can steal—
A wound that still bleeds, but begins to heal.

At the highways of woes, the tires hum dirges,
While the sky wears the gray of forgotten surges.
Each mile marker counts what the heart cannot name—
Regret, separation, unspoken shame.

The rest stops offer coffee too bitter to taste,
And benches where loneliness holds a firm grasp.
No billboards proclaim of salvation ahead,
Just flickering neon that reads: 'You're already dead.'

Yet in the rearview, a small light persists,
A memory glowing where compassion exists.
A hand once held, a word softly said,
Now fueling the steps where the broken are led.

For though the road twists through thunder and frost,
And grief rides shotgun, no matter the cost,
There's power in moving, in choosing to go,
Even if the destination is nowhere I know.

At the highways of woes, the wind sings low,
Of lovers parted and seeds never sown.
Tarmac unrolls like a scroll of old pain,
Etched with the footprints of loss and of rain.

I drive with no compass, no future in sight,
Just the hum of the engine through the cold of the night.
Each passing car carries a soul in disguise,
With shadows behind them and tears in their eyes.

But look—on the shoulder, a wildflower grows,
Defiant in color, untouched by the snows.
A splash of red where all else is gray,
A sign that beauty still finds its way.

So I roll down the window and let the wind in,
Let sorrow speak, then release it again.
For even the longest road must have bends,
And every dark journey eventually ends.

At the highways of woes, the sky weeps tar,
And the trees stand like judges with arms raised in scar.
No birds sing here, only engines that groan,
As if metal and motion are utterly alone.

I carry a suitcase of unsaid goodbyes,
And photographs faded beneath clouded skies.
Each mile eats seconds, each hour a stone,
Dragging the spirit, making it known:

That pain has a geography, vast and unkind,
With rivers of silence and mountains of rind.
But deep in the tunnel, past layers of night,
A pulse still beats with enduring light.

Not loud, not triumphant, but steady and slow,
Like roots in the dark where new green things grow.
And though the road stretches with no end in view,
I travel not broken—but becoming, and true.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes, where shadows stretch long,
And echoes of sorrows in silence belong,
I wandered through dusk with a heart full of rain,
Chasing phantoms of joy, love, and pain.
Each mile a memory, each signpost a tear,
Marking decades of longing, of hope, and of fear.
Trucks roared past like the years slipping by,
Headlights like eyes that refuse to say why.
Yet in the distance, a flicker, a glow—
A roadside diner where kind strangers go.
Steam on the windows, coffee black and deep,
A haven where the broken can briefly sleep.
And though the road winds through grief and through frost,
I drive on, not counting what sorrow has cost.
For even in darkness, a soul may find grace,
Not in arriving, but in keeping the pace.
At the highways of woes, I no longer flee—
I carry my wounds like stars yet to be.

At the highways of woes, the asphalt breathes pain,
A serpent uncoiling through sun-scorched terrain.
Each crack a story, each pothole a cry,
Of lovers abandoned, of dreams left to die.
I walked with no destination, no map,
Just the weight of old letters I couldn't unclasp.
Trucks blared like warnings, the wind sang a dirge,
As I traced my regrets like a priest with a scourge.
Yet in the rearview, a light started growing,
Not of rescue, but knowing—of seeds softly sowing.
For grief is not merely a path to endure,
But a forge where the spirit grows steady and pure.
And though the horizon stays cloaked in gray mist,
I’ve learned to walk lightly, to not be dismissed.
At the highways of woes, I found not an end,
But the strength to begin, to love, to defend.
Not joy untouched, but joy earned and wise—
A lantern lit softly in sorrowful skies.

At the highways of woes, the rain never ceased,
And the sky wore a shroud, forever released
From the mercy of mornings or colors so bright—
Just gray on gray, day after night.
I drove with the radio whispering songs
Of lost love and places where nothing belongs.
Streetlights blinked slowly, like tired old eyes,
Counting the miles of my slow goodbyes.
Each exit a choice I once failed to take,
Now buried beneath mist and mistake.
Yet somewhere, a child laughs in a field,
A reminder that wounds are not all that are sealed.
For even in sorrow, life pulses below—
Like roots in the dark, where new green things grow.
And though this road bends through despair and delay,
I carry a hope that won’t fade away.
At the highways of woes, I am not undone—
I am learning to travel with sorrow as one.

At the highways of woes, the wind howls names
Of those I have loved and lost in the flames
Of time and regret, of choices unkind,
Of words left unspoken, of peace left behind.
Tires hum dirges on concrete and stone,
A rhythm of grief I’ve claimed as my own.
Mile markers pass like the beats of a heart
That still dares to hope, though torn apart.
In the glow of the signs—"Rest Area Ahead"—
I pause, not for comfort, but simply to tread
On solid ground, to feel earth beneath feet,
To taste something real, though bittersweet.
And in that stillness, a whisper takes flight:
"You are more than your sorrow, your failures, your night."
So I climb back in, turn the key, face the dark—
Not healed, but still human, still leaving a mark.
At the highways of woes, I drive not to flee,
But to find who I am meant to be.

At the highways of woes, the stars refuse light,
And the moon hangs like guilt in the depth of the night.
I drove with no music, no words, just the sound
Of tires on pavement, the only thing found.
Each shadow a memory I tried to outrun—
A father’s last breath, a marriage undone.
Yet in the stillness, a strange peace arose,
Not joy, not healing, but something that grows
When you stop fighting pain and let it walk near—
A companion, not master, both fragile and clear.
And though the road forks and the weather turns cruel,
I carry my wounds like old, trusted tools.
For grief shapes the soul like a river the stone,
And love is not lost—it has simply grown
Deeper than surface, beyond what is seen,
A current beneath where the true self has been.
At the highways of woes, I no longer break—
I bend, I remember, I choose to awake.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes, where shadows stretch long,
And echoes of heartbreak compose a sad song,
I wandered through seasons of silence and smoke,
With dreams turned to dust by the words I awoke.

Each mile bore a memory I couldn’t outrun—
A whisper of battles already lost, already won.
Trucks roared like thunder, their lights cutting night,
While I clutched at the fragments of love and of light.

No exit signs gleamed, no rest stops in sight,
Just the hum of the asphalt beneath fading light.
Yet in every pothole, a star found its place,
A glimmer of grace in the vast, aching space.

For though sorrow may stretch like an endless road,
And grief be the burden I daily unload,
There’s beauty in traveling, step after step,
In learning to carry what others might forget.

So I walk with my wounds, not hiding their trace,
For even the highways of woes lead somewhere—maybe grace.

At the highways of woes, the wind carries cries,
Of lovers departed, of dreams that died young.
Tires hiss secrets on rain-slicked blacktop,
Where hope wears thin like a worn-out hubcap.

I drove through the fog with rearview regrets,
Each mile a confession I couldn’t forget.
Streetlights flickered like dying heartbeats,
While silence sat shotgun with folded hands, meek.

No map could guide me through sorrow’s terrain,
No GPS voice to ease the pain.
Just the rhythm of wheels on a fated route,
And memories revving like a broken exhaust.

But somewhere past sorrow, beyond the gray,
A dawn cracks open, refusing to stay.
Not to erase the ache, nor the miles I’ve known,
But to walk them with purpose, no longer alone.

For even the highways of woes, dark and steep,
May carry the soul where it’s meant to leap.

At the highways of woes, the sky sags low,
A ceiling of clouds where no bird dares go.
Each lane a lament, each signpost a sigh,
As travelers pass with questions and why.

I walked with a suitcase full of old fears,
Stitched shut with silence, marked by years.
The rumble of engines, a constant refrain,
Like blood through the body, again and again.

No shoulders to rest on, no exits to take,
Just the weight of the world with every step I make.
Yet in the distance, a flicker, a hue—
A billboard of flowers in a field overdue.

Perhaps not salvation, nor rescue, nor cure,
But a moment of peace, something pure.
For even the highways of deepest despair
Can cradle a whisper, a breath in the air.

And if I keep walking, though slow and unsure,
I might find, at the end, a door still secure.

At the highways of woes, the asphalt breathes pain,
Absorbing the tears of those caught in the rain.
Each crack a confession, each stripe a divide,
Between what we wanted and what we must hide.

I met a ghost there, dressed in my skin,
Who asked if I’d ever let sorrow wear thin.
We shared a cigarette lit by regret,
Then parted like debts I can’t quite forget.

But even in darkness, a rhythm remains—
The pulse of the earth through tire marks and stains.
A song in the static, a hum in the wires,
A trace of old laughter rising through mires.

So I drive not to flee, but to finally face
The miles of my making, the depth of my space.
For the highways of woes, though cruel and unkind,
Are also the paths where the lost are defined.

At the highways of woes, the stars refuse light,
And the moon hangs like a bruise in the night.
I walked with no name, just echoes behind,
Of voices that loved me, now lost to the wind.

Each car that passed carried someone like me—
Eyes hollow with stories too heavy to free.
We exchanged no words, just a nod and a glance,
A silent alliance in this land of mischance.

But deep in the ditches, where wildflowers grow,
Tiny rebellions against endless woe,
Petals like prayers pushing through cracks,
Defying the weight of emotional tax.

So I knelt in the gravel, not broken, but bent,
And whispered a vow to the firmament:
That even on highways where sorrow is law,
I’ll carry a spark, and keep walking because—
Because every road ends, and I choose to believe,
That beyond lies a dawn I have yet to receive.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes, where shadows stretch long,
And whispers of sorrow compose a sad song,
I walk with a burden, both heavy and slow,
Beneath skies that remember the dreams I let go.
Each mile a memory, each signpost a tear,
The past in the rearview, yet ever so near.
Trucks rumble like thunder, their cargo unseen—
Regrets tightly wrapped in plastic and sheen.
I pass through the dusk where the streetlamps blink low,
Guiding ghosts down the routes only heartbreak would know.
Yet somewhere ahead, past the tolls and the pain,
A dawn unimagined begins to explain
That sorrow, though vast as the interstate's span,
Is not the final destination of man.
And though I may falter and sometimes stall,
I'm still moving—still answering the call.
For even in grief, there's a rhythm, a rhyme,
And perhaps, just ahead, lies a reason for time.

At the highways of woes, the asphalt weeps black,
Where silence is loud and the rearview’s off track.
No exits, no markers, just echoes that call
From voices long lost, from lovers who fall.
Each lane is a lifetime I didn’t complete,
A choice left unmade, a heart left to beat
In isolation, where no headlights reach
The corners where loneliness likes to preach.
I drive with no license, no map, no name,
Just fuel made of tears and a flickering flame
Of hope that sputters with every steep rise,
Where gravity pulls at my unspoken cries.
Yet in the distance, a billboard appears—
Faded, but legible through all of the years:
"You are not abandoned, though shadows may grow,
Even grief has a destination you know."
And so I press onward, though broken and slow,
Because even highways of woes must let go.

At the highways of woes, the wind sings a dirge,
A symphony spun from a world grown inert.
Tires hum ballads of choices gone wrong,
Of lullabies lost and where we belong.
No rest stops here, only mile after mile
Of echoes that stretch like a never-healed smile.
Traces of laughter in cracks of the tar,
Like memories buried beneath what we are.
I see hitchhikers—phantoms of me
From futures abandoned and dreams I can’t see.
They wave, but I don’t dare slow down or turn,
Afraid that their sorrow might make my heart burn.
Yet still, in the silence between engine’s low groan,
A whisper persists: "You’re not walking alone."
For every soul stranded, for every who grieves,
There’s a rhythm in ruins, a pulse beneath leaves.
And though this road bends through the valley of sighs,
It spirals toward stars in the vast, open skies.
At the highways of woes, we are broken, yet whole—
Still journeying onward, still searching the soul.

At the highways of woes, the rain never ends,
Just drizzles of heartbreak on rusted-out friends.
Tail lights like embers in fog’s heavy shroud,
Each one a promise that time screamed aloud.
I drive through the downpour with windows rolled down,
Letting grief wash the silence with sound.
No GPS here to reroute the pain,
Just signs pointing backward, again and again.
A diner appears with its neon half-dead,
Serving coffee that tastes like things left unsaid.
The waitress smiles—she’s been down this same route,
Her eyes hold the map of a sorrow devout.
She whispers, "Keep going. The worst is not here.
Beyond the next overpass, hope reappears."
So I climb back in, though my spirit is thin,
With engine and anguish both creaking within.
For even the highways of endless despair
Can carry you closer to healing somewhere.
And though scars remain where the potholes once tore,
They mark where you traveled—and where you are more.

At the highways of woes, the stars refuse light,
And every onramp leads deeper in night.
No horns, no billboards, just silence that bites,
And rearview mirrors full of extinguished lights.
I drive with no purpose, no exit in sight,
Just echoes of footsteps that left in the night.
Each mile a requiem, each curve a goodbye,
To versions of myself I let wither and die.
Yet in the stillness, a rhythm takes form—
Not loud, not defiant, but steady, a norm.
A heartbeat beneath the hum of the wheels,
A truth that no sorrow or distance conceals:
That pain is a traveler, not owner of road,
A companion, not master, beneath this dark load.
And though I may wander through decades of gray,
There’s beauty in motion, in choosing to stay.
For even the highways of endless lament
Are stitched through with threads of what love once meant.
So onward I travel, not healed, but aware—
That grief is not all that the journey will bear.

responses.text:

At the highways of woes, the asphalt runs deep,

At the highways of woes, the sky wears a bruise,

I drove with no destination, just flight,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A farmer's wife, both young and gay,'

responses.text:
A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Danced through the fields at break of day.
Her skirts would flutter, light as hay,
Chasing the dawn along the way.
She sang to sheep and whispered low
To calves that in the meadow grow.
Her laughter rang like wind-bells high,
Beneath the ever-changing sky.
No crown she wore, yet ruled the land,
With gentle touch and strong command.
Her hands, though soft, could mend and sow,
Tend broken wings and row on row.
At dusk, she'd sit by crackling fire,
Her heart alight with sweet desire—
Not for gold or city’s gleam,
But for love, and stars, and dream.
Her husband smiled, his eyes alight,
With joy found in her morning light.
No tale of court, no royal page,
Could match the grace of country stage.
So here’s to her, both brave and free,
The wild, bright heart of farm and tree.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Rose with the sun to start the day.
She fed the hens and milked the cow,
Then brushed her hair and made a bow.
To life she brought a joyful sound—
A skipping step on stony ground.
Her apron flapped like barnyard wings,
As she counted eggs and gathered springs.
She loved the soil, the rain, the breeze,
The rustle of the ripening trees.
And though her days were filled with toil,
She danced through moments with a smile.
Her husband worked the furrowed rows,
But she was where the beauty grows—
In gardens bright and kitchen pies,
In lullabies and firelit sighs.
Her youth was not in looks alone,
But in the seeds that she had sown.
And when the years had turned to gray,
They'd say: 'She lived, and lived that way—
With laughter loud and spirit free,
The soul of all the countryside.'

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,

She rose each morn with sunlit grace,

Her hands, though calloused, held such care,
For every lamb, for every hare.
She danced barefoot in summer rain,
Sang songs to soothe the barnyard pain.
Her voice, a lark at break of dawn,
Could lift a weary soul, forlorn.
She loved her man with steady flame,
Not loud, but deep—no need for name.
Together they would watch the sky,
And count the stars as years went by.
No ballroom halls could hold her joy,
Found in a child, a newborn boy.
She raised him strong, with roots in earth,
A legacy of quiet worth.
And when at last she passed away,
The fields themselves seemed sad that day.
Yet in the wind, a laugh would play—
A farmer's wife, both young and gay.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Would greet the world at break of day.
She'd tie her hair and pull on boots,
And chase the night from root and shoots.
Her spirit sparkled, wild and free,
Like daisies dancing in the lea.
She laughed at storms, she sang in snow,
Her joy the kind that few could know.
She baked the bread, she tended bees,
She climbed the hill with perfect ease.
And when her man came home at night,
She lit the fire with pure delight.
No jewels adorned her simple dress,
Yet beauty shone in her finesse.
She lived with rhythm, deep and true—
The pulse of sky and soil and dew.
Her youth was not in years alone,
But in the seeds that she had sown.
And though the years would steal her grace,
They couldn't dim her warm embrace.
For love like hers, so bold, so spry,
Outlives the stars, outlasts the sky.
A farmer's wife, both young and gay—
She turned the common into play.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Would wake at dawn to greet the day.
She'd hum a tune while gathering eggs,
And stroke the cat beneath the hedges.
Her hair would fly in golden strands,
Like wheat released from binding bands.
She twirled in skirts of faded blue,
And kissed the sky with morning dew.
She didn't crave the city's noise,
But found her peace in girls and boys,
In piglets squealing, goats that leap,
And promises the seasons keep.
Her love was quiet, deep, and wide,
Like rivers flowing, strong with pride.
She stood beside her weathered man,
And held his calloused, working hand.
No fanfare marked her daily grace,
Yet every step left beauty's trace.
She planted flowers by the gate,
And laughter echoed, never late.
And when the stars began to gleam,
She'd whisper tales beside the stream.
A farmer's wife, both young and gay—
She turned the soil, and turned the gray
Of toil and time, to gold and song,
A fleeting life, yet lasting long.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A farmer's wife, both young and gay,'

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
In shadows deep where silence calls,
And weary hearts entangle in doubt,
There stands a light that never falls—
A haven when the storms rage out.

God is the refuge of His saints,
A fortress built on ancient stone;
No tempest breaks His firm restraints,
No fear can claim His own, His own.

When footsteps falter on the steep,
And tears like evening rain descend,
He wakes the promises He keeps,
And calls the broken to amend.

Not in the thunder, nor the flame,
But in the whisper, soft and near—
He speaks His love, unearned, unclaimed,
And calms the soul with holy fear.

So let the world spin wild and wide,
Let mountains crumble into sea;
The saints shall rest in Him, their guide,
For none who trust are lost, but free.

Beneath the weight of endless skies,
Where stars grow dim and courage dies,
A quiet voice, both deep and near,
Whispers hope to those who hear.

God is the refuge of His saints,
Not carved in stone, but breathed in grace,
A shelter built on sacred plaints,
A warm embrace in time and space.

No storm can shake the peace He gives,
No night too long for His dawn,
In every heart that trusts and lives,
His quiet strength is clearly drawn.

The orphan, widow, broken man,
The lost who weep along the way,
Are held within His mighty hand,
And welcomed into endless day.

So when the world turns cold and grim,
And sorrows coil like thorny vines,
He lifts the soul, restores the dim—
God is the refuge, love divine.

When shadows stretch and courage fades,
And sorrow sings its mournful tune,
When hope is lost in darkened glades,
And night outlasts the waning moon—

God is the refuge of His saints,
A harbor strong against the gale,
Where every soul, though torn and faints,
May lift its eyes and will not fail.

Not in the sword or shield of men,
Nor in the vaults of gold or fame,
But in the cross, the pierced hand’s ken,
Eternal love has claimed His name.

The meek shall lean upon His breast,
The weary find their longed-for rest,
For He who shaped the sky and sea
Now guards the least of these with glee.

No power, death, nor depth, nor height,
Shall steal the child from Father’s sight.

In quiet hush of morning’s birth,
Or when the evening fades to gray,
There flows a current through the earth—
A love that will not drift away.

God is the refuge of His saints,
A river deep, both calm and wide,
Where every heart that sorrow taints
May wash in grace and step inside.

No chain of sin, no guilt’s dark stain,
Can stand before His mercy’s flame.
He calls the lost, relieves the pain,
And speaks each soul’s true, given name.

The mountain may dissolve to dust,
The oceans roar and then recede,
But He remains in steadfast trust,
The soul’s true home, the soul’s true need.

So let the tempest howl and shake,
His arms are strong. His love won’t break.

When silence screams and shadows creep,
And faith feels thin as morning frost,
When promises seem fast asleep,
And all the world has counted lost—

God is the refuge of His saints,
A lamp that burns through longest night,
A hand that lifts, that gently slants
The scales of justice, makes them right.

Not in the rush of crowded streets,
Nor in the halls of power’s pride,
But in the hush where sorrow meets
A Savior who has died, who died.

The widow’s cry, the orphan’s tear,
The prisoner’s unmarked, hidden plea—
He hears each one, draws ever near,
And sets the bound soul free.

So trust the One whose love won’t end;
Your refuge is, and will, your Friend.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:

The saints draw near, and find the Presence near,

Can break the bond that grace has firmly sealed.
In every cry, in every burdened prayer,
His voice responds—the Rock that will not yield.

Not by their strength, but by a love divine;
In every storm, they know they are blessed,
For mercy flows like water, rich as wine.
No sword can pierce this fortress made of grace,
No lie can shake the truth that holds them fast.
In every age, in every time and place,
The Lord remains the shelter meant to last.
So lift your eyes when darkness hides the sun—

O steadfast Light when all the world turns dim,
O quiet voice when thunder fills the air,
You are the shelter built on holy hymn,
The breath of life, the answer to our prayer.
Your arms, like mountains, rise against the night,
Your love, a river flowing ever true.
In deepest pain, in absence of all sight,
Your presence speaks: 'I am with you.'
No storm can reach the peace that You impart,
No grief endure beyond Your healing hand.
You guard each soul, protect each faithful heart,
And lift the fallen by Your gentle plan.
So let the earth be shaken, let it spin—
God is the refuge where new life begins.

When shadows fall and hope begins to fade,
And sorrow walks where joy once used to tread,
There is a name that time cannot degrade,
A throne of grace where saints lay down their dread.
Not made of stone, nor raised by human hand,

This refuge stands in every troubled land,
A fire of love that darkness can’t obscure.
Through ancient days and ages yet to be,
The faithful flee to Him and find their rest.
No power on earth, no force beneath the sea,
Can break the peace that flows from His behest.
So come, O soul, when trials press you down—
God is the refuge of His saints, renowned.

A whisper in the whirlwind, soft and clear,
A harbor where the lost at last belong,
God draws the saints through suffering and fear,
And wraps them in the shelter of His song.
No fortress strong, no castle on a hill,
Could match the safety of His open hand.
He knows each tear, each unrelenting ill,
And lifts the soul to stand on holy land.
Though nations rage and stars from heaven fall,
Though every dream dissolve to dust and ash,
He is the refuge, constant through it all,
The one true home where weary spirits dash.
So let the storm rage on with all its might—
God is the refuge, and His saints take flight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:

When night descends with sorrow in its breath,

God is the refuge of His saints, a shield

A spring in desert, a celestial field
Where hope takes root beneath unclouded skies.
Not made of stone, nor guarded by a sword,
But built on grace that neither bends nor breaks,
His love a flame no darkness can afford
To touch, and every burden from it takes.
So let the winds howl, let the mountains fall—

In every age, when trials rise like flame,

When silence speaks and all the world is cold,

His arms, not walls, define the sacred space

A whisper stirs where lonely hearts have cried,

No storm can breach the sanctuary He lends,

To rise anew where broken hope descends.
He does not sleep, nor turn His face away,
But guards each soul as treasures guarded well;
Through fire and flood, He makes the pathway stay,
And writes their names where death itself must fell.
So saints endure, not by their strength, but His—
