When the world turns cold and cruel,
And hearts grow faint with silent dread,
God is the refuge of His saints,
A living stream where dreams are fed.

No fortress built of steel or stone
Could stand as firm, as deep, as true,
As He who sits on heaven’s throne,
Whose love renews and makes things new.

He knows the path each soul has trod,
The tears that fall, the silent plea,
And lifts the broken to their God,
With arms outstretched eternally.

No storm can breach His quiet grace,
No night endure against His day.
In every trial, in every place,
His saints in Him are kept at bay.

So let the winds of sorrow blow,
Let darkness gather, thick and deep—
He is the peace the faithful know,
The promise that the soul will keep.

Upon the edge of endless time,
Where echoes fade and silence grows,
God is the refuge of His saints,
The root from which all healing flows.

Not in the clamor, not in might,
But in the hush where prayers take flight.

He does not shout, nor shake the ground,
Yet every breath is held in Him.
No single soul is lost, unbound—
Each thread is woven, firm and trim.

When shadows press and courage fails,
And doubt would steal the light of morn,
He lifts the weak, He rights the scales,
A refuge not of place, but sworn.

No wall too high, no depth too far,
Can keep the saint from His embrace.
He is the morning, He the star,
The sanctuary, the resting place.

So saints may walk through fire and flood,
For He, their God, is ever near—
A constant, everlasting good,
The One who calms each silent fear.

When thunder rolls across the sky,
And every hope seems swept away,
God is the refuge of His saints,
The light that turns the night to day.

No sword can pierce His covering,
No lie endure beneath His gaze.
He is the well from which we spring,
The fire that burns through darkest haze.

He does not slumber, does not sleep,
But watches every sacred name.
His promises run deep, run steep,
And none who trust will know such shame.

The world may rage, the mountains shake,
The seas may roar with fury wild—
Yet in His arms, no soul will break,
For He sustains His chosen child.

So let the storm exalt its voice,
Let chaos dance and shadows play.
His saints rejoice, they have no choice,
For God is refuge—come what may.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
Beneath the weight of skies that groan with storm,
Where thunder chants a dirge of ancient fear,
There stands a hush—a shelter, strong and warm—
Where trembling saints in silent faith draw near.
Not built of stone, nor guarded by the sword,
But woven from the breath of love divine,
A fortress not by mortal hands restored,
But whispered forth where grace and mercy twine.
For when the world grows cold and hearts grow faint,
And shadows stretch like wolves across the plain,
A voice, like wind through olive trees, will paint
The dark with peace no earthly power can feign.
God is the refuge of His saints, they say,
And in that truth, the soul finds its way.

When night descends with claws of doubt and dread,
And sorrows rise like tides against the shore,
The saints recall the words once softly said:
'God is the refuge of His saints,' no more
Shall they be lost, nor left to face alone
The howling void where hope seems torn apart.
For in the hush, a Presence gently known
Upholds the weary, mends the broken heart.
No fortress tall, no citadel of steel,
But arms outstretched upon a rugged tree,
A love that will not waver, will not yield,
A sanctuary built on mercy’s plea.
So let the tempest rage and darkness call—
They cannot shake the One who shelters all.

When mountains shake and oceans overflow,
When time itself appears to fray and fall,
The saints still stand, though all around them go,
Because they lean upon the Lord of all.
God is the refuge of His saints, a rock,
A hidden stream where weary souls may drink,
The steady hand that guides through smoke and shock,
The whispered word that makes the broken think:
Perhaps, despite the chaos and the pain,
There is a love that holds them in the storm.
And so they rise, again, again, again,
Not by their strength, but by a faithful norm.
For in His presence, fear begins to cease—
God is their peace, their life, their lasting lease.

In quiet glens where prayer takes root in dew,
And hearts like wounded birds still seek the sky,
A promise hums the ancient echoes through:
'God is the refuge of His saints'—and why?
Because the world is sharp and full of thorn,
Because the night is long and hope may fade,
He opens wide His arms at break of morn,
A shelter built where light and love are made.
No storm can breach the safety of His name,
No grief too deep for mercy to restore.
He calls the outcast, whispers every saint:
'You are not lost; I am your door, your shore.'
So let the earth give way, the stars grow dim—
The refuge stands, and calls them back to Him.

When silence speaks and shadows start to flee,
When breath is prayer and stillness sings His name,
The saints remember where their hearts are free:
God is the refuge from the wind and flame.
Not carved from wood, nor raised on human plan,
But born of grace that flows from endless light,
A haven shaped by the eternal Man,
Who walks with those who walk the edge of night.
He does not shout, but breathes a gentle 'Here,'
A hand to hold when every path is lost.
In every tear, in every whispered fear,
He bears the cross where every soul is crossed.
So let the world collapse, let kingdoms cease—
God is the refuge, and His arms release.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, 
beneath the quilt of night, nowhere to bide 
but deep within the hollows of her mind, 
where silence wraps like ivy, thick and blind. 
She folds her hands and breathes into the dark, 
a quiet war against the world’s harsh spark. 
The phone glows soft with words she won’t reply, 
the clock ticks on, indifferent to her sigh. 
Not broken—no—but weary to the bone, 
she guards the tender ache she calls her own. 
No need for rescue, nor for grand design, 
just space enough to simply not be fine. 
She dreams of forests dense with muffled sound, 
of tree roots cradling her to the ground. 
And when at last she rises, slow and worn, 
the morning finds her softer, newly born.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, 
behind closed blinds and books she won’t read, 
in corners where the light forgets to glide. 
She sips her tea and lets the minutes bleed. 
No tragedy, no crisis, just a need 
to vanish from the roles she’s asked to play—
the daughter, friend, the one who plants the seed 
of calm in others at the close of day. 
She’s tired of smiling when she doesn’t feel, 
of offering strength she’s borrowing on loan. 
Here, in the hush, her fractured thoughts can heal, 
untethered and unclaimed, she’s not alone. 
For solitude is not defeat or flight, 
but sanctuary found in quiet night.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, 
like leaves that curl before the coming storm, 
retreating inward, nowhere left to bide, 
seeking shelter from affection warm. 
Not hate, but overflow—too much to be 
seen, touched, expected, known. She longs to cease. 
To fold into herself completely, free 
from motion, voice, the weight of peace. 
A blanket fort, a journal locked with string, 
the hum of rain against the windowpane. 
In these small acts, her spirit starts to sing 
a lullaby devoid of joy or pain. 
She isn’t lost—she’s choosing not to show. 
Sometimes to hide is how the quiet grow.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, 
not from danger, nor from shame, 
but from the noise that swallows peace inside, 
from calling every ache by name. 
She crawls beneath the sheets, pulls down the shade, 
ignores the text, the ring, the knock. 
No explanations ever need be made—
she’s weathering a different kind of shock. 
The world insists that feeling means to share, 
to speak, to rise, to push, to fight. 
But she knows healing sometimes lives in air 
that no one breathes but her on sleepless night. 
She isn’t broken. She’s in tending mode. 
Sometimes to hide is bearing love’s hard code.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, 
in coat pockets, in train rides with no end, 
in fiction worlds where she can’t be denied 
the right to drift, to pause, to bend. 
She’s not unloved, nor lonely in the strictest sense, 
but full—to bursting—with the weight of now. 
Each smile, each task, each social recompense 
feels like a debt upon her quiet brow. 
So she retreats, not running, just arriving 
at some internal cave where no one knocks. 
Here, thoughts like birds stop briefly, softly, leaving 
feathers of calm among the ticking clocks. 
She’ll reappear when inner tides subside. 
Sometimes to hide is to abide.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text: Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, beneath the hush where shadows glide. Beneath the bed, behind the door, where silence wears a velvet core. She folds herself in linen sheets, where no one hears her muffled breath, where clocks forget the shape of time and moonlight dims to match her rhyme. The world outside insists on sound—bright laughter, calls, demands unbound. But here, in corners no one sees, she breathes in dark, she bends the breeze. Not broken, not afraid, just small, a quiet pulse behind the wall. She isn’t lost, she isn’t gone—just gathering the light at dawn. For though she hides, she does not flee; she gathers strength beneath the tree. And when she rises, soft and slow, the world will never quite know how such stillness holds a thunderous glow.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, wrapped in coats too wide, in alleyways where streetlights die, beneath the weight of open sky. Not from sorrow, not from shame, but from the noise, the endless name—called, wanted, seen, defined. She seeks the hush, the unassigned. A bench at dawn, a library stair, the pause between breath and prayer. No cave, no lock, just space to be unseen, unfound, unclaimed. Not broken, just too deeply known. She hides to feel her bones, to hear the hum beneath the rush, the truth that whispers, not in hush. And when she walks back into view, she carries silence, deep and true—like roots beneath a flowering tree, she hides so she can finally be.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, to slip between the cracks of light, to vanish where the edges fray, and no one thinks to look her way. Not out of fear, nor guilt, nor shame, but from the ache of being named—daughter, friend, the one who copes, the smile that stretches past its hope. She hides to find the girl she was before the world drew lines in sand. Beneath the quilt, behind the book, in midnight’s soft, forgiving nook. She breathes. She is. She does not speak. The stars above do not seek. And in that hush, that gentle flight, she guards the embers of her light. For hiding isn’t running far—it’s holding fast to who you are. And when she steps back into view, she brings the quiet, deep and true.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, to fold into the afternoon’s long sigh, to let the curtains swallow sound, and let her thoughts drift underground. Not because she’s sad or scared, but because the world is overaired—too bright, too loud, too quick to judge, too eager, always, to adjust. She hides to feel the weight of air untainted by demand or care. A closet, car, a bathroom stall—anywhere she fits, and all. She counts her breaths, she hums a tone, she makes herself a quiet throne. And in that space, so thin, so brief, she finds a kind of sweet relief. Not running from, but turning in, to nurse the flame beneath her skin. She hides not to disappear, but to reappear, clear, sincere.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, to dissolve into the wall, to become the shadow on the stair, the breath that no one sees or hears. No drama, no collapse—just need for space without a map. She slips behind the washing machine, beneath the porch, inside a dream. Not broken, just full—overflowing with things unsaid, with masks worn thin, with love that costs to always win. She hides to hear her own name fall from her lips, unshaped by call. To sit with thoughts that have no end, to be the girl, not just the friend. And when she comes, she comes anew—carrying silence, calm, and due. A fortress built of air and night returns her, whole, to morning’s light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath the floorboards, out of sight,
Where shadows gather, soft and wide,
And silence wraps her like the night.
She folds into the closet’s gloom,
A coat of breathless, aching air,
Escaping every pointed room,
And all the voices waiting there.
She dreams of caves beneath the hill,
Where roots and echoes twist and twine,
No need to answer, no will,
Just moss and time and hush and pine.
But dawn still finds her at the sill,
Eyes red, but open, letting in
The world that calls with steady will—
She breathes, and steps back into skin.
Not broken, though she’s often bent,
She hides, then reappears—content.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
In linen closets, under beds,
Where no one asks, where none decide
The shape her quiet heart should tread.
She craves the hush behind the wall,
The space between the ticking clocks,
Where no demands can reach at all,
And time forgets its steady knocks.
She folds herself in paper thin,
A note unsent, a name erased,
Letting the world believe her kin
With laughter, strength, a steady face.
But in the dark, she learns to breathe,
To curl like roots beneath the snow,
To be the silence underneath,
The unlit ember’s steady glow.
And when she rises, worn but whole,
She carries peace from that deep hold—
Not running, not escaping, no,
But gathering strength in being stowed.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath the sheets, behind the door,
To let the world just slip aside,
And not be needed anymore.
She dreams of burrows, deep and warm,
Of foxes curled in hollow trees,
Of oceans hushed in coral form,
Of mountains breathing silently.
She doesn’t hate, nor does she blame,
She simply needs to disappear,
To mute the fire behind her name,
To vanish for a day, a year.
But kindness knocks, a gentle sound,
A cup of tea, a hand, a word,
And slowly, from the dark, she’s found,
Not broken, but by love deferred.
She hides to heal, not to be lost,
Then reemerges, soft, aware—
A woman shaped by quiet cost,
Who hides, but chooses to be there.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
In static hums and basement light,
Where no one sees the other side,
The cracks that bloom from silent night.
She’d trade her skin for shadow’s ease,
For walls that hold without demand,
To sway like weeds beneath the breeze,
Unseen, unclaimed, ungoverned land.
She’d be the dust upon the shelf,
The book unread, the song unsung,
The quiet pulse behind herself,
The place where no one stays too long.
But life insists with morning’s glare,
With ringing phones and children’s cries,
And though she longs to disappear,
She meets the day with tired eyes.
Not weak, but worn from holding tight,
She hides to keep her soul intact—
A breath, a pause, a need for night,
Then love recalls her, drawn back.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
In train stations at 3 a.m.,
Where strangers pass with nowhere stride,
And no one asks her name.
She’d vanish into subway steam,
A silhouette without a past,
A whisper lost within a dream,
A shadow built to last.
She’d shed the weight of expectation’s frame,
Step out of roles like outworn shoes,
Forget the rules, the guilt, the shame,
And live where no one chooses.
But still, she finds a reason near—
A cat that waits, a blooming tree,
A voice that says, "I’m glad you're here," 
And so she stays, though part of her flees.
She hides in thoughts, in books, in rain,
In music low and rooms half-lit,
Escapes again and yet again,
But always—always—comes back to it.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, 
to fold herself beneath the floorboard's sigh, 
where light forgets the shape of her eyes 
and silence wraps her like a tide. 
She gathers shadows like old friends, 
threads them through her trembling hands, 
builds a cave from unspoken words 
and vanishes where no one stirs. 
Not broken—just too full, too seen, 
her heart a storm in flannel sleeves, etreating where the world’s not keen 
on all the truth her breath believes. 
She doesn’t need to be found, 
just let the quiet hold its ground.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, 
not from fear, but from the noise—
the endless buzz of eyes that pry, 
the weight of voices without choice. 
She slips behind the curtain of her thoughts, 
where colors bloom in muted grace, 
where time dissolves and judgment halts, 
and sorrow finds its resting place. 
Here, in the hush beneath the stairs, 
she draws the dark like a favorite quilt, 
lets grief and dreams untangle their hairs, 
and breathes a breath that feels exiled,ilt. 
She isn’t lost, just gathering light 
to face the world another night.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, 
burrow deep where roots converse, 
where moonlight can’t pierce the pride 
of earth that guards a softer verse. 
She sheds her skin of smiles and nods, 
the 'I’m fine' that cracks at dawn, 
and lets the quiet lap her thoughts 
like waves that carry no one on. 
No guilt for vanishing, no shame—
just need, like hunger, like the rain. 
She isn’t fleeing, only breathing, 
letting her soul do its slow healing. 
And when she climbs back into view, 
she’ll wear the peace the shadows knew.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, 
not to escape, but to exist 
without the weight of being eyed, 
without the ache of being missed. 
She curls inside the hollow of a tree, 
or feigns a smile, stays in the room, 
lets stillness hum her symphony, 
a quiet bloom beneath the gloom. 
Her silence isn’t empty space—
it’s full of prayers and half-formed art, 
of memories she can’t erase, 
and dreams too fragile for the heart. 
She hides not to disappear, 
but to reappear, clear.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide, 
under blankets, behind books, 
from the chaos rushing wide, 
from the pain that hooks. 
She dims the lights, turns off the phone, 
lets the world believe she’s gone. 
But in the dark, she’s wide awake, 
writing poems no one will take. 
She hides to feel, to sort, to mend, 
to be a shadow, not a friend. 
Not forever—just for now—
a silent bow, a furrowed brow. 
She hides because she cares too much, 
and sometimes, love is touch too much.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath the floorboards, far and wide.
Not from the storm, nor thunder's crack,
But from the weight of all she can't take back.
She folds herself into the closet's gloom,
Where silence blooms like funeral plumes.
Her breath a hush, her pulse a thread,
A living girl believed long dead.
She dreams of trees with hollow trunks,
Where no one calls, where no one runs.
Just moss and mist and muffled sound,
And roots that wrap her safe around.
She doesn’t hate the world outside—
It’s just too loud, too sharp, too wide.
A single touch might make her shatter,
So she retreats to what is matter:
The wall, the dark, the quiet hum,
The solace that the shadows drum.
And though she knows she must return,
Her skin once more for others to burn,
She lingers here, where no one sees,
The quiet war inside her knees,
The tremor in her throat, the sigh—
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like a secret the moon keeps when stars won't confide.
She gathers shadows like shawls at her back,
Tucks her voice into a tobacco sack.
She slips through cracks in the kitchen wall,
Where dust bunnies dance and old echoes call.
No name, no face, just a shape in the gloom,
A whisper that fades before it can bloom.
She isn’t broken, just built for retreat,
A heartbeat wrapped in layers discreet.
The world demands a smile, a song,
But she's been quiet for far too long.
Not sad, not mad—just deeply worn,
Like lace unraveling at the storm.
She hides not to vanish, but to be,
A self untouched by urgency.
In silence, she finds her truest sound,
A peace profound, without a crown.
So let her vanish, let her glide—
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Not from danger, not from pride,
But from the constant, buzzing light
That claws at her with hungry might.
She folds into the corner’s crease,
A paper crane that seeks release.
Her fingers trace the cold, bare wall,
As if to build a fortress, small.
She isn't running from a face,
But from the ache of too much space—
Too many eyes, too loud a tone,
A world that won’t leave her alone.
She dreams of caves beneath the sea,
Where pressure holds her tenderly.
No names, no tasks, no roles to play,
Just breath and dark and drift away.
She hides to feel, not to forget,
To gather all she can’t have said.
And though she’ll rise, rejoin, comply,
Beneath her skin, the impulse sighs—
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like a fox in brambles, nowhere to bide
But deep within where thistles grow
And no soft hand will ever know.
She isn’t lost, she isn’t ill—
Just tired of wearing what they will.
The mask, the laugh, the nod, the grace,
A practiced smile on a weary face.
She crawls beneath the porch at dawn,
Where spiderwebs and silence yawn.
No need for words, no need to try,
Just earth and root and muffled sky.
She hides not out of fear or shame,
But to reclaim her quiet name.
A name not called, a self unshown,
A heart that beats for itself alone.
She’ll reappear when night recedes,
With folded hands and loosened needs.
But in the hush where shadows glide,
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Tuck herself where thoughts subside.
Not in anger, not in shame,
But to breathe without a name.
She slips beneath the sofa's edge,
Where dust collects like childhood pledge.
No need for air, no need for sound,
Just the pulse beneath the ground.
She isn't broken, just too real,
A wound that time won’t fully heal.
The world is sharp, too bright, too near,
And kindness sometimes stings like fear.
So she retreats to where it's thin—
The space between what’s out and in.
A breath held long, a door ajar,
The ghost-light of a fallen star.
She knows she’ll rise, she knows she’ll speak,
But for now, the shadows are meek.
They ask no questions, judge no side—
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath the weight of skies too wide.
Not from fear, nor from shame,
But the world speaks too loud, too the same.
She folds into corners where silence is kind,
Wraps shadows like blankets around her mind.
Not broken, not lost—just needing to cease
The constant demand to be loud, to be seen.
Her breath slows to match the hush of the trees,
Eyes closed to the ache of forced symphonies.
In stillness, she finds her truest disguise,
A sanctuary woven from starless nights.
Here, no roles to play, no words to defend,
Just the pulse of a soul that refuses to bend.
And though she returns, with a smile softly spread,
A part of her stays where the quiet was bred.
For hiding is not surrender or flight,
But gathering strength in the depth of the night.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To dissolve in the hush where thoughts coincide.
Not from sorrow, nor from pain,
But the noise of living drives her insane.
She slips behind curtains of memory and mist,
Where even her name is no longer insisted.
No gaze to meet, no mask to wear,
Just the whisper of wind through unspoken prayer.
Her fingers trace edges of forgotten rooms,
Lit by moonlight and ancient gloom.
Here, she is neither wrong nor right,
Only breath, and dark, and soft respite.
She isn’t running—she’s coming home,
To a place where she’s finally free to be alone.
And when she emerges, brushed by dawn’s gold,
She carries the calm that the quiet once told.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To vanish like smoke on the other side
Of a world that demands too much, too fast,
Where every moment is meant to last
Only as long as it's seen, as it's shared.
So she seeks out the cracks, the unguarded, the bare.
Under stairs, in the woods, behind books on the shelf,
She tucks herself gently, preserving herself.
Not because she’s afraid, but because she’s aware—
That light needs shadow, and sound needs air.
She breathes in the hush, exhales all disguise,
And in that breath, she recognizes her size:
Not small, not broken, but deep and wide,
Like an ocean retreating before the tide.
She hides not to disappear, but to be
The quiet truth beneath what she must seem.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To slip through the world like a secret inside.
Not from love, not from care,
But from the weight of always being there.
Present. Alert. Smiling. Fine.
So she dreams of a cave, a nook, a sign
That says, "Do not enter," written in dust,
Where silence is sovereign and time turns to rust.
She imagines her bones learning how to rest,
Her mind unknitting its constant quest.
No notifications, no names, no roles,
Just the rhythm of breath and the hush of her soul.
And though she returns when the world calls her name,
A quiet ember still burns, untouched by flame.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold into earth, to melt into tide.
Not from pain, but from too much light,
From days that stretch too long, too bright.
She longs for the hush beneath roots and stone,
Where even her heartbeat feels like its own.
No expectations, no eyes to meet,
Just the comfort of darkness, thick and sweet.
She isn’t lost—she’s gathering in,
Pulling pieces back from the world’s loud din.
In the quiet, she remembers who she was
Before the world needed to name and classify.
And when she returns, she carries the shade,
A softness within that won’t be unmade.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text: And when, in the city in which I love you, / the streetlamps flicker like hesitant hearts, / I trace your name in fogged café windows— / a secret the morning will erase. / The tram lines hum your rhythm, / and pigeons scatter like unspoken vows. / Each alley echoes with your laughter, / a melody tangled in scaffolding and rain. / I love you in the rush of midnight trains, / in the hush between sirens, in the breath / before a stranger says your name. / This city is not stone and steel, / but the pulse beneath my palms as I press them / to the pavement, feeling you move through it— / a current in the wires, a shadow in the glass. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I close my eyes, I don’t see darkness— / I see the glow of a thousand lit windows, / each one a room where you might be.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / the bridges sigh under the weight of headlights, / I remember how your voice softens at dusk, / like the glow that wraps the riverbank. / We walked where the old clock tower chimes, / your hand in mine, a quiet rebellion. / Now, even in crowds, I find your absence— / a hollow in the wind, a pause in the song. / This city maps your memory: / the bench where we kissed in October, / the bakery with the crooked sign, / the rooftop where we watched the stars fade. / I love you in every language the street signs speak, / in the scent of rain on hot pavement, / in the way strangers’ eyes sometimes / mirror the color of yours. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I turn a corner and almost see you— / that ache is the purest form of devotion.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / the neon signs stutter like uncertain promises, / I walk the same streets we once wandered, / now foreign beneath my feet. / The noodle shop still plays that song, / the one you danced to with chopsticks as microphones. / I order your favorite, though I don’t like spice— / each bite a tribute, a slow burn. / I love you in the way the rain slicks the pavement, / reflecting fractured lights like shattered vows. / In the subway’s echo, I hear your laughter, / brief and bright as a match struck in the dark. / This city holds your ghost in every doorway, / in the curve of a bench, in the hum of escalators. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I whisper your name into my scarf— / the wind carries it, maybe to you, / or maybe just into the endless, aching sky.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / the clouds press low like unopened letters, / I climb the fire escape to our old view— / a skyline stitched with memory. / Your shadow lingers on the bricks, / a silhouette in the grime of years. / I love you in the rust of railings, / in the graffiti that blooms like wildflowers. / The bodega cat still naps in the sun, / indifferent to time, to loss, to love. / I buy a soda, the kind you stole once, / and leave a coin too big for forgiveness. / This city breathes you in its alleys, / exhales you in taxi horns and distant sirens. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I sit on the edge and dangle my feet— / the wind tugs at my coat like a child, / asking, pleading: stay, remember, stay.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / the fog rolls in like a thief of edges, / I walk without direction, guided only / by the echo of your footsteps in my chest. / The river mirrors nothing tonight— / just gray on gray, like a photograph / of a place we never visited together. / I love you in the silence between buses, / in the steam rising from manholes, / in the way the world softens / when I imagine you beside me. / This city was never ours, / yet every corner holds a 'what if' / like a coin in a fountain. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I stop beneath a broken streetlamp, / I let the dark gather around me— / not as absence, but as a kind of prayer.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text: And when, in the city in which I love you, / The streetlights hum beneath a bruised sky, / I trace your name on fogged café windows, / Where steam curls like secrets we let die. / The subway rattles, a distant heartbeat, / Each station echoing what we once were— / A laugh caught in a crowded corridor, / A glance that lasted just past the blur. / Brick walls wear our shadows like old coats, / Worn thin by seasons we never named. / I pass the bench where you almost held me, / And wonder if love is just timing, re-framed. / The city breathes with a thousand stories, / But mine is silent, wrapped in your ghost. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I walk alone, I love you the most.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / Rain slicks the pavement with silver regret, / I follow echoes down narrow alleyways, / Where silence wears your silhouette. / Neon signs blink in indifferent code, / While I speak your name to the hollow air. / Each lamppost marks a moment lost, / A breath we shared, dissolved somewhere. / The bridges arch like unanswered prayers, / Stretching across rivers of memory and rust. / I board every train that might carry me home, / But home is a place I can't adjust. / Skyscrapers loom with cold precision, / Their windows dark, or too brightly lit— / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I forget your face, I forget it.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The dawn cracks open like a shy confession, / I watch the baker sweep flour into art, / And imagine your hands in that soft impression. / Pigeons scatter like notes we never sent, / Fluttering above our unspoken vows. / The tram lines stretch like silver threads, / Sewing the hours with mechanical bows. / I buy a coffee just how you liked it, / Black and bitter, and let it go cold. / The barista smiles, but doesn’t know— / This cup is a ritual, tender and old. / Somewhere, a saxophone weeps on a corner, / Playing a tune we might have danced to. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I breathe, I love you. I do. I do.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The clocks all stutter and time stands still, / I stand where we parted, on cracked sidewalk, / Beneath a billboard with a broken will. / The wind carries scraps of yesterday’s song— / A melody tangled in telephone wires. / I count the stars that the smog lets through, / Ignoring their cold, indifferent fires. / Your favorite bookstore has closed its doors, / Replaced by glass and a name I don’t know. / Progress grinds memory into dust, / But I keep what the bulldozers couldn’t mow. / I whisper to walls, to trees, to the rain, / To anything that might carry a trace— / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I vanish, I’ll still love this place.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The moon hangs low like a forgotten key, / I climb the fire escape to our old roof, / Where constellations used to align with me. / The skyline pulses—a mechanical heart— / While mine beats uneven, stuck on your name. / I spread my arms, not to fly, but to feel / The wind that once carried our shared, fleeting flame. / A siren wails like a distant goodbye, / And I answer it with silence, deep and wide. / The stars blink once, as if in reply, / To the love that lives where we used to reside. / I close my eyes and let the night speak— / Not in words, but in warmth and in hue. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / The world forgets, I remember you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text: And when, in the city in which I love you, / The streetlamps hum their amber lullaby, / I trace your name in steam on subway glass, / A breath, a ghost, a syllable of sky. / The taxis blur like fireflies in rain, / Their headlights stitching stories through the night, / While in my chest, a compass spins in vain— / True north is where your quiet footsteps light. / We never spoke of forever, not in words, / But in the pause between a train’s arrival, / In coffee rings on pages of half-read books, / In how your silence felt like revival. / And when the dawn unbuttons its gray coat, / And pigeons scribble prayers on cold concrete, / I still believe—though distance holds its note— / That love like ours refuses to retreat. / So in this city, loud with unmet glances, / I love you in the grammar of second chances.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The bridges shiver under midnight's weight, / I walk the river’s edge where echoes pool, / And call your name to seals of rust and fate. / The high-rises wear halos of pale light, / Like saints who’ve traded heaven for a view, / While lovers climb their towers out of sight— / But none, I think, as haunted as we do. / Your voice lives in the static of bus stops, / In graffiti that spells a secret vow, / In every train that leaves but never stops, / Just like the one that carried you from now. / I count the stars the smog has stolen blind, / And wonder if you see the same dark dome. / This city is a clock with tangled hands, / Ticking in rhythms we no longer call home. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I vanish—still, I do so in your name.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The rain begins its slow, insistent hush, / I stand beneath a broken awning’s edge, / Remembering the warmth of your soft blush. / Neon signs bleed color on the streets, / Translating longing into liquid light, / And every stranger’s shadow holds your shape, / A fleeting dream I almost hold too tight. / The baker locks his shop with gentle care, / The night bus driver nods as if he knows— / That love persists in corners, thin as air, / And lingers where the quiet sidewalk glows. / I pass the café where we shared one cup, / Now empty chairs face out like silent prayers. / The city breathes, and I breathe in your dust, / And love you in the absence it still bears. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I close my eyes, I find you in the sound— / The distant siren, someone’s violin, / The heartbeat of this place where you are found.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The moon hangs low above the library dome, / I write your name inside a borrowed book, / Then leave it on a bench for someone’s home. / The fountains chant in Latin I don’t know, / Their spray like memories I can’t contain, / And pigeons strut like poets full of pride, / While time rewinds to when we felt no pain. / Your laughter lives in escalator hums, / In chimes from churches with no one inside, / In how the breeze flips pages, soft and numb, / As if the world still wants you here beside. / I ride the loop where we once held hands tight, / The rails still sing our rhythm, slow and deep. / This city wears our love like second skin, / Though you have gone, and I still walk and weep. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / The stars blink once—just once—I know they mean: / That even gone, you are my constant view, / And I will love you in between each scene.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The traffic drones a hymn of rust and speed, / I watch the clouds above the courthouse spire, / And wonder if you're somewhere planting seed. / The laundromat glows blue with idle spin, / A couple argues two blocks down from here, / But I am lost in how your fingers felt, / Like summer rain on every doubt and fear. / The bodega cat still naps by sugar sacks, / The same as when you bought me mango tea. / The world moves on with such indifferent grace, / While I stay rooted, dreaming you of me. / I pass the park where we once skipped a stone, / And find the pond now frozen, still, and wide. / A single duck breaks through the fragile glass— / A crack that sounds like something we denied. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I whisper low—'I’m here'—the wind replies: / 'So am I,' in the breath between each sigh, / And love remains, though neither of us tries.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text: And when, in the city in which I love you, / the streetlights flicker like forgotten vows, / I trace your name in steam on subway glass, / where silence hums beneath the urban roar. / Each corner holds a breath we never spoke— / a café where your laughter once took flight, / a bridge where dusk confessed our quiet fears. / The city wears our echoes like a second skin, / pulsing with rhythms only hearts can hear. / Even in crowds, I find you in the stillness— / a shadow leaning toward a distant door, / a scent of rain where you once stood and smiled. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / time dissolves and every light becomes a star, / I know no map could chart the way I’ve wandered— / through alleys of memory, beneath skies of maybes— / still loving you where every road begins.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / the rain combs through the avenues like fingers, / I walk where your footsteps might have lingered, / past neon signs that spell your favorite songs. / The buses sigh, the sirens write their poems, / and I imagine you in every window, / sipping dusk from a chipped blue cup. / This metropolis, vast and unfeeling, / becomes a chapel where my love takes root— / in graffiti hearts, in shared umbrellas, / in the way a stranger’s voice recalls your tone. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / the skyline bleeds into violet surrender, / I whisper promises to the wind, / knowing you may never hear them— / yet the streets remember what I cannot say.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / the clocks all stop and silence fills the squares, / I stand where we once danced without music, / our shadows tangled on the pavement. / The buildings lean in, holding their breath, / as if the world knows this love is fragile— / a match struck in a storm, a note held too long. / Still, I return to corners soaked in memory, / where your voice once warmed the winter air. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / the stars blink through pollution and doubt, / I count them like reasons to stay— / each one a flicker of what might have been, / each one a reason to keep walking, / heart open, toward a door you left ajar.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / the trains run late and dreams go underground, / I ride the rails where your reflection fades— / a ghost in glass, a smile half-remembered. / The advertisements shout their hollow joys, / but I see only your coat in passing crowds, / only your rhythm in the drumming rain. / This city, built on steel and strangers, / bends around the shape your absence carved. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / the morning breaks with sirens and sirens, / I wake to the ache of your not-being— / yet love persists, quiet and uninvited, / like ivy cracking through concrete, / like a song that refuses to end.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / the bridges hum with the weight of departures, / I stand where we once promised forever, / beneath a sky stitched with airplane trails. / The river carries whispers we once cast— / hopes folded into paper boats, set loose. / Now, the water speaks in ripples of maybe. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / the neon blinks in colors we both loved, / I let the lights paint my skin in memory— / red for passion, blue for longing, gold for what’s lost. / This city breathes you in every season, / in autumn leaves that swirl like your hair, / in winter’s hush that sounds like your breath. / And though you're gone, I love you here— / where every street leads back to you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text: And when, in the city in which I love you, / The streetlights hum beneath a bruised sky, / I trace your name on fogged café windows, / Where steam from tea curls like a whispered lie. / Each corner holds a syllable of your voice, / Echoing down alleys where shadows entwine. / I pass the bench where we once spoke of stars, / Now cold and bare, stripped of your sign. / The buses groan with the weight of silence, / Their routes mapped with memories I can’t discard. / I find you in neon, in rain-slicked pavement, / In every hush between traffic and guard. / And though you’re gone, the city still breathes you— / A pulse beneath concrete, a beat in the dark. / So I walk, not in hope, but in quiet devotion, / Loving you fiercely, despite the stark / Truth that you left. Yet the city remembers, / And in its chaos, I’m never quite alone.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The moon hangs low like a forgotten tune, / I climb the fire escape to our old roof, / Beneath a sky stitched with stars too soon. / Your laughter lingers in rusted elevator shafts, / In the echo of heels on midnight stairs. / I pass the bodega where you bought me peaches, / Their sweetness still clinging to August air. / The subway hums with your favorite song, / A ghost in the static, a flicker of sound. / I ride the rails just to feel you near, / Though you’re miles away, or perhaps underground. / This city wraps me in your absence, / A coat lined with moments I can’t release. / Every lamppost casts your silhouette, / Every breeze whispers your quiet peace. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I close my eyes, you are all I see— / Not gone, but woven through brick and wire, / The constant heart of this place and me.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The rain begins its slow, insistent hush, / I stand beneath the awning of that theater, / Where we once kissed, untouched by the crush. / Umbrellas bloom like black mushrooms in the square, / Each one hiding a story not mine. / I watch the couples dart between taxis, / Laughing, alive, in a world that’s not ours, not now, not in time. / I find your face in the flicker of screens, / In the pause between songs on a passing car’s radio. / The city pulses with a rhythm we knew, / A beat beneath chaos, steady and slow. / I leave notes in library books we once shared, / Folded like secrets in dog-eared lines. / Perhaps someone will find them and feel what I felt— / The ache and the beauty, the yours and the mines. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / The night folds its wings and the dawn starts to rise, / I whisper your name to the waking streets, / And the city, in answer, softly replies.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The dawn cracks open like a pomegranate split, / I walk the river where the gulls cry warnings, / And the water shivers with dreams unfit. / Your shadow rides the ferry’s iron belly, / Crosses to work, though you don’t work here. / I see you in the woman with your scarf tied, / In the man who pauses, then disappears. / The park bench holds the shape of your sitting, / The coffee shop remembers your usual order. / I drink it black now, though you took it sweet— / A small rebellion, a quiet border. / The city wears your name like a second skin, / In every echo, every footfall’s refrain. / I love you not despite the distance, but because / The miles make your presence a kind of rain— / Falling unseen, yet soaking the streets, / Nourishing roots no one sees. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / I breathe, it’s your breath moving through me.

And when, in the city in which I love you, / The clocks all stop at ten past three, / I wonder if time itself has paused to listen, / To the quiet ache of missing you and me. / The pigeons scatter like pages from a journal, / The traffic halts, no honking, no sound. / Only the wind turns the pages of posters, / Faded ads for a concert we never found. / I walk past the mural where your eyes once watched me— / Painted over now, a new face in blue. / But I know where to look, beneath layers of color, / To find the old truth still shining through. / This city forgets, but I do not. / I am the archive, the keeper of traces. / Your laugh in the creak of a subway door, / The scent of your skin on rain-washed faces. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / The world holds its breath and waits for a sign, / I whisper, 'I’m here,' and the silence answers, / 'So am I,' in a voice not quite mine.

responses.text: And when, in the city in which I love you, / The streetlamps flicker like forgotten vows, / I trace your name in steam on subway glass— / A breath, a ghost, a syntax of loss. / The skyline hums a lullaby of steel, / Each window lit with someone’s quiet ache. / I walk the avenues where echoes kneel, / And gather silence for the ground we break. / Your absence is a rhythm in the rain, / A taxi’s yellow blur, a bus’s sigh. / I love you in the rush, the pause, the pain, / Beneath the bridges where the pigeons cry. / The city breathes your shadow in its seams, / In corner stores and midnight movie screens. / And when, in the city in which I love you, / The world contracts to one unspoken 'you,' / I vanish—just a comma in your view.
