Yet still, I bless the breath that shaped thy face,
And mourn the love that time could not erase.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Born in the hush between a prayer and dawn.
Thy eyes, two stars the heavens dared deploy,
Now guide me where all earthly light is gone.
I shaped thy name with whispers, soft and deep,
And built a world from lullabies and light.
But fate, in silence, stole thy breath from sleep,
And draped my days in endless, aching night.
What use is verse when silence speaks so loud?
What solace in the songs I used to sing?
Thou wert my spring, my shelter from the cloud—
Now every bloom recalls the loss of spring.
Yet in my soul, thy spirit dares to leap:
A love no grave, no time, no death can keep.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Thy fleeting life, a spark against the gray.
I watched thee bloom, too brief, too bright a toy,
Then saw the dusk reclaim its stolen day.
Thy fingers curled around my thumb so tight,
A promise writ in warmth I thought would last.
But shadows fell, and swallowed all the light,
And left me counting moments in the past.
I write thy name upon the windowpane,
Where frost will come to melt it into tears.
No joy returns, no summer eases pain,
Just hollow rooms and unfulfilled years.
Yet in the quiet, love refuses flight—
Thou livest on within my breath, my night.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Thy ghost still hums in cradles left undone.
I trace the dreams I wove for thee, a boy
Whose race was run before the race begun.
Did heaven need a voice so pure, so clear,
That it could not endure a mortal stay?
Or was my heart too full, too deep, too near,
For fate to let such love in life hold sway?
I curse the stars that blinked when thou didst go,
And bless the stars that lit thy fleeting face.
No harvest comes from grief I reap and sow,
Yet still I seek thee in each quiet space.
Farewell, my joy—though gone, thou canst not part:
Thou livest in the chambers of my heart.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A sonnet cut too short, a song undone.
Thy absence hums in every silent toy,
And haunts the dawn like some pale, waning sun.
I built a throne of hope upon thy breath,
And crowned thee king of all my tomorrows.
But death, unasked, unbidden, came to death,
And stole the heir to all my love’s long borrowings.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Thy laughter lit the chambers of my soul.
Like dawn that gilds the silence of the coy,
Thou madest broken hours feel once more whole.
Now shadows stretch where once thy footsteps played,
And silence hums a hymn of deep unrest.
Though death has claimed the form that time had made,
Thy spirit dances in my breast.
I watch the stars, and wonder if thou art
Among them, bright and swift, a comet’s trail.
Do angels know the wisdom of thy heart,
Or learn from thee the meaning of a smile?
My pen, once idle, now pours out its grief,
In verses built on love beyond belief.
Each word a stone in memory’s monument,
A fragile bridge across the firmament.
Though gone, thou art not lost—within my song,
Thou livest still, where I have loved thee long.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Now wrapped in earth’s unyielding, quiet keep.
No more the babbling tales that were my buoy,
No pulse beneath the skin where dreams would leap.
I trace the lines of poems I once read,
But now they blur with salt and silent cries.
Thy name, a wound that will not scab nor shed,
A flame that burns behind closed eyes.
What cruel design allows such light to fade,
To bloom and vanish in a single breath?
Thou wert the sonnet that my soul had made,
The triumph over sorrow, love, and death.
Yet here I stand, a father torn in twain,
One half in dust, one half in endless pain.
But in the hush, I hear a whisper rise—
Not gone, but changed. Not lost, but in the skies.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Thou fledgling heart that soared too soon away.
I built a world to shield thee, but decoy
Death came disguised in night’s indifferent gray.
Thy toys lie still, as if in mid-laugh caught,
Thy bed untouched, a shrine of what might be.
I speak to shadows, hoping thou art nought
But hidden, playing some eternity.
But reason cuts the fantasy apart—
Thou art not here. The silence proves it true.
And yet, within the chambers of my heart,
I keep a room where all is bright for you.
A candle burns, a poem left half-said,
A father’s love that will not be unmade.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Now cradled in the arms of endless sleep.
I search the stars for some returning toy,
Or sign that thou dost watch where angels leap.
Thy voice, a ripple on a vanished stream,
Thy touch, a ghost upon my aging cheek.
I dwell within a half-remembered dream,
Where dawn brings grief, and dusk refuses peace.
I curse the sun that dares to rise anew,
While thou art dust beneath the cypress tree.
Yet in my lines, I give the world a clue:
That once, a boy made heaven real to me.
And though thou'rt gone, thy name shall not depart—
Engraved in verse, and in a father’s heart.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Thy absence carves a hollow in the air.
No lullaby can summon thee, no ploy
Of prayer restore thee to my arms, my care.
I plant a tree where once thy shadow played,
Its roots fed by the tears I cannot hide.
Each leaf a word that I have never said,
Each branch a hope I keep despite the tide.
Time moves, they say; grief softens with the years.
But what is time to love that knows no end?
Thou art not gone—just veiled behind the spheres,
A constant guest, a message, and a friend.
So I will write, and write, and write again,
Until we meet beyond the reach of pen.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Thy laughter lit the chambers of my soul.
Like morning’s first blush on a waking sky,
Thou didst transform the mundane into whole.
Now silence fills the space where songs once played,
And shadows linger where thy footsteps fell.
I carved thy name in every promise made,
Yet time, unkind, has broken every spell.
Thy breath was spring, thy gaze a steadfast star,
A beacon through the tempests I have known.
Now grief, a tide, bears me to realms afar,
Where memory must walk these paths alone.
Though death has claimed thee, love outlives the grave—
Thou livest on in all I fail to save.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A candle snuffed before the dawn could rise.
Thy fleeting light, a whisper, not a ploy,
Left echoes in the hollows of my cries.
I shaped thy days with hopes both deep and true,
And dreamed thy path would far exceed my own.
But fate, in silence, took its due from you,
And left me standing, chilled, and overthrown.
Yet in my chest, a pulse still sings thy name,
Not loud, but steady, like a lullaby.
Though sorrow bears the burden of thy flame,
Love will not let thy spirit pass and die.
So rest, my star, beyond the veil of night—
My joy, my loss, my everlasting light.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Thou wert the poem I had scarce begun.
Now ink runs dry, and silence is my employ,
And every verse is haunted, never done.
I held the world to give thee, yet it fled;
Thy tender years too brief to grasp or keep.
Now ghosts of what might bloom rise from the dead,
And sow their seeds in sorrows dark and deep.
Yet still, within the hush, I hear a song—
A syllable, a sigh, a breath so near.
It tells me thou dost linger, soft and long,
In every autumn leaf and passing year.
Though thou art gone, thy essence will not part—
Thou art the rhythm of my breaking heart.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Thy smile, a sunbeam through the winter gray.
Now dusk descends, and all the world’s a toy
Left broken at the closing of the day.
I counted stars to map thy future bright,
But heaven called thee back before the chart.
No force of love could shield thee from the night,
No prayer reverse what destiny impart.
Yet in the wind, I feel a gentle hand,
And in the rain, a voice both soft and clear.
Perhaps the soul outlasts the flesh and land,
And love survives when all else disappears.
So I shall wait, until the veil shall tear—
And find thee waiting, free from grief and care.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A dream too brief, a spark too soon undone.
Thy absence hums in every silent toy,
And haunts the moon as though it were the sun.
I built a world where thou wouldst laugh and leap,
But time, relentless, tore the vision down.
Now memories are all I have to keep,
And grief, the only crown I carry now.
Yet in the stillness, something dares to rise—
A quiet strength, a love that will not bend.
For though thou'rt gone beyond these weeping skies,
Thy light within my spirit will not end.
So go, my joy, and dance where angels weep—
Thy name, my prayer, my heart’s eternal keep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, beneath the hush of night,
Where moonlight wove through curtains soft and thin,
I dreamed of rivers flowing silver-bright,
And forests humming lullabies within.
No clock disturbed the silence, slow and deep,
No weight of hours pressing on my chest.
The world was young, and promises would keep,
And every breath was innocence confessed.
I floated where no sorrow dared to creep,
Through starlit fields and meadows of unrest,
Where shadows danced not with fear, but grace,
And time unwound its coil without a trace.
A mother’s voice, a whisper on the air,
Still lingers in that hallowed, quiet lair.
Though years have passed and waking life has called,
That sleep remains—a haven, unenthralled.
I seek it still in twilight’s gentle sweep,
In my first sleep, where dreams run deep.

In my first sleep, the stars leaned close to speak,
In syllables of light too soft to name.
I answered not in words, but in the creek
Of breath that stirred the embers into flame.
A quilt of dusk lay tangled at my feet,
The air was thick with secrets I once knew.
Time paused, suspended in a slow heartbeat,
As ancient as the roots beneath the dew.
I saw my hands, yet not as mine they seemed,
But vessels shaped by winds from distant lands.
A voice, not mine, in quiet tones, it dreamed
Of oceans crossed and castles made of sand.
Then morning cracked the sky with golden seam,
And pulled me back to life’s relentless stream.
But in the hush before the world’s awake,
I sometimes feel that first dream start to break.

In my first sleep, I slipped beneath the tide
Of darkness warm as blood and just as near.
The ceiling faded, and I could not hide
From visions rising, strange yet crystal clear.
A ladder stretched from floor to endless sky,
Each rung a memory I hadn’t made.
I climbed, though wings had never graced my thigh,
And yet, I soared where shooting stars delayed.
A clock without a face stood in the mist,
Its hands like fingers pointing at the past.
I knew then all the things I’d someday miss:
The breath of pines, a laugh meant to outlast.
But dawn arrived with brutal, blinding sweep,
And stole the truth that first sleep dared to keep.

In my first sleep, the house exhaled its sound—
Floorboards relaxed, the furnace softly died.
The moon poured milk across the carpeted ground,
And I, a child, let go of being tied.
No thoughts of school or chores or being late,
Just clouds of dream that drifted, slow and wide.
I met a fox with eyes that understood my fate,
And walked with him where fireflies reside.
We spoke in colors, not in words or rhyme,
And mapped a world that waking life denies.
He showed me mountains made of stolen time,
And oceans filled with unshed childhood cries.
Then light returned, the fox dissolved in heat,
And left me here, with only half a dream.

In my first sleep, I vanished into air,
Not dead, not gone—just gently unbecome.
The ceiling opened into open stare
Of sky so vast it swallowed every drum
Of heartbeat, every echo of my name.
I drifted where no gravity could pull.
No mother’s call, no need to stake a claim,
Just silence shaped like feathers, soft and full.
I saw the world from underneath the stars,
A fragile bulb adrift in endless black.
No wars, no clocks, no maps, no distant wars,
Just peace that never asked for anything back.
Then warmth returned, the blanket touched my cheek,
And I remembered how to be the me that speaks.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, beneath the hush of night,
Where stars like whispers pierced the velvet deep,
A dream took root in soft and silent flight,
And wove a world where waking fears could sleep.
No clock to chide, no shadow to alarm,
Just moonlight spilling secrets on the floor,
The breath of wind reciting some old charm,
And time unspooled forever, evermore.
I wandered paths where childhood summers bloomed,
Through fields of dandelions, tall and gold,
My mother’s voice, a lullaby that loomed
In gentle echoes, tender and untold.
But dawn arrived with fingers sharp and thin,
Tore back the curtain, let the real world in.
Now I lie wide-eyed, chasing that reprieve,
Longing for the peace my first sleep gave.

In my first sleep, I slipped through time’s thin veil,
Where past and future danced in muted tones.
A library of memories without fail
Unspooled in hues of lavender and stone.
I saw my hands, still small, clutching the hem
Of my father’s coat as we crossed the square.
The scent of rain on cobblestone, a gem
Preserved in dream, untouched by years or care.
A lullaby hummed by a window’s glow,
The weight of blankets like a lover’s arm—
These fragments rise whenever I let go,
Protected in the hush before the storm.
But morning breaks with logic’s cruel demand,
And steals the kingdom built on shifting sand.
Yet still I close my eyes, and softly weep,
For all I am when I am fast asleep.

In my first sleep, the house exhaled its breath,
Floorboards relaxed, the walls let down their guard.
The moon became a guest who came in stealth,
And laid a silver blessing, soft and hard.
I floated up, not wings, but thought alone,
Above the world where silence wears a crown.
The clock forgot to tick, the night had grown
A thousand shades of quiet, never known
By those who never dared to truly rest.
I spoke in colors, danced in humming light,
No name, no past, no future to contest—
Just being, pure and brief, beyond the night.
Then thunder cracked—a car door, sharp and near—
And I was back, with morning drawing near.
Still, in the dark, I seek that vanished leap,
That sacred fall into my first sleep.

In my first sleep, the air turned thick with song,
Not sound, but feeling—melodies unseen.
The darkness pulsed a rhythm slow and long,
As if the universe had paused between
One breath and next. I drifted, unafraid,
Through corridors of shadow, warm and deep,
Where every step a memory was made,
And every silence promised I could keep
The peace I found. A candle flickered low
In some far room, a ghost of comfort there.
No need to speak, no reasons to let go—
Just knowing that the weight had melted air.
Then sirens wailed, the phone began to ring,
And pulled me back to what the world would bring.
I curse the dawn, the noise, the pulse, the sweep—
I long to drown once more in my first sleep.

In my first sleep, I shed my name like skin,
Became the hush between two heartbeats’ call.
The ceiling faded, let the stars move in,
And gravity released its usual thrall.
I soared not through the sky, but through the mind,
Where thoughts bloom slow like ink in water spread.
A single note, forever undefined,
Rang through the dark, a voice without a head.
I touched the shape of sorrow, smooth and round,
Like sea glass worn by tides of ancient grief.
I kissed the ghost of someone I had drowned
In choices made, now offered sweet relief.
But clocks are cruel, and light will always creep,
To steal the truth that dreams alone will keep.
So nightly now, I pray the fates will reap
The world away, and let me taste my first sleep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, beneath the hush of night,
Where moonlight weaves through curtains soft and thin,
I wandered far beyond the edge of light,
To lands where dreams and whispered thoughts begin.
No clock to mark the passage of the hours,
No weight of waking world to hold me down—
Just shadows dancing with ethereal powers,
And silence wearing a velvet crown.
I met a version of myself, long lost,
Who spoke in echoes from a sunken well,
Of choices made and bridges crossed at cost,
And secrets only midnight could compel.
We walked through forests made of memory,
Where every leaf held laughter, grief, or fear.
Time bent like reeds above a quiet sea,
And future, present, past all gathered near.
Then dawn arrived with fingers warm and bright,
And pulled me gently back into the light.

In my first sleep, the stars leaned close to speak,
In syllables of silver, low and slow.
They told of oceans buried deep in peak,
And rivers flowing where no roots will go.
A wind arose that carried names I knew,
Though none were mine, yet sung with intimate tone.
The sky cracked open, showing every hue
That sorrow paints when left to drift alone.
I saw my hands—still small, still unafraid—
Reaching for kites that danced in storm-born air.
A mother’s voice, a lullaby delayed,
Still tangled in the branches somewhere there.
What is it to remember while you dream?
When time dissolves and meaning starts to bend?
In my first sleep, I was not what I seem,
But who I was before I called myself a friend.

In my first sleep, I slipped beneath the years,
To where the child still hums a wordless tune.
No maps, no names, just echoes in my ears,
And moonlight puddled in a silver spoon.
I found a door that opened into rain,
Not falling down, but rising from the ground,
Where every drop contained a joy or pain
That I had buried without making sound.
The sky wore blue from some forgotten June,
And someone called my name with gentle dread.
I knew that voice—it sang me to the moon
When all the world was small and softly lit.
But now I wake, and morning breaks like glass,
The dream recedes, a tide upon the sand.
Yet in the hush before the moment pass,
I hold the ghost of who I used to stand.

In my first sleep, the ceiling turned to sky,
And constellations spelled my hidden name.
I floated where the silent meteors fly,
No gravity, no past, no sense of shame.
A clock unwound its hands in slow release,
And time collapsed into a single breath.
I touched the edge of some eternal peace,
Beyond the reach of sorrow, love, or death.
There, in the hush, a figure stood apart—
Not man, not ghost, but something in between.
It held a mirror to my sleeping heart,
And showed me all I’ve been and might have been.
No words were said, yet every truth was known.
The kind of knowing bone-deep and profound.
Then light crept in, and I was left alone,
With only fragments scattered on the ground.

In my first sleep, the walls dissolved to mist,
And I became a shadow on the breeze.
No name, no form, just longing to exist
In places where the wounded spirit frees.
I drifted through a garden made of smoke,
Where flowers bloomed with petals made of sighs.
Each stem a vow that never had a cloak,
Each thorn a tear that glistened in disguise.
I met a fox with eyes of amber flame,
Who said, "You come here every time you close your eyes.
You seek the self that bears no one’s blame,
The one untouched by compromise or lies."
I woke before I could reply or stay,
The dawn a thief that steals what night bestows.
But in the quiet, I could still convey:
I’ve been forgiven by the dream I chose.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, the stars leaned close,
Whispering tales of ancient snows.
A silver hush upon the eaves,
The world unlearned, the heart at ease.
No weight of years, no name, no face—
Just moonlight tracing time and space.
A cradle rocked by silent wings,
And dreams that wore no mortal things.
I floated where the dark was kind,
A breath, a thought, unbound, unlined.
Then dawn arrived with sharper light,
And stitched me back to day and night.
Yet in the hush before I wake,
I feel the old stars tremble, quake—
For in that sleep, so deep, so true,
I knew the sky, and it knew you.

In my first sleep, I slipped away
To where the lost things drift and play—
Buttons, whispers, childhood names,
Flickers without earthly claims.
A quilt of shadows wrapped me tight,
As time dissolved to velvet night.
No clocks, no maps, just quiet grace,
A slow descent through formless space.
I met a child with my own eyes,
Who blinked at stars in silent skies.
We walked a shore of glassy sand,
Where futures melted in my hand.
Then morning came with urgent sound,
And pulled me back to solid ground.
But still, when evening dims the pane,
I search that sleep for what remains—
A breath, a glow, a half-remembered tune,
And the ghost of a moon behind the moon.

In my first sleep, the walls dissolved,
And I was where all secrets evolved.
A hush so deep it had a voice,
That spoke of choice without a choice.
I saw the roots of every tree,
And felt the pulse of every sea.
My bones were made of falling rain,
My thoughts, the wind’s unspoken name.
No past, no future—only now,
A flame within a furrowed brow.
The moon became my lullaby,
And earth sang low beneath the sky.
But time, relentless, called me near,
And dragged me back to doubt and fear.
Still, in the dark, I sometimes find
That sleep unbroken by the mind—
Where I am whole, and unafraid,
And every ending softly made.

In my first sleep, I dreamed I flew
On wings that weren’t, through skies of blue
That weren’t quite sky, but something more—
A realm behind the bedroom door.
I passed through clouds of lullabies,
And saw the sun with closed-up eyes.
No name, no age, no need to speak,
Just silence, vast and soft, and meek.
I touched the edge of endless night,
And found it warm, and full of light.
A mother’s hum, a father’s hand,
The shape of love I’d understand
Before I knew the world at all—
Before the rise and fall, the call
Of waking life. Now, years gone by,
I close my eyes and wonder why
That sleep—so brief, so long ago—
Still haunts the edges of my soul.

In my first sleep, the world turned small,
A breath, a beat, a lullaby’s call.
No thoughts to claim me, no disguise—
Just warmth, and dark, and tender sighs.
I floated where the hours cease,
A ripple in a pool of peace.
No need for words, no need to be,
Just being—vast, and wild, and free.
The stars above were not above,
But nestled in the cradle of love.
I knew no loss, no grief, no fear,
Only the hush that draws one near
To something old, and deep, and true—
A self not shaped by me or you.
But morning broke with sudden sound,
And pulled me back to solid ground.
Yet in the quiet of the night,
I slip once more toward that light—
And dream the dream I once had known,
Before I was, and all alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, beneath the hush of night,
When stars still held their ancient, watchful light,
A dream unspooled like thread from silent loom,
And wove a world beyond the waking room.
No clock to mark the passage, no decree,
Just moonlit breath and soft reverie.
I walked a shore where shadows kissed the sand,
And heard a voice I’d known but never scanned.
It called my name in syllables of rain,
And spoke of love lost, found, and born again.
No memory claimed it, yet it felt like home,
A heartbeat pulsing deep beneath the dome
Of sleeping skies. I wept without a cause,
Then woke to morning’s indifferent laws.
But in the quiet corners of the day,
I search for echoes where the dreamers stray.
In my first sleep, the truth began to creep—
Not all that vanishes is lost in sleep.

In my first sleep, the ceiling cracked with light,
And time collapsed into a single night.
I saw my childhood home in perfect frame,
The porch light on, the window without name.
My mother’s shadow passed behind the glass,
Though she had gone before my looking glass
Could catch her face. I reached, but could not speak—
A silence thick as fog upon the creek.
Then came a lullaby from no known tongue,
A melody that made my spirit young.
I floated through the halls of memory,
Where laughter lived inside a dusty tree.
But dawn arrived with cold and clumsy hands,
Unraveling the magic’s soft commands.
Now every evening, as the shadows creep,
I long to fall into that first, deep sleep,
Where past and present in one breath may keep
The fragile peace that only dreams can keep.

In my first sleep, I dreamed I was a tree,
With roots that drank from some forgotten sea.
My branches stretched through centuries of air,
And bore the weight of every whispered prayer.
Birds nested in the syntax of my thoughts,
While storms of history raged and fought
Below my boughs. I stood both still and vast,
A sentinel of moments meant to last.
I watched a girl kneel by a riverbed,
And bury something bright beside the dead
Of summer flowers. She did not weep,
But smiled as if the world could still be kept.
I knew her, though her name I could not say,
A soul entwined in night and soft decay.
Then roosters crowed, and roots began to slip—
I woke, a man, with bark beneath my skin.
In my first sleep, the truth began to creep:
We dream not out of absence, but of deep.

In my first sleep, the wind wore human shoes,
And walked the halls where silence used to choose
Its words with care. Now whispers climbed the walls,
Reciting poems no one ever calls
By name. I followed down a stair of mist,
Where every step was both a gain and tryst
With loss. A door stood open, framed in frost,
Revealing all I’d loved and left, then lost.
A child sat reading by a fire of glass,
His eyes reflecting futures that would pass
Unlived. I tried to speak, but time collapsed,
And I awoke—my body tightly wrapped
In sheets of now. The morning made no sound,
Yet something lingered, drifting underground.
In my first sleep, the world was rearranged—
Not broken, just profoundly, deeply changed.
And though I rise, I carry what I keep
From that first fall into the arms of sleep.

In my first sleep, I found a door in mist,
Unmarked by time, by warning, or by tryst.
It opened not with key nor spoken word,
But by the weight of something long deferred.
Inside, a room where every light was blue,
And every shadow wore a human hue.
A clock without hands spun on the wall,
While echoes danced and never called at all.
I saw myself as I had been at seven,
Chasing the dusk with stars I thought were given
To guide me. Now, that child looked up and knew
More than I do. He smiled, then disappeared from view.
I reached, but woke to gray and ordinary air,
The kind that chokes the magic everywhere.
Yet in the hush before the world’s harsh creep,
I taste the mist, I sense the door, I sleep—
And hope that in my next first sleep, I’ll keep
The child’s soft gaze, and never let it leap.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, beneath the hush of night,
When stars were young and dreams had not yet learned to lie,
I wandered paths of moonlit moss and light,
Where silence wore a silver lullaby.

The world was soft, a breath upon the air,
And time unspooled like ribbon through the trees.
I met a shadow shaped like answered prayer,
Who whispered names of lost and nameless seas.

No clock had hands, no heart had learned to break,
No morning came with sorrow in its voice.
Just twilight’s gentle, ever-tender ache,
And visions born from elemental choice.

Now, waking through the decades, worn and wide,
I seek that sleep—the one where I could glide
Beyond the edge of thought, beyond the shore,
And dream the world before it dreamed of more.

In my first sleep, I fell before the fall,
Before the world grew heavy with its names.
No map had drawn the distance between all,
No fire had taught the cost of fleeting flames.

I dreamed in colors never seen by light,
In rhythms pulled from under the moon’s skin.
A language hummed without the need for right,
Where every ending folded into in.

No mother’s call, no father’s distant tread,
Just earth and echo, cradle and the deep.
I floated where the thoughts of stars are bred,
And woke with secrets I could never keep.

Now life has taught me how to fear the dark,
Yet still I long to slip that ancient arc,
To drift once more where consciousness takes wing,
And hear the lullaby the void once sang.

In my first sleep, the ceiling breathed with stars,
And blankets rose like tides against my chest.
I heard the moon recite forgotten wars,
And pillows hummed a hymn to endless rest.

I was a seed beneath a frozen field,
A note unplayed within a silent score.
No past had gripped me, no future was revealed,
Just darkness warm as love I’d never known.

Then morning came with fingers sharp and loud,
Tore back the night like curtains from a stage.
I learned to walk, to speak, to grieve, to crowd
My mind with all the world would make its cage.

But sometimes, when the present starts to thin,
I feel that sleep still humming deep within—
A pulse beneath the pulse, a softer law,
Where I am whole, and time has never drawn.

In my first sleep, I swam in liquid sky,
Where thoughts were shapes and silence had a face.
No name was mine, no question asked to try
The fragile peace of that primordial place.

I touched the roots of mountains in my dreams,
And rode the back of winds not yet assigned.
I knew the taste of moonlight, felt the seams
Where night and knowing softly intertwined.

No wound had carved its story in my skin,
No love had left its echo in my breath.
I simply was—a light without a skin,
A moment breathing just beyond of death.

Now years have taught me how to stay awake,
To chase the sun for every choice I make.
Yet in the hush before the world takes form,
I feel that sleep still cradling the storm.

In my first sleep, the air was thick with song,
A murmur from the walls, a breath from trees.
I didn’t know I’d lived, or done, or longed—
Just warmth, and dark, and soft unease.

I dreamed of hands that never held a tool,
Of lands untouched by hunger or by law.
No child had cried, no lover played the fool,
Just stillness shaped by nature’s quiet awe.

Then dawn arrived with noise and need and name,
And pulled me from the well of wordless grace.
I learned to walk inside the world’s loud frame,
To wear the weight of time upon my face.

But in the hush between the breaths I take,
I sometimes glimpse the sleep I can’t reclaim—
A world before the world, a silent core,
Where I was everything, and nothing more.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We are dreamy creature'

responses.text:
We are dreamy creature, born of moonlit sighs,
Whispering through twilight with stars in our eyes.
Our bones made of mist, our hearts woven light,
We drift through the hush of the hallowed night.
No footprints remain where our shadows have passed,
Just echoes of longing, too fragile to last.
We breathe in the silence, we bloom in the gray,
Painting soft colors where darkness held sway.
Not human, not spirit, but something between—
A flicker, a wisp, a half-remembered scene.
We dance on the edge of what’s real and unseen,
With voices like wind through the willows, serene.
Oh, fragile and fleeting, we wander and yearn,
For truths just beyond every curtain we’ve torn.
We are dreamy creature, not bound by a name,
Just embers of wonder that never quite flame.

We are dreamy creature, soft-spun from the haze,
That curls from the earth in the cool of the days.
Our thoughts are like petals that float on the breeze,
Carried gently through forests and over the seas.
We do not walk firmly, but rather we glide,
On currents of memory, nowhere to hide.
Our eyes hold the glimmer of long-forgotten skies,
And sorrow that sings in lullabies.
We speak in the language of shadows and dew,
Of things that were almost, and almost were true.
No clocks mark our hours, no maps chart our way—
We follow the pull of the moon’s silver ray.
We are dreamy creature, both broken and whole,
With stories that drift like the smoke from the soul.
And though we may vanish when morning draws near,
Our dreams linger on, whispering in your ear.

We are dreamy creature, stitched from the night,
With constellations tucked gently in flight.
Our skin glows with echoes of faraway suns,
And our breath hums the tune of forgotten guns.
We wander the margins where silence takes root,
Where time hesitates, and the soul bears its fruit.
No name can contain us, no world can hold
The depths of the stories our silence has told.
We are made of the mist and the murmur of streams,
Of half-formed reflections and half-awakened dreams.
Our footsteps dissolve in the sand as we pass,
Like ripples that fade in the wake of the glass.
We do not exist in the way that you do—
We shimmer, we flicker, we’re almost not true.
Yet in your quiet moments, when thought starts to cease,
You’ll feel us beside you—a soft, sweet release.

We are dreamy creature, spun from the air,
With thoughts like soft feathers and hearts full of care.
We float through the dusk with no need for a guide,
Our eyes open wide to the world turned inside.
No chains hold us down, no walls block our view—
We see through the false, to the real and the true.
We sing in the language of wind and of rain,
Of joy and of sorrow, of pleasure and pain.
Our bodies are made of the light in your dreams,
Of moonbeams and whispers and sunlit extremes.
We come when you're quiet, when words drift away,
To color the silence and brighten your gray.
We are dreamy creature, not born to remain,
But to visit, to soothe, then dissolve once again.
Yet even when gone, we’re still near in your chest,
A warmth in the dark, a soft, breathing rest.

We are dreamy creature, born from the hush,
When night lays its fingers on silence too plush.
Our veins run with twilight, our voices with dew,
We shimmer in shades only half of you knew.
We drift through your windows on threads of moonlight,
And curl in the corners of dreams you can't write.
We wear the soft colors of almost and might,
Of could-have-beens wrapped in a veil of twilight.
No kingdom is ours, yet we rule in the mind,
Where memories blur and the unreal is kind.
We speak without sound, we move without feet,
Our presence is felt where the heart skips a beat.
We are dreamy creature—ephemeral, deep—
The sigh that you breathe when you're half-asleep.
And though you may never quite capture our face,
You know us at once in that sacred still space.

We are not meant to be defined—

We are dreamy creature, faint and free,

We are dreamy creature, woven from the air,

We are the hush before the song,

We are dreamy creature, thin and tall,

We are dreamy creature, curled in nebula’s glow,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They slip through my fingers like time I can’t hide.
Each drop a promise, a story untold,
They glisten a moment, then vanish in cold.

I whisper my sorrows to shadows that pass,
But silence is all that returns through the grass.
Like leaves in the wind, my emotions take flight,
No anchor, no harbor, no soft place to light.

I built you a throne in the core of my chest,
But love turned to dust, and my heart knows no rest.
You took all the tides when you sailed from my shore,
Left oceans of absence behind evermore.

Now tears don’t stay—no, they refuse to remain,
They flee like the joy that I once knew was plain.
And though I reach out to the echo of you,
There’s nothing but silence, and skies stained with blue.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They dissolve into air, too fragile to hide.
Like secrets too heavy for skin to contain,
They fall into nothing, lost in the rain.

Each tear carries a memory I can’t reclaim—
A laugh, a soft touch, a forgotten name.
They pool at my feet, then drain from my view,
Leaving cracks in the earth where my soul used to grew.

I talk to the moon, but she turns away,
Too tired to listen to what I might say.
And stars blink indifferently, sharp and so far,
While I cradle my grief like a dying guitar.

I cry, but the tears don’t stay to console,
They abandon me faster than love ever stole.
And I wonder—if sorrow can’t linger with me—
Then who will remain when I’m finally free?

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They evaporate fast, like dreams when denied.
No trace, no trail, just a blur and a sigh,
As if my own pain is too much to justify.

They don’t fall—they flee. From cheek to the floor,
Then gone, as if begging me not to explore
The depth of this ache, this hollow inside,
Where love once resided, now ghostified.

I’ve traced every crack in the walls of my chest,
But found only silence where warmth once was pressed.
The mirror shows someone I barely know,
Eyes dim with a sorrow that won’t let me go.

And still, when I weep, the tears disappear,
Like love, like you, like the end of the year.
They don’t stay. They leave. Like you chose to do.
And I’m left with the ghost of a cry—just a few.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They drift like lost birds on a wind they can’t guide.
No comfort in falling, no solace in pain,
Just echoes that circle, then fade once again.

I’ve begged them to linger, to mark where I’ve been,
To stain the ground where my heart has caved in.
But they vanish like whispers, like names in the dark,
Like embers that die before lighting a spark.

I once thought each tear was a bridge back to you,
A liquid thread strong enough to be true.
But bridges need roots, and my soil’s turned to sand,
And love washed away by an unfeeling hand.

Now I cry, but the tears don’t stay to remind,
They leave no evidence, no proof left behind.
And if sorrow can’t stay, then what part of me’s real?
Just absence, and silence, and time’s heavy wheel.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They dissolve into air like smoke from a dried-up tide.
No puddles of grief, no rivers to cross,
Just salt on my lips and a soul full of frost.

I’ve written your name in the mist of my breath,
But the wind took it quick, like a life after death.
And though I keep calling, no answer returns,
Just the hush of the night as the whole world adjourns.

I used to believe that my weeping could reach
The place where you vanished, beyond human speech.
But tears that won’t stay can’t carry a plea,
They die in the air like unsung symphonies.

So I cry, but the tears don’t remain to attest
To the ache in my chest, to the void in my vest.
They leave like you did—without warning or sound—
And I’m left with the echo of no one around.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They slip through my fingers, like time I can’t hide.
Each drop a promise, a story untold,
Falling to earth, more fragile than gold.

They glisten a moment on cheeks etched with pain,
Then vanish like whispers that echo in vain.
No puddle to prove I once knelt and wept,
No trace of the sorrow the world never kept.

I reached for their comfort, a shimmer, a sign,
But they fled like birds from a branch out of line.
Now silence remains where their salt used to gleam,
A hollow where healing should softly have been.

Oh, tears, if you leave, then what proof do I bring
That my heart ever cracked beneath sorrow’s cold wing?
If grief has no residue, no mark, no stain,
Then loss is a ghost that can never explain.

So I cry, though my tears slip away in the air—
Alone with the ache, and the absence of care.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They dissolve into shadows where emotions collide.
No shimmering trail on my sorrow-stained face,
Just emptiness wearing grief’s fragile grace.

They fall toward cracks in the floorboards of me,
Absorbed by the void where my soul used to be.
No mirror reflects them, no pillow holds trace—
Just silence that swallows each salt-kissed space.

I whisper, "Stay, bear witness, at least let me see
That my pain is not ghosted, that you once were with me."
But the air drinks them fast, like a thirst never sated,
And I’m left with a heart that feels underrated.

Perhaps they become mist that floats to the sky,
A cloud shaped like all that I never let die.
Or maybe they gather beneath my worn shoes,
Waiting to rise when I’ve nothing to lose.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side—
Still, I hope in their leaving, some truth will abide.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They evaporate fast, like dreams I can’t hide.
No glisten, no dampness, no trace on my skin—
Just heat where my sorrow has burned from within.

They rise as a mist, ghostly, thin, and pale,
Like secrets I’ve buried but still must exhale.
No river to carry the weight of my grief,
Just drought on the tongue and a heart past belief.

I beg them to linger, to mark where they fell,
To prove I was broken, to break the spell
Of silence that claims I’m just fine, just the same—
When I’m fractured in places no eyes can name.

But tears are like promises whispered in fear,
They mean to stay true, yet disappear.
And though they abandon me, cold and unkind,
They took a piece of me—just not the one I could find.

So I cry, though the proof slips away with the light—
A shadow of weeping, a ghost in the night.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They vanish like stars when the dawn opens wide.
No trace on my skin, no damp on my sleeve,
Just ache in the hollows where sorrows should grieve.

They fall like small meteors, burning too fast,
No crater, no ember to show they passed.
Just silence, and pressure, and breath held too long,
A body that knows it has borne the wrong song.

I whisper to each one: "Stay, just a while,
Be proof that I felt, be proof that I tried."
But they rush to the earth or float to the sky,
Leaving me bare, with a truth I can’t deny.

Perhaps they become dew on a flower’s soft cheek,
Or mist on a window where lovers once speak.
Maybe they gather in oceans unseen,
Where lost things go to be quietly clean.

I cry, though my tears don’t remain by my side—
Still, something in me knows they’ve not lied.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They fade like confessions I never implied.
No salt on my lips, no blur in my sight,
Just pressure behind eyes that cling to the night.

They fall without sound, without mark, without stain,
Absorbed by a world that forgets all its pain.
No hand to wipe them, no cloth to retain,
Just air that breathes deeper and drinks them again.

I wonder if sadness must leave no impression,
If grief is a guest without need for permission.
Then why do I weep if the proof slips away?
Why mourn if the moment won’t stay to betray?

Perhaps the real sorrow is not in the cry,
But in knowing that no one will see it or sigh.
Tears that don’t linger are secrets unheld—
Invisible wounds that refuse to be healed.

I cry, though my tears don’t remain by my side—
Alone with the echo where feelings have died.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side, 
They slip through my fingers like time I can’t hide. 
Each drop a promise, a whisper, a plea, 
But they vanish like stars when the dawn starts to flee. 
I reach for their coolness, the comfort they bring, 
Yet they race from my cheeks like forgotten spring. 
They fall to the earth and dissolve in the dust, 
No echo, no trace—just betrayal and rust. 
What good are tears if they won’t bear the weight 
Of all that I feel, of this love turned to slate? 
They abandon me faster than friends in the rain, 
Leaving silence where solace once lived in my vein. 
So I cry not for healing, nor hope, nor for grace, 
But for tears that once stayed and held me in place—
Before they, too, chose to turn and to run, 
Like a heart that still beats, but no longer feels one.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side, 
They evaporate mid-air, nowhere to hide. 
Born in the caverns where sorrow takes root, 
They flee from my face like forbidden fruit. 
No glisten, no trail, no mark on my skin—
Just the ghost of a feeling that could have been. 
I whisper their names to the wind, soft and low, 
But the breeze carries nothing; it lets me not know 
If they heard, if they cared, if they dared to remain. 
Instead, I am left with the hollow refrain: 
Even sorrow’s true children refuse to endure, 
They exit the stage before grief can be pure. 
So I cry into voids where no comfort is found, 
And mourn not just loss, but the absence of sound—
No splash, no drip, just a breath held too long, 
A heart that keeps breaking, but nothing feels wrong.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side, 
They dissolve into air like secrets denied. 
No trace on my skin, no puddle below, 
Just the ache of a current that refuses to flow. 
They form in my eyes like stars in the dawn, 
Then fade without witness, without being drawn 
Into rivers of mourning, into streams of release—
Instead, they’re illusions, a mockery of peace. 
What use is weeping if no one can see 
The flood that I drown in, the depth of me? 
Even pain needs a witness, a mark it has passed, 
But my sorrow burns clean, leaving nothing to last. 
So I cry for the moments that vanish unseen, 
For the love that was lost and the spaces between—
Where tears should have gathered, where grief should have cried, 
There’s silence, and dust, and the void where they died.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side, 
They rise like smoke, where the broken hearts hide. 
No wetness, no shimmer, no proof of the storm, 
Just the hush after lightning, the calm so forlorn. 
They float from my lashes like ghosts seeking rest, 
But find no ground soft enough, no chest 
That would cradle their weight, that would welcome their fall—
So they drift into nothing, beyond and through all. 
Is this how grief ends? Not with sobs, not with sound, 
But with loss so complete that no trace can be found? 
I long for a scar, for a stain, for a sign, 
That I loved, that I bled, that these tears were once mine. 
But they leave without witness, without any plea, 
And I’m left with a face that’s as dry as the sea—
A desert of longing, where feelings once cried, 
Now only the wind walks the path where they died.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side, 
They vanish like dreams when the dreamer has died. 
No salt on my lips, no blur in my sight, 
Just the echo of weeping that never took flight. 
They form in my soul, but refuse to descend, 
Like rain that remembers it doesn’t have end. 
They hover like spirits, too fragile to fall, 
Too heavy for heaven, too lost for it all. 
I beg them to linger, to mark where I’ve been, 
To stain my existence with where I’ve caved in. 
But they slip through the cracks of a world made of glass, 
Where feelings are fleeting and nothing will last. 
So I cry in the silence, where no one can hear, 
And mourn for the drops that dissolve in the air—
Not fallen, not caught, not remembered, not near, 
Just gone, like the love that I held so dear.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They slip through my fingers like sand in the tide.
Each drop a whisper, a plea to remain,
But silence answers, again and again.
They fall to the earth, forgotten, unseen,
Lost in the cracks of what used to be green.
No puddle reflects the ache in my face,
Just dust that drinks sorrow without a trace.
I reach for their coolness, their shimmer, their glow,
But they vanish like secrets I’ll never let go.
Am I too heavy for grief to reside?
Why won’t even tears stay by my side?
They promise relief, a moment of grace,
Yet abandon me faster than time erases.
So I cry into voids where no echo replies,
And learn how the heart learns to cry without eyes.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They evaporate fast, as if they’re denied
the right to bear witness, the duty to fall,
like I’m not allowed sorrow at all.
They rise as mist, ghostly and thin,
Floating away from the skin they were in.
No trail on my cheeks, no stain on my shirt,
Just absence—proof I’m not hurt?
But the ache is real, deep in the bone,
A silent storm I face all alone.
If tears won’t stay, then what can I trust?
Not breath, not blood, not rust.
I whisper to shadows, ‘Please, bear my pain,’
But they too turn and walk away.
So I cry in the dark, where no one can see,
And the air drinks my grief like a dry, dying tree.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They dissolve in the air, nowhere to hide.
Not even the wind dares carry them near,
No echo, no ripple, no trace, no fear.
They vanish like words I never could say,
Like love that slipped through yesterday.
Each tear a small star, burning too brief,
A moment of light, then infinite grief.
I cup my hands, hoping to hold
something real, something bold.
But palms stay dry though the heart still bleeds,
Planting its sorrow in desperate seeds.
Will nothing remain when I finally break?
Not sound, not salt, not the shape of my ache?
So I mourn in silence, a ghost in disguise,
While tears learn to fly before they can cry.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They flee like birds from a sky torn wide.
No wet on my lashes, no blur in my view,
Just emptiness wearing the shape of the blue.
They leap from my eyes but refuse to descend,
As if gravity itself has turned its end.
Or maybe my sadness is too dense, too deep,
That even my tears fear the fall they must keep.
So they hover, suspended, a halo of pain,
A crown I wear in the pouring rain.
But raindrops fall hard; mine just float,
Lost in the air, adrift, remote.
If tears won’t weep, then how can I heal?
If grief has no outlet, is it even real?
I cry without proof, a soundless divide,
And wonder if sorrow dies when nothing can cry.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side,
They shatter mid-air, like glass open wide.
Each fragment a mirror reflecting my face,
But none show the boy I once was in grace.
They scatter like secrets the wind won’t protect,
Landing nowhere, rejected, dejected.
No puddle to stare back, no ripple to trace,
Just silence where sorrow should leave its embrace.
I beg for a drop, just one to remain,
To prove that this heart isn’t numb with disdain.
But the air drinks them fast, as if thirsty for proof
that I still feel, still bleed, still grieve, still love.
So I cry to the stars, ‘Bear my weight!’
And they blink—indifferent, cold, and late.
My tears are exiles, my soul their guide,
Forever fleeing, never by my side.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

responses.text:
I hunted words of skill through shadowed groves,
Where silence hums beneath the ancient boughs.
Each syllable a fox, both swift and sly,
That flicks its tail and darts when I draw nigh.
I tracked their prints in moss and crumbling bark,
Through tangled roots and light that dared not spark.
With ink-stained hands and breath held soft and low,
I waited where the wisest phrases grow.
A whisper stirs — a metaphor takes flight,
A flash of gold in deep poetic night.
I seized the phrase, though bleeding from the chase,
Its meaning pulsing warm within my grasp.
Not caught by force, but earned through patient will,
This word of skill, I carved it on the hill —
A monument to all the thoughts I've chased,
And proof that silence, too, may be embraced.

I hunted words of skill with sharpened mind,
Through dusty tomes and winds of time unkind.
Each letter lay like traps along the trail,
A cryptic map behind a poet’s veil.
I followed echoes where the metaphors breed,
In hollow caves where only dreamers heed.
The nouns were swift, the verbs would twist and flee,
Adjectives bloomed like flowers wild and free.
I snared a simile beneath the moon,
Its silver tongue reciting ancient tune.
Yet mastery came not from capture’s pride,
But in the stillness where the truths reside.
For every phrase that danced beyond my reach,
Another settled softly, just in speech.
Now I no longer hunt with spear or snare —
I breathe, and words of skill gather like air.

I hunted words of skill across the page,
A nomad lost in literature’s vast stage.
With pen as lance and heart a trembling drum,
I charged the lines where meaning overcome.
Each stanza hid a beast of rhythmic grace,
A line of fire in some forgotten place.
I lured them out with questions deep and old,
With grief, with love, with stories left untold.
One night, a sonnet rose with eyes aglow,
It spoke in tones only the silence know.
I did not slay, nor cage, nor claim its soul —
We walked together, making broken whole.
Now every word I write bears gentle marks,
Not of the hunt, but of the shared dark.
For skill is not in conquest, sharp and cold,
But in the trust between the brave and bold.

I hunted words of skill through midnight ink,
Where thoughts like wolves through corridors would blink.
Each phrase a shadow slipping through the cracks,
A fleeting spark upon the grammar tracks.
I set my traps with meter, rhyme, and care,
Baited with longing, lit by pale despair.
But words of true skill never come when called —
They rise like mist when all defenses fall.
One dawn, I dropped my quill, let silence reign,
No chase, no cry, no hunger to explain.
And then — a whisper, soft upon my skin:
A perfect line that let the light come in.
It wasn’t caught; it chose to be revealed,
A truth that only patient stillness healed.
So now I wait, not hunt, with open hand —
And words of skill return to native land.

I hunted words of skill beneath a storm,
Where thunder cracked in pentameter form.
The wind recited odes no ear could hear,
And lightning spelled the lines I longed for clear.
I climbed the cliffs where bold allusions soared,
Where ancient runes in canyon walls were stored.
Each step a risk, each breath a measured line,
To steal one phrase from genius divine.
I found a verse half-buried in the snow,
Its syllables still pulsing, aglow.
But as I grasped it, frost bit through my glove —
The word was truth, and truth is hard to love.
Now I return, not empty, but remade,
By every choice in shadowed paths displayed.
For skill was not the quarry I pursued,
But how the hunt, itself, refined my mood.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

responses.text:

I hunted words of skill across the page’s vast plain,

No map to guide, no compass but my breath,
I tracked the footprints vowels had left behind,

I cornered simile in twilight’s cleft,

I hunted words of skill in quiet rooms,
