But still I followed, frail and worn,
For in your eyes, the dawn was born.
Now here I stand, where waters meet,
Your breath the pulse beneath my feet.
No more the journey, cold and strong—
The river led me to you, at last, where I belong.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
A silver thread through ancient song,
Cutting canyons, carving time,
Bearing witness, bearing rhyme.
I drifted lost in shadowed glens,
Haunted by the might-have-beens,
But eddies curled like guiding hands,
Drawing me through broken lands.
Each stone I passed, a prayer I made,
Each storm that broke, a vow conveyed.
The water wept, the banks did sigh,
Yet onward, ever, I drew nigh.
And when at last I saw your face,
Reflected in that sacred place,
I knew the floods, the frost, the fight—
Were just the river’s path to light.
Now we stand where waters part,
Beating heart to beating heart.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
A nomad’s tale, a pilgrim’s song.
I walked where willows wept and leaned,
Where sorrow pooled and dreams had been.
But in the current, soft and low,
I heard your name begin to grow—
Not shouted, but a quiet call,
Like moonlight touching waterfall.
I crossed the rapids, sharp and wide,
With nothing but my faith as guide.
My clothes were torn, my spirit thin,
Yet something pulled me deep within.
And when the banks at last drew near,
And I beheld you standing there,
Time folded like a closing door—
The river led me, and I’m yours.
No map, no star, no creed could do
What water whispered: I lead to you.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
A crooked path, a winding song.
I cursed the rocks, I cursed the rain,
I cursed the silence, cursed the pain.
But every curse the water took,
And turned it into quiet brook,
That sang beneath the cypress trees,
And danced upon the evening breeze.
I lost my way a thousand times,
Chasing phantoms, broken rhymes,
Yet always, like a steady drum,
The river murmured, "Overcome."
And now I stand where currents cease,
Where love has brought me into peace.
Your hand in mine, the journey done—
The river led, and love has won.
No longer lost, no more apart—
The river led me straight to heart.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
A hymn of flood, a siren’s song.
I battled tides with aching limbs,
Through fevered dreams and shadowed hymns.
Yet in the depths, a current clear
Would banish doubt, dispel my fear,
And in its pull, I felt a thread—
A nameless voice that softly said:
"Endure, for love is ever near."
So I pressed on, year after year,
While seasons turned and mountains fell,
And something in me knew you well
Before I saw your face appear,
Before I felt you standing here.
Now time dissolves, the waters blend—
This journey had no true beginning, only end
In your embrace, where rivers run
Not to the sea, but to one.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,'

responses.text:
The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
Through jagged rocks and twilight songs,
Where willows wept and currents curled,
I wandered, lost, across the world.
Each bend a test, each eddy, pain,
Yet something called, a distant strain.
Not voice, nor light, but something true—
A pulse within the water’s blue.
I waded through the frozen dawn,
My spirit frayed, my hope half-gone.
But in the current’s gentle push,
I found the path, I found the hush.
And there you stood, where waters meet,
With eyes like rain and calm, complete.
The river knew what I could not—
That love is forged in trial and rust.
So I thank the stream, both fierce and kind,
That carved my soul to match your mind.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
A silver thread through ancient song.
It wound through canyons, deep and wide,
Where shadows lived and dreams would hide.
I followed blindly, bruised and torn,
Bearing burdens not yet born.
Yet every ripple, every fall,
Seemed to whisper, "Hold, hold on,"
As if the water knew your face,
And shaped my steps with quiet grace.
The storms I weathered, cold and grim,
Were but the prelude to the hymn
That rose when first I saw your hand
Outstretched upon the river’s sand.
No map, no star, could chart this course—
Just water’s will, and love’s true force.
And now I stand, where currents cease,
Fulfilled by silence, love, and peace.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
A winding tale of right and wrong.
It pulled me past the cliffs of doubt,
Where silence screamed and fears ran out.
I stumbled through the thorned ravine,
Beneath a sky of ashen sheen.
But in the murmur of the flow,
A promise stirred I didn’t know.
Not words, but warmth beneath the skin,
A pull that drew me deep within.
And when the waters slowed and cleared,
I saw your face, my heart appeared.
No need for speech, no need to prove—
The river spoke with patient love.
It shaped the banks, it shaped my soul,
To make me ready, make me whole.
Now hand in hand, we stand and gaze
At where the water meets the days.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
A crooked path where I went wrong
More times than stars that pierce the night,
Yet still the current held me tight.
It dragged me through the choking reeds,
Through sleepless nights and selfish deeds,
But never let me drift too far—
A steady pull, my guiding star.
And when I knelt, too weak to stand,
It lifted me with gentle hand.
The waters sang of distant shores,
Of open hearts and open doors.
And there, where river kissed the sea,
You waited, calm, in harmony.
No grand design, no fated plan,
Just water’s truth, and love’s long span.
So I believe in streams that choose,
And every soul the current views.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
A serpentine trail of grief and song.
I crossed the marsh where echoes died,
And climbed the banks on blistered pride.
Each mile a mirror, harsh and clear,
Reflecting every hidden fear.
But deep within the river’s core,
A rhythm called from evermore.
Not loud, but constant, like a breath,
That danced with life, defied my death.
And when at last the current stilled,
Your presence rose, the world fulfilled.
No need for reasons, signs, or proof—
The water knew the path, the truth.
It carried me through fire and frost,
To find what I had never lost.
Now we stand where waters end,
Lovers, and rivers, and true friends.
